questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history of diarrhea and poor appetite. He has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. A duodenal biopsy is taken and the histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following noninvasive serological studies is the most sensitive to confirm the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette, along with the biopsy image showing villous atrophy, crypt hyperplasia, and lamina propria infiltrates, indicate a case of celiac disease. The most sensitive noninvasive serological test that can be used for diagnosis is the measurement of IgA antibodies against tissue transglutaminase.

Celiac disease is an autoimmune gluten-induced enteropathy. It is associated with HLA DQ2 and DQ8. The pathogenesis of celiac disease involves an inflammatory response to gluten and gliadin (gluten-derived peptide). In the small intestine, gliadin is deamidated by the tissue transglutaminase (tTG), an intestinal enzyme. The deamidated gliadin is more immunogenic and is presented to helper T cells, which mediate mucosal inflammation and cause tissue damage. 

Clinically, patients with celiac disease present with malabsorption syndrome with diarrhoea, abdominal pain, bloating, chronic refractory anaemia, and marked unintentional weight loss. Some patients may also present with dermatitis herpetiformis characterised by blistering lesions caused by the deposition of IgA at the tips of the dermal papillae.

Antiendomysial and anti-tTG antibodies are found in serological studies.

Microscopic findings on biopsy of the proximal small intestine will show villi atrophy, villi flattening, crypt hyperplasia, and increased intraepithelial CD8+ T lymphocytes.

Management of patients with celiac disease involves starting patients on a gluten-free diet.

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

The following are the general tests for malabsorption:

Qualitative: Sudan III staining

questions.text: Which subunit of Nerve Growth Factor has Trypsin like activity?
questions.solution:
Alpha subunit of Nerve Growth Factor has Trypsin like activity.

 Nerve Growth Factor is the first neurotrophin identified. It is a protein growth factor that is needed for the growth and maintenance of sympathetic neurons and some sensory neurons.

It is made up of two α, two β, and two γ subunits.

Subunit Function
α Trypsin like activity
β Nerve growth-promoting activity
γ Serine proteases

The structure of the β subunit of NGF resembles that of insulin.

questions.text: A 20-year-old man with a history of usage of a drug that comes in a  colorful graphic blotting paper presents to the OPD with visual perception changes. He says that the episodes last for seconds to minutes and have recurred for the past 7 months. Which of the following drugs does he most likely consume and what is the effect he experiences?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse which is consumed on colorful graphic blotting paper the patient experiences a flashback phenomenon with recurrent visual perception changes lasting for seconds to minutes. 

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc.

Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. Flashbacks are defined as episodic recurrences of drug effects after the acute pharmacological effects have subsided and are very transient. This syndrome is diagnosed as a hallucinogen persisting perception disorder according to DSM-5.

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other options-

Option A: Run amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania. The person kills anyone against whom he may have real or imaginary enmity and then kills anyone that comes in his way until homicidal tendencies last. 

Option B: The "cold turkey" phenomenon refers to the intense withdrawal symptoms that occur when an individual abruptly stops using heroin, typically starting 8 to 10 hours after the last dose. Initial symptoms include lacrimation, rhinorrhea, yawning, and sweating. As the withdrawal progresses, individuals may experience more severe symptoms such as weakness, chills, gooseflesh, nausea, muscle aches, and hyperthermia. 

Option C: Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs characteristic of chronic cocaine abuse. It is a feeling as if grains of sand are lying under the skin or some small insects are creeping on the skin giving rise to an itching sensation(formication, tactile hallucinations) with resultant excoriation, leading to irregular scratches and ulcers.

questions.text: A young woman developed sudden onset congestive heart failure. Her condition rapidly deteriorated and she died after a few days. Autopsy of the heart showed patchy interstitial infiltrates composed mainly of lymphocytes, some of which surrounded individual myocytes. What is the most common cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the autopsy showed patchy interstitial infiltrates composed mainly of lymphocytes is suggestive of viral myocarditis.

Viral myocarditis is the most common cause of inflammation of the myocardium. The most common viral causes are coxsackieviruses A and B, echovirus, and influenza virus. Most patients recover from acute myocarditis, but a few may die from congestive heart failure or arrhythmias.

On gross examination, the heart appears normal or dilated. Sections of the heart show interstitial inflammatory infiltrate with focal myocyte necrosis. There is a predominant lymphocytic infiltration. 

Other options:

Option A-  Giant cell myocarditis is characterized by granulomatous inflammation with multinucleated giant cells (fused macrophages) interspersed with lymphocytes, eosinophils, plasma cells, and macrophages.

Option B- Protozoal myocarditis occurs in Chagas disease (Trypanosoma cruzi), toxoplasmosis, etc. Histopathology will show the presence of parasites in the myofibers along with infiltrates of neutrophils, lymphocytes, and macrophages. 

Option C- Hypersensitivity myocarditis is caused due to hypersensitivity reactions to several drugs. The inflammatory infiltrate includes many eosinophils, and the infiltrate is principally perivascular.

questions.text: A 6-month old infant presented with progressive macrocephaly, hypotonia, and delayed milestones. He had one episode of seizure in the previous week. MRI was done which showed diffuse white matter degeneration. MR spectroscopy finding is given below. What is the pathology associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
Deficiency of aspartoacylase leads to Canavan disease, a severe leukodystrophy, characterized by excessive excretion of N-acetylaspartic acid (NAA) and spongy degeneration of the white matter of the brain. MRS can show a high peak of N-acetylaspartic acid.

Metachromatic leukodystrophy is an autosomal recessive disease that results from a deficiency of the lysosomal enzyme arylsulfatase A.

Mutations in intermediate filament proteins such as GFAP cause Alexander disease

ABCD1 peroxisomal transporter mutation is involved in Adrenoleukodystrophy.

questions.text: A one-month-old male baby was brought to your OPD with complaints of seizures, vomiting, and weak limb movements. He was delivered at term by C-section and weighed 2.7 kilograms at birth. Examination revealed bulging fontanelles and head circumference more than 97 percentile for the age and sex. Hypotonia was present. A CT scan was performed which showed the following findings. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This clinical vignette of an infant with symptoms of hydrocephalus and a CT scan showing a large posterior fossa cyst with a poorly developed cerebellum and absent normal vermis is strongly suggestive of Dandy-Walker malformation. 

It is a developmental anomaly characterized by

  • Cystic dilation of the fourth ventricle
  • Poorly developed cerebellum that is displaced superiorly and laterally
  • Hypoplasia of the cerebellar vermis
  • An enlarged posterior fossa with an elevation of the lateral venous sinuses and the tentorium
  • Atresia of the foramen of Magendie and possibly, the foramen of Luschka.

Clinically, the obstruction to CSF flow leads to non-communicating hydrocephalus which presents as nausea, projectile vomiting, seizures, bulging fontanelles, large head circumference, developmental delay, hypotonia, and 'sunset sign'. It can be diagnosed with ultrasonography, CT, or MRI. 

Other options-

Option B- Arnold Chiari malformation is the most common malformation of the posterior fossa and hindbrain. There are two types of Chiari malformations- 

  • Chiari I malformation—This is the more common type. The cerebellar tonsils are displaced downward through the foramen magnum. It may be associated with syringomyelia.
  • Chiari II malformation: Displacement of the medulla, the fourth ventricle, and cerebellar vermis through the foramen magnum. It is almost always associated with a myelomeningocele.

Given below is an image of Chiari I malformation-

Given below is an image of Chiari II malformation-

Option C: Joubert syndrome is an autosomal recessive neurologic disorder that is characterized by cerebellar vermis hypoplasia. Affected neonates will present with hypotonia, tachypnoea, abnormal eye movements and mental retardation. Given below is an MRI of the brain showing the pathognomonic "molar tooth sign" which is due to the presence of prominent superior cerebellar peduncles. 

Option D: Holoprosencephaly is a developmental disorder of the brain that results from the defective formation of the prosencephalon/forebrain. Given below is an ultrasound showing lobar holoprosencephaly.

questions.text: In a road traffic accident victim with a GCS scale of 8/15, rapid-sequence intubation is planned. Which of the following is not done in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Manual ventilation before intubation is not done in rapid-sequence induction (RSI).

RSI is done during emergency surgery, with the objective of securing the airway rapidly and preventing aspiration.

Steps of RSI are shown in the image below:

Steps not done in RSI:

  • Manual ventilation before intubation: Avoided as this inflates the stomach and causes regurgitation
  • Premedications: Not given as surgery is done immediately under emergency

RSI is avoided in patients with raised intracranial pressure as it worsens the condition.

questions.text: A patient presents with claudication in the right thigh during walking. There is no history of impotence or buttock claudication. On examination, the right femoral and distal pulses are absent. Angiography suggestive of peripheral obstructive vascular disease is given below. What will be the best surgical management?
questions.solution:
The symptom of pain in the right thigh while walking and the given angiography findings are suggestive of aortoiliac occlusive disease with right common iliac artery obstruction. The treatment of choice for unilateral iliac vessel occlusion is an aortofemoral bypass.

Atherosclerosis is the most common cause of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases.

Diagnosis of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases includes:

  • Clinical examination- weakened pulses below the level of obstruction
  • Reduced Ankle-Brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) -<0.9 - intermittent claudication (occlusive arterial disease)<0.3 - critical limb ischemia.
  • Color doppler- normal artery has a triphasic signal
    • Biphasic waveform - mild-moderate stenosis
    • Monophasic waveform - severe stenosis
  • Duplex scanning - a non-invasive technique that uses a combination of B mode ultrasound and Doppler study. 
  • Digital subtraction angiography (DSA) is now the standard technique. The artery is better outlined because the photos are digitized by a computer, which removes extraneous tissues.
  • CT angiography (CTA) and MR angiography (MRA) - for extent and type of obstruction. These are not used routinely for the diagnosis but only if symptoms warrant surgical intervention.

Below is an angiography image showing the right common iliac artery obstruction.

Management of peripheral obstructive vascular diseases is as follows:

  • Carbohydrate and lipid-free diet
  • Graduated exercise program in combination with smoking cessation improves walking efficiency
  • Control of hypertension, diabetes, and hyperlipidemia
  • Percutaneous transluminal balloon angioplasty (PTA) - is more useful for isolated iliac stenosis (<4cm in length) rather than occlusion
  • Bypass graft surgeries 

The site of obstruction, the clinical findings, and recommended bypass graft surgeries are tabulated below:

A collagen-impregnated, knitted Dacron graft is used for proximal aortic anastomosis in aortofemoral bypass. For femoropopliteal bypass grafting, a great saphenous vein graft is ideal.

questions.text: A 35-year-old patient presents with a one-year history of intermittent chest pain, headaches, and abdominal pain. She reports seeing multiple specialists and undergoing extensive testing, all of which have returned with normal results. She is still convinced of having a serious underlying disorder. Her social life has been affected, as she is always preoccupied with researching her symptoms. How would you manage this patient?

choices.text: Recommend a diet and lifestyle modification plan

questions.solution:
The patient with intermittent chest pain, headaches, and abdominal pain for one year with normal findings on examination and repeat investigations is indicative of somatic symptom disorder and should be managed with reassurance and scheduling regular appointments.

The presence of one or more somatic symptoms for more than 6 months in the absence of an organic cause is suggestive of somatic symptom disorder. It is characterized by the fear of having a serious illness based on the person's misinterpretation of bodily symptoms.

It equally affects men and women and is commonly seen in the third decade of life. It is associated with poor insight. Patients believe that they have a serious disease that has not yet been detected and they can­not be persuaded otherwise. Their convictions persist despite negative laboratory results, the benign course of the alleged disease over time, and reassurances from doctors.

DSM-5 criteria for the diagnosis of somatic symptom disorder: 

  • One or more somatic symptoms that are distressing or result in significant disruption of daily life.
  • Excessive thoughts, feelings, or behaviors related to the somatic symptoms or associ­ated health concerns as manifested by at least one of the following:
    • Disproportionate and persistent thoughts about the seriousness of one’s symptoms.
    • Persistently high level of anxiety about health or symptoms.
    • Excessive time and energy are devoted to these symptoms or health concerns.
  • Although a single somatic symptom may not be continuously present, the state of be­ing symptomatic is persistent.
  • The belief cannot have the intensity of a delusion, as seen in a delusional disorder, and cannot be restricted to distress about appearance, as seen in a body dysmorphic disorder.

Smith's consultation letter is associated with somatic symptom disorder. 

It is intended for primary care physicians. It provides them with do's and don'ts regarding their encounters with patients with multiple medically unexplained physical symptoms. It suggests the following:

  • Regularly scheduled appointments
  • Performing brief physical examinations focusing on the area of discomfort at each visit
  • Avoid unnecessary diagnostic procedures, invasive treatments(option D), and hospitalizations
  • Avoid using statements such as symptoms are all in your head
  • Encourage patients to talk about stressors

Other options :

Option B: SSRIs in somatic symptom disorder are not used as first-line and are indicated if the patient has comorbid depression or anxiety disorder.

Related Pearl: Somatoform Disorder

Somatoform Disorder

Key features of somatic symptom and related disorders

Somatic symptom disorder

Excessive anxiety and preoccupation with ≥1 unexplained symptom

Illness anxiety disorder

(hypochondriasis)

Fear of having a serious illness despite few or no symptoms and consistently negative evaluations

Conversion disorder

(functional neurologic symptom disorder)

Neurologic symptom  incompatible with any known neurologic disease, often acute onset associated with stress

Factitious disorder

Intentional falsification or inducement of symptoms with a goal to assume the sick role

Malingering

Falsification or exaggeration of symptoms to obtain external incentives (secondary gain)

questions.text:
A 35-year-old multiparous woman presents with SUI that has persisted for 6 months despite regular Kegel exercises. Which of the following medications can be used as part of the conservative management in this patient?

Stress Urinary Incontinence - SUI
questions.solution:
Venlafaxine is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) indicated in SUI.

It demonstrates efficacy in improving SUI, especially in women with concurrent depression or anxiety. It works by increasing levels of serotonin and norepinephrine, which can enhance urethral sphincter strength and improve bladder control.

GSI is defined as a small involuntary leakage of urine with increased abdominal pressure in the absence of detrusor contraction. It occurs when the bladder pressure exceeds urethral pressure during physical stress in the absence of detrusor contraction.
 
Grading of GSI:
Grade I: Incontinence with only severe stress, such as coughing, sneezing, and jogging
Grade II: Incontinence with moderate stress, such as fast walking, and going up and down the stairs
Grade III: Incontinence with mild stress such as standing

Investigations are only done prior to surgery to confirm the diagnosis. They include the stress test, cotton swab or Q tip test, Marshall and Bonney’s test, urethroscopy, and urodynamic studies. These are not required prior to conservative management.

Conservative treatment should be the first approach, especially for younger women, as it is cost-effective, has fewer complications, and preserves future surgical options. This approach is also suitable for elderly or frail women, those unfit for surgery, and those desiring to bear children. Kegel exercises, particularly beneficial for younger women with mild stress incontinence, can significantly improve symptoms over 8-12 weeks. Surgical options are available but should be considered only after conservative methods, especially in young women, as future pregnancies may affect surgical outcomes.

Conservative management of GSI:

  • Kegel pelvic floor exercises
  • Drugs - Alpha-adrenergic drugs, venlafaxine, imipramine, and estrogen cream.
  • Ring pessaries/vaginal cones
  • Electric stimulation
  • Artificial urinary sphincter (AUS) system

Surgical management of GSI:

  • Vaginal Operations: Kelly’s repair: Anterior colporrhaphy with plication of the bladder neck
  • Pacey’s repair: Apposing medial fibers of puborectalis muscles in the midline under the bladder neck region to elevate it
  • Abdominal Operations: Marshall–Marchetti–Krantz operation: Retropubic colposuspension, where the bladder neck and the vaginal vault are sutured to the periosteum of the back of the pubic symphysis
  • Burch's colposuspension: Vaginal suspension achieved using the iliopectineal ligament
  • Laparoscopic colposuspension
  • Combined abdominal and vaginal operations: Pereyra operation
  • Tension-free vaginal tapes
  • Periurethral collagen injection

Other options:

Options B and C: Oxybutynin is an anticholinergic medication, and Mirabegron is a beta 3 receptor agonist primarily used for urge urinary incontinence (UUI) due to its bladder relaxant properties. It is not indicated for SUI, as it can worsen the condition by decreasing urethral tone.

Option D: Terazosin is an alpha-adrenergic blocker primarily used for benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) in men. It can worsen SUI in women by relaxing the urethral sphincter.

questions.text: A patient presented to the OPD with progressively worsening weakness. Initially, he could walk with short, jerky steps without assistance, but over time, he developed a crossed gait and now requires stick for balance while walking. Toxin contamination is suspected. What is the cofactor of the enzyme inhibited by the toxin likely causing his symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points towards lathyrism caused due to BOAA (beta oxalyly amino alanine). This toxin inhibits the enzyme lysyl oxidase whose cofactor is copper.

Lysyl oxidase is a copper-containing enzyme that is involved in the formation of cross-links in collagen synthesis. Inhibition of the enzyme by the sweet pea toxin leads to defective collagen formation and leads to lathyrism.  

Lathyrism is a paralyzing disease of humans and animals. It is due to the consumption of khesari dal/Lathyrus sativus or its variants such as sweet pea(Lathyrus odoratus). It is mostly consumed by agricultural laborers of poor economic status because it is relatively cheap. It can present as skeletal, vascular, or neural manifestations.

It usually affects young males aged 15-45 years and it is manifested in stages: 

  • Latent stage
  • No-stick stage
  • One-stick stage
  • Two-stick stage
  • Crawler stage

The patient is initially able to walk with short jerky steps without any aids, but the progressive spastic paralysis causes a crossed gait, and the patient has to use sticks to maintain his balance. Eventually, the knee joints are unable to support the weight of the body and the patient cannot stand erect at all. Long-term consumption of khesari dal leads to neurolathyrism. It is characterized by gradual spastic paralysis of the lower limbs.

The interventions that can be used to prevent lathyrism include:

  • Vitamin C prophylaxis
  • Limiting the proportion of the dal to less than a quarter of the total cereals and pulses consumed in a day
  • Removal of the toxin by parboiling and steeping method.

questions.text: A 12-year-old unvaccinated boy was suspected to have a diphtheria infection. The following test was performed in a microbiology lab to test the toxigenicity of the diphtheria strain. This is an example of which type of immunodiffusion method?
questions.solution:
The image shows double diffusion in two dimensions which is called the Ouchterlony procedure. An example is Elek’s test for testing toxigenicity in diphtheria bacilli. 

The images given below show the different types of immunodiffusion.

questions.text: Perifascicular atrophy is seen in :
questions.solution:
Perifascicular atrophy is seen in Dermatomyositis.

Myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles.

Dermatomyositis:

  • Dermatomyositis is an immunologic disease in which damage to small blood vessels contributes to muscle injury.
  • Muscle biopsies of affected patients show infiltrates of mononuclear inflammatory cells that tend to be most pronounced in the perimysial connective tissue and around blood vessels.
  • Sometimes there is a distinctive pattern in which myofiber atrophy is accentuated at the edges of the fascicles— perifascicular atrophy.

Muscle biopsy findings in dermatomyositis-

Other options:

Option D: Toxic myopathies/Drug-induced myopathies are mainly linked to lipid-lowering agents like statins and glucocorticoids, causing muscle pain, weakness, and elevated CK levels. High-dose glucocorticoids can result in acute quadriplegic myopathy, while chronic use leads to proximal weakness with normal CK levels. Other drugs, such as amphophilic cationic and antimicrotubular agents, may also cause muscle toxicity, identifiable by autophagic vacuoles in muscle biopsies.

Related Pearl: Inflammatory myopathy

questions.text: A 50-year-old male is admitted under palliative care after being diagnosed with end-stage lung cancer. He is noted to have extreme weight loss and complains of anorexia and fatigue. Which of the following changes are unlikely to be seen in this condition?

choices.text: Production of lactate by the cancer cells
Downregulation of muscle specific ubiquitin ligase

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario suggests cancer cachexia, where there is upregulation of muscle-specific ubiquitin ligase. Down-regulation of the enzyme is unlikely.

Cancer cachexia is a hypercatabolic state defined by a loss of muscle mass (with or without loss of fat) that cannot be explained by diminished food intake. It occurs in 50% of cancer patients, most commonly in individuals with gastrointestinal, pancreatic, and lung cancers, and is responsible for 30% of cancer deaths. It is a highly debilitating condition characterized by extreme weight loss, fatigue, muscle atrophy, anaemia, anorexia, and oedema. Atrophy of the diaphragm and other respiratory muscles can lead to respiratory failure which is a major cause of mortality in patients with cancer.

Certain factors contribute to the development of cachexia : 

  • Inflammatory cytokines like tumour necrosis factor (originally called cachectin), interleukin 1, and interleukin 6 (option D).
  • Proteolysis-inducing factor secreted by the tumour and the cytokines initiate the transcription of muscle-specific ubiquitin ligases. These ligases ubiquitinate structural components of myofibrils such as myosin heavy chain, leading to their degradation by the proteasome.
  • The lipid mobilizing factor secreted by the tumour increases fatty acid oxidation (option B).
  • In fast-growing cancer cells, glycolysis proceeds rapidly, forming large amounts of pyruvate, which is reduced to lactate (option A) and released. The lactate is used for gluconeogenesis in the liver and, combined with the marked increase in hepatic protein synthesis secondary to the increased delivery of amino acids from the catabolic muscle, contributes to the hypermetabolism seen in cancer cachexia.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presented with unilateral nasal obstruction and bloody nasal discharge. On examination, a polypoidal nasal mass is observed. A biopsy was taken from the mass and the histology image is shown below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with unilateral nasal obstruction, a nasal polypoidal mass, and bloody nasal discharge, along with the histological section showing ribbons of thickened epithelial proliferations growing downwards into the stroma, suggest a diagnosis of inverted papilloma.

An inverted papilloma is a benign tumour that originates from the nonolfactory mucosa of the nasal cavity, known as the Schneiderian membrane. Human papillomavirus (HPV) is believed to play a significant role in its development. This condition predominantly affects men aged 40-70 years.

Clinically, they are almost always unilateral and typically present with symptoms such as nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis. Due to their location and growth characteristics, these tumours can invade adjacent structures, including the sinuses and, in some cases, the orbit, necessitating careful monitoring and management.

On nasal endoscopy, it presents as a pale polypoidal mass. Biopsy is essential for diagnosis.

Medial maxillectomy is the treatment of choice. It can be performed by lateral rhinotomy or sublabial degloving approach. Radiotherapy is not advised as it may induce malignancy. 

Other options:

Option A: Rhinosporidiosis also presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge, but examination will show a mulberry or strawberry mass with white dots and subcutaneous nodules on the skin. The biopsy will show sporangium with sporangiospores as shown below.

Option C: Adenocarcinoma presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge, but examination will show an ulceroproliferative mass in the nasal cavity.

Option D: Olfactory neuroblastoma, or Esthesioneuroblastoma presents with unilateral nasal obstruction and discharge. These are highly vascular tumours that appear as cherry red polypoidal masses in the olfactory mucosa. The biopsy(as shown below) may reveal low-grade tumours with pseudorosettes or high-grade with nuclear pleomorphism.

Related Pearl: Inverted Papilloma

Inverted papilloma is also known as transitional cell papilloma or Ringertz tumor or Schneiderian papilloma. It is a common benign tumour of the paranasal sinuses. It is a premalignant condition with 10-15% chances of turning malignant.

Etiology: Human papillomavirus has been implicated in its etiology.

Origin: Arises from the lateral wall of the nose from the non-olfactory epithelium of the nose

Clinical features:

  • More common in men.
  • Predominance between 40-70 years.
  • Unilateral nasal obstruction, nasal discharge, and epistaxis are the main presenting symptoms
  • It is a locally invasive tumor and can invade orbit and paranasal sinuses.
  • Proptosis, diplopia, and lacrimation can result from orbital invasion

Findings: It is seen as a pale polypoidal mass resembling a simple nasal polyp.

Investigations: A biopsy is needed for diagnosis.

Treatment: Medial maxillectomy via lateral rhinotomy or midfacial degloving approach. Radiotherapy can lead to malignancy.

questions.text: According to the sustainable development goals, by 2030, neonatal mortality and under 5 mortality should be reduced to _____ (per 1000 live births) and ______ (per 1000 live births) respectively:
questions.solution:
In sustainable development goals, target 3.2 aims to reduce neonatal mortality to 12/1000 live births and under 5 mortality to 25/1000 live births, by the year 2030.

There are 17 global goals and 169 targets set for 2030 as part of the official Sustainable Development Goals of the Agenda 2030. Goals related to health are:

  • Goal 2- Reduce hunger, improve food security and improve nutrition
  • Goal 3- Ensure healthy lives and promote well being
  • Goal 6- Availability and management of water and sanitation

Important features of Goal 3 are (by 2030):

  • Reduce the global maternal mortality ratio to less than 70 per 100,000 live births
  • End preventable deaths of newborns and children under 5 years of age, and reduce neonatal mortality to at least as low as 12 per 1,000 live births and under-5 mortality to at least as low as 25 per 1,000 live births
  • End the epidemics of AIDS, tuberculosis, malaria, combat hepatitis, water-borne diseases, etc.
  • Reduce mortality from non-communicable diseases and improve mental health
  • Prevent and treat substance abuse
  • Achieve universal access to sexual and reproductive health-care services, including family planning, information and education, and the integration of reproductive health into national strategies and programs
  • Reduce deaths and illnesses from environmental pollution
  • Achieve universal health coverage for healthcare services.

questions.text: Immunofluorescence showing granular deposits of complement protein C3, IgG, IgA, and IgM indicates which of the following condition?
questions.solution:
Granular deposits of complement protein C3, IgG, IgA, and IgM on immunofluorescence are seen in Lupus nephritis.

Lupus nephritis is a systemic complication seen in patients with systemic lupus erythematosus(SLE). Immunofluorescence staining of the kidney biopsy specimen shows positive staining for fibrinogen, IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, λ chain, and k light chain. This is known as a full-house effect. 

Other options:

Option A: Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis - Immunofluorescent stain demonstrates discrete, coarsely granular deposits of complement protein C3 and IgG corresponding to “humps”. 

Option B: Negative immunofluorescence is indicative of minimal change disease. There are no Ig or complement deposits.

Option C: Focal segmental glomerulosclerosis - Immunofluorescence microscopy shows IgM and C3 deposition in the sclerotic areas and/or in the mesangium.

questions.text: A young animal rescue worker complained of an itchy rash on his abdomen. On examination, multiple creeping lesions are seen as shown in the image below. What is the drug of choice for this condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with an image showing red, raised serpiginous lesions are suggestive of cutaneous larva migrans. The drug of choice for this condition is ivermectin.

Cutaneous larva migrans is caused by non-human hookworms like Ancylostoma braziliense and Ancylostoma caninum. It is acquired via direct skin contact with soil contaminated by dog or cat feces. The larvae remain confined to the outer layers of skin, as they cannot penetrate the basement membrane of the human skin.

It presents as erythematous, pruritic papules at the site of entry. This is followed by the appearance of erythematous serpiginous tracks of lesions on skin. This is due to the migration of larva through the dermo-epidermal junction. The lesion shifts correspond to the movement of the larva. Hence these lesions are also called creeping eruptions.

Diagnosis is based mainly on clinical features.

The treatment includes topical application of thiabendazole and oral albendazole or ivermectin.

The differences between cutaneous larva migrans and visceral larva migrans are:

  Cutaneous larva migrans Visceral larva migrans
Tissue involved Skin Liver, lungs, and eyes
Infecting Organism Mostly by non-human nematodes Mostly by non-human nematodes (mainly by dogs and cats)
Portal of Entry Penetration of skin Ingestion of infected eggs
Eosinophilia Mild Persistent high
Serodiagnosis Not developed Well developed
Treatment Thiabendazole/ Albendazole/ Ivermectin

Albendazole/ Diethylcarbamazine (DEC) and Prednisolone. 

DEC has greater side effects than Albendazole so it is rarely used 


Note: A rapidly moving lesion (10cm/hr) produced by Strongyloides stercoralis is known as larva currens (running larva). It occurs as an otherwise asymptomatic lesion in immunocompetent individuals.

Other options:

Option B: Praziquantel is used for the treatment of all human tapeworms, neurocysticercosis, schistosomes, and Fasciola hepatica infection.

Option C: Diethylcarbamazine is used for the treatment of filariasis, visceral larva migrans, and tropical pulmonary eosinophilia.

Option D: Prednisolone is used as an immunosuppressant for the treatment of a variety of infections like neurocysticercosis, visceral larva migrans, etc.

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman presented with a large left breast mass with enlarged axillary lymph nodes. She also has a family history of breast cancer. Which is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis of breast carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Trucut /core-needle biopsy is the investigation of choice for confirming the diagnosis of breast carcinoma.

A 14 gauge needle is used for core biopsy which helps to analyze the breast architecture. The advantages include a low complication rate, minimal scarring, and a lower cost as compared to excisional breast biopsy.

Other options:

Option A: Fine-needle aspiration cytology (FNAC) is a cytological investigation and, hence, not the investigation of choice. The needle used is a 22 gauge needle. It is used in the case of non-palpable lesions.

Option C: Mammography is either used to screen asymptomatic patients or evaluate patients with abnormal findings such as a mass or discharge. Two views - a mediolateral oblique (MOL) and a craniocaudal (CC) view are obtained. The volume of breast tissue and axillary tail of Spence is seen in the MOL view whereas the medial aspect of the breast is seen through the CC view. 

Option D: Excisional biopsy is one in which the breast lesion along with normal breast tissue is removed. It is done when the results of the core biopsy are not consistent with imaging findings and clinical findings.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues best represents the graph as shown below?
questions.solution:
The graph shows an increase in glucose transporter expression with the increase in insulin secretion which is representative of tissues expressing insulin-dependent glucose transporters which is found in the adipose tissue, cardiac muscle and skeletal muscle.

Glucose uptake by skeletal muscle, cardiac muscle and adipose tissues is via GLUT-4 which is insulin-dependent. 

In the cytoplasm of insulin-sensitive cells, the vesicles contain a pool of GLUT-4 molecules. When the insulin receptors of these cells are activated, the vesicles move rapidly to the cell membrane and fuse with it, inserting the transporters into the cell membrane.

The membrane patches containing transporters are endocytosed when insulin action stops, preparing the vesicles for subsequent insulin exposure. Phosphoinositol 3-kinase is activated by the insulin receptor, which causes the vesicles to migrate to the cell membrane.

The other GLUT transporters are not insulin-sensitive and are constitutively expressed in the cell membrane. Ex: GLUT-1 in RBC's and brain, GLUT-2 in the beta cells of the pancreas and GLUT-3 present in the brain and kidneys.

questions.text: A 23-year-old male presents to the ER after a skateboarding accident during which he had fallen with head hitting the ground first. He has a nasal discharge which has the following appearance on a tissue paper. The investigation of choice for localizing the site is:
questions.solution:
HRCT is the investigation of choice for localizing the site of the leak in CSF rhinorrhea. History of head trauma along with nasal discharge that shows double target sign on tissue paper is consistent with traumatic CSF rhinorrhea.

Though Beta 2-transferrin assay is the best laboratory test for identifying the presence of CSF in the sinonasal fluid it does not provide information regarding the site or laterality of the defect.

Related Pearl: Features of CSF rhinorrhea

  • Reservoir sign - In CSF rhinorrhea, the fluid which had collected in the sinuses, particularly sphenoid, empties into the nose.
  • Double ring sign or halo sign or target sign - CSF is mixed with blood and collected on a piece of filter paper. It shows a central red spot (blood) and a peripheral lighter halo.

The image below shows the double ring sign in CSF rhinorrhoea:

  • CSF can’t be sniffed back.
  • CSF doesn’t stiffen the handkerchief.

 

Note: The repeated reappearance of pus immediately after cleaning, in the external auditory canal of patients with acute mastoiditis/coalescent mastoiditis is also referred to as Reservoir sign.

questions.text: You were asked to assess a 36-year-old primigravid woman in her 40th week of gestation just before labor was induced. Which of the following are favorable factors for successful induction of labor in this woman?
questions.solution:
A body mass index of < 30 kg/m2 favors successful induction of labor.

Favorable factors for induction of labor include:

  • Young age
  • Mul­tiparity
  • Body mass index (BMI) < 30
  • Favorable cervix; Bishops score ≥ 9. A score of < or = 6 is considered unfavorable
  • Estimated fetal birthweight < 3.5kg
  • Positive oxytocin sensitivity test (indicates the sensitivity of the uterus)
  • Period of gestation closer to term or post-term
  • Presence of fetal fibronectin in vaginal swab (> 50 ng/mL) 

Note:

  • As per Williams Obstetrics 26th edition, a Bishop's score ≥9 indicates a high likelihood for successful induction of labor.
  • As per NICE guidelines, a Bishop's score ≥8 indicates that the cervix is ripe, favorable, a high chance of spontaneous delivery or response to induction.
  • As per FOGSI guidelines, the cervix is considered favorable if Bishop's score is > 6.

Related Pearl: Indications & contraindications for induction of labor

Indications:
  • Uncontrolled maternal diabetes mellitus
  • Gestational hypertension
  • Pre-eclampsia
  • Post-term pregnancy
  • Abruption placentae
  • Premature rupture of membranes
  • Rh-isoimmunization
  • Intra-uterine growth restriction (IUGR)
  • Intra-uterine death (IUD)
  • Oligohydramnios
Contraindications:
  • Contracted/distorted pelvis and cephalopelvic disproportion
  • Placenta previa or vasa previa
  • Active genital herpes
  • Pelvic tumor & carcinoma cervix
  • Transverse lie or footling breech
  • Appreciable macrosomia
  • Severe hydrocephalus
  • Umbilical cord prolapse
  • High-risk pregnancy with fetal compromise
  • Previous classical cesarean or hysterotomy
  • Previous history of uterine rupture
  • Pelvic surgeries like vesicovaginal fistula/rectovaginal fistula/pelvic floor repair (third or fourth-degree perineal tears repair)
  • Previous 3 or more lower transverse cesarian sections.

Related Pearl: Bishop’s Score (Modified)

Score 0 1 2 3
Dilatation (cm) Closed 1-2 3-4 5+
Cervical length (cm) >4 2-4 1-2 <1
Consistency Firm Medium Soft -
Position Posterior Midline Anterior -
Head-Station -3 -2 -1, 0 +1, +2

Total score = 13

Favourable= 6-13

Unfavourable= 0-5

Note: 

  • According to NICE guidelines, a score of 6-13 is favorable for induction of labour.
  • According to Williams Obstetrics (26th edition), a score of 9 or more indicates a high likelihood of successful induction.

questions.text:
A 62-year-old male presents to the OPD with yellowish discoloration of the eyes. He has a history of daily alcohol consumption for the last 25 years. You send some laboratory investigations which are given below. Considering his high PT, you admit the patient and provide parenteral vitamin K to him. His PT the next morning was 12 seconds. What is the most likely pathology in this patient?

TSB (total serum bilirubin): increased

ALT: 89 IU

AST: 96 IU

Total cholesterol: 448 mg/dL

LDL: 212 mg/dL

PT (prothrombin time): 22 seconds
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, laboratory investigations revealing moderately elevated aminotransferases and prolonged PT, which is corrected with parenteral vitamin K, suggest cholestasis.

Cholestasis occurs when bile flow is obstructed, leading to the accumulation of bile acids and bilirubin. The elevated total serum bilirubin, along with the elevated PT here suggests impaired liver function. Cholestasis can cause malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins (A, D, E, K) due to decreased bile salt availability, which is essential for fat absorption. The need for parenteral vitamin K in this patient indicates that he was likely experiencing malabsorption of fat-soluble vitamins due to cholestasis.

Other options:

Option A: Acute fulminant hepatitis typically presents with a rapid onset of severe liver dysfunction, often leading to hepatic encephalopathy. While the patient has elevated PT, the mild elevation in ALT and AST is not consistent with the severe transaminitis seen in fulminant hepatitis. Additionally, the patient's chronic alcohol use points more toward chronic liver disease rather than an acute process.

Option B: Gilbert's syndrome is characterised by intermittent hyperbilirubinemia due to decreased bilirubin conjugation, but it does not usually lead to significant jaundice or liver enzyme elevations, nor does cause elevated PT.

Option C: Given the history of alcohol use, alcoholic hepatitis usually presents with higher AST and ALT levels (often >300 IU), significant hepatomegaly, and potentially more severe coagulopathy, which is unlikely in this case.

Related Pearl: Laboratory Evaluation of Liver Disease

Test Category

Hepatocyte integrity

Cytosolic hepatocellular enzymes

Serum aspartate aminotransferase (AST)

Serum alanine aminotransferase (ALT)

Serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH)

Biliary excretory function

Substances normally secreted in bile

Serum bilirubin

  • Total: unconjugated plus conjugated
  • Direct: conjugated only

Urine bilirubin

Serum bile acids

Plasma membrane enzymes (from damage to bile canaliculus)

Serum alkaline phosphatase

Serum γ-glutamyl transpeptidase (GGT)

Hepatocyte synthetic function

Serum albumin

Coagulation factors:

Prothrombin (PT) and partial thromboplastin time (PTT) (fibrinogen, prothrombin, factors V, VII, IX, and X)

Hepatocyte metabolism

questions.text: A 46-year old lady is being evaluated for abnormal uterine bleeding by a dilatation and curettage procedure. The following instruments are placed on a table in the minor operating theatre. Which of the following instruments will be used in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Among the given instruments 1, 2, and 3 - Sim's uterine curette, Hegar's dilators, and Simpson's uterine sound are used for dilatation and curettage (D&C).

Instruments used in D&C:

  • Sim’s speculum: It retracts the posterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix
  • Anterior vaginal wall retractor: Retracts the anterior vaginal wall to expose the cervix.
  • Vulsellum or Allis forceps: To hold the anterior lip of the cervix
  • Uterine sound: Simpson's uterine sound is a 30 cm long angulated instrument with a handle at one end and a rounded blunt tip at the other.
    It is used to measure the length of the uterus. It can be identified by the markings used for measurement
  • Cervical dilators: 
    • Hegar's dilator is a double-ended dilator used to dilate the cervix.
    • Hawkins’ single-ended dilator 
    • Fenton’s dilator
  • Curette:
    • Sim's curette is a single-ended curette
    • Blake's curette is a double-ended curette

Other options: 

Karman's cannula: It is used for menstrual regulation. 

Leech Wilkinson's cannula and Rubin's cannula are used in hysterosalpingography.

Related Pearl: Instruments in OBG

questions.text:
A male infant presents with hypertension and undervirilized genitalia. Which of the following are correct laboratory findings regarding the diagnosis?
  Cortisol Corticosterone Aldosterone 17-OH progesterone

1

 ↑ ↓ ↓ ↓
2 ↓ ↑ ↑ ↓
3 ↓ ↓ ↑ ↓
4 ↓ ↓ ↓ ↑
questions.solution:
Incomplete virilization of male genitalia and the presence of hypertension indicate 17α hydroxylase deficiency presenting with decreased levels of cortisol and 17-OH progesterone and increased levels of corticosterone and aldosterone (option B).

Since the patient has hypertension, it suggests increased aldosterone or deoxycorticosterone. Thus, there are two conditions with increased blood pressure.

  1. 17α-hydroxylase deficiency:- increased aldosterone with decreased androgens leading to undervirilized male genitalia.
  2. 11β-hydroxylase deficiency:- increased deoxycorticosterone and decreased aldosterone but with increased androgens, leading to normal male infants but females with ambiguous genitalia.

Related Pearl: Variants of Congenital Adrenal Hyperplasia (CAH)

21-hydroxylase deficiency 17-hydroxylase deficiency 11β-hydroxylase deficiency 3β-HSD deficiency

Deficiency of cortisol and aldosterone

Deficiency of cortisol and sex hormones

Deficiency of cortisol

Deficiency of cortisol, aldosterone, and testosterone

↑ in testosterone

 ↑ in aldosterone ↑ in deoxycorticosterone (mineralocorticoid) and testosterone  ↑ in DHEA
Salt wasting crises Salt retention and  hypertension

Salt retention and  hypertension

 Salt-wasting crises
Virilization of females (ambiguous genitalia 46XX)     Failure of sexual development in females at puberty Virilization of females  (ambiguous genitalia 46XX) Females are mildly
virilized (DHEA is a weak androgen)
Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY) Precocious puberty in males Males are incompletely virilized (ambiguous genitalia 46XY)

Note: In 11β-hydroxylase deficiency, aldosterone synthetic capacity is normal and some corticosterone is synthesized from progesterone by intact aldosterone synthase enzyme. Thus, it is unusual for patients to manifest signs of adrenal insufficiency.

questions.text: A 60-year-old woman from a rural area presents with a gritty sensation in her eyes and a past history of salivary gland swelling. She is on oral pilocarpine and steroids. Rose Bengal staining is positive as shown below, especially in the interpalpebral areas. Schirmer's test shows 7mm of wetting in 5 minutes. Which of the following layers of tear film is deficient in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario along with the the findings of interpalpebral conjunctival involvement on rose bengal stain and dry eye on Schirmer's test (< 10 mm in 5 minutes) indicate keratoconjunctivitis sicca. It occurs due to a deficiency of the aqueous layer of tear film.

She also has a history of parotid swelling and dry eyes, both of which are characteristic of Sjogren’s syndrome, which is a common cause of keratoconjunctivitis sicca. Her use of oral pilocarpine to stimulate salivary gland secretion and steroids for immunosuppression further supports the diagnosis.

Keratoconjunctivitis sicca:

Causes:

  • Sjogren's syndrome (primary keratoconjunctivitis sicca)
  • Non-Sjogren's keratoconjunctivitis sicca
    • Primary age-related hyposecretion (most common)
    • Lacrimal gland deficiencies- congenital, infiltration by tumours or sarcoidosis, surgical removal
    • Lacrimal gland duct obstruction- old trachoma, burns,  SJS
    • Reflex hyposecretion (neurogenic causes)- Parkinson disease, 7th nerve palsy, reflex sensory block

Clinical features:

Patients often experience a sandy or gritty sensation under the eyelids, stringy discharge, transient blurring of vision, and redness with crusting of the eyelids. A burning sensation, lack of emotional or reflex tearing, and symptom exacerbation with exposure to air-conditioning, heat, prolonged reading, or screen time are also common.

On examination, there may be signs of posterior seborrheic blepharitis, positive Rose Bengal staining, keratinization, conjunctivochalasis, corneal plaques, and tear film abnormalities.

Evaluation includes tests like tear film break-up time, Schirmer's test, Rose Bengal staining, fluorescein clearance timing, tear film osmolarity, phenol red thread test, tear meniscometry, and impression cytology.

Diagnostic evaluation of keratoconjunctivitis sicca includes measurement of tear flow by Schirmer I test and determination of tear composition, with an assessment of tear breakup time or tear lysozyme content. Slit-lamp examination of the cornea and conjunctiva after rose bengal staining reveals punctuate corneal ulcerations and attached filaments of corneal epithelium.

Treatment:

  • Education and lifestyle modification
  • Medical management: Tear substitutes, mucolytic agents, topical steroids, topical cyclosporin, antibiotics, secretagogues like cevimeline
  • Surgical management: Punctal occlusion, eyelid tarsorrhaphy, amniotic membrane transplantation
  • Others: Contact lenses, Antibiotics, moister chamber spectacles and shields.

Related Pearl: Layers of the Tear Film

Lipid layer

  • Outermost layer
  • Secreted by the meibomian, Zeis glands
  • Prevents evaporation of tears

Aqueous layer

  • Middle layer
  • Secreted by the lacrimal and accessory lacrimal glands
  • Provides lubrication

Mucin layer  

  • Innermost layer
  • Secreted by the goblet cells of the conjunctiva
  • Help in spreading the tear film over the ocular surface

The maximum density of the goblet cells is seen on the nasal bulbar conjunctiva.

Related Pearl: Tear film tests used for the diagnosis of dry eye

Schirmer test

Inference 

  • 15 mm: Normal
  • 5-10 mm: Moderate keratoconjunctivitis sicca (KCS)
  • < 5 mm: Severe KCS

Tear film break up test (TBUT)

Inference 

  • 15-35 seconds: Normal
  • < 10 seconds: Unstable tear film

Rose Bengal staining

Inference

  • A pattern: Confluent staining → Severe KCS
  • B pattern: Extensive staining → Moderate KCS
  • C pattern: Fine punctate stains → Mild KCS

Tear osmolarity test

Abnormal osmolarity is defined by 

  • An elevated reading, >300 mOsm/L, indicating loss of homeostasis, or
  • When the inter-eye difference is >8 mOsm/L, indicating instability of the tear film.

questions.text: Which of the following tests is denoted in the image given below?
questions.solution:
The given test is Adson’s test done for evaluation of thoracic outlet syndrome.

Thoracic outlet syndrome is a syndrome occurring due to neurovascular bundle compression in the thoracic outlet. Its causes include: 

  • Cervical rib
  • Anomalous insertion of the scalene muscles
  • Tumors in the neck region
  • Brachial plexus trauma and diseases. 

The image below shows the cervical rib. 

Related Pearl: Thoracic outlet syndrome and its tests:

Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a neurovascular syndrome caused due to the compression of the lower trunk of brachial plexus (C8 and T1) and subclavian vessels in the thoracic outlet between the clavicle, the first rib, and scalene muscles.

Clinical features due to compression of:

  • Brachial plexus: Pain and paraesthesia along the ulnar aspect of the arm.
  • Subclavian vessels: Cyanosis, cold fingers, pallor and Raynaud's phenomenon.

Provocative tests: Adson's test, Halstead's maneuver, Wright's test, Roos test.

Adson’s test: The examiner locates the radial pulse while arm is held in extension, external rotation, and slight abduction. The patient is instructed to take a deep breath and turn head towards the test arm while extending the neck. This manoeuvre will tense the anterior and middle scalenes. If there is outlet obstruction, the radial pulse will get diminished or absent on that side. 

Halstead maneuver (reverse Adson's): The examiner palpates the radial pulse and applies downward traction on the tested extremity while the patient’s neck is hyperextended and rotated to the opposite side. Diminished or absent pulse indicates a positive test.

Wright’s hyperabduction test: The examiner palpates the radial pulse and hyper-abducts the arm. The patient takes a deep breath and may rotate or extend his neck for additional effect. Absence of pulse indicates a positive test.

Roos test: The patient abducts the shoulders to 90 degrees and flexes the elbow to 90 degrees. The patient is made to open and close the hand repeatedly for three minutes. The test is positive if the patient is unable to complete the test or experiences cramping, pain, numbness, on the affected side.

questions.text: All of the following increases during normal pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Clotting factors XI and XIII are slightly decreased during normal pregnancy.

Pregnancy is a hypercoagulable state. Clotting factors X, IX, VIII, VII, and I increase in pregnancy whereas levels of II, V, and XII are either unchanged or mildly increased. Clotting factors XI and XIII are slightly decreased.

During normal pregnancy, blood volume, plasma volume, red cell volume, total hemoglobin, total plasma protein, globulin, ESR, fibrinogen, clotting factors X, IX, VIII, VII, I, II, V, and XII are increased.

Hematocrit, plasma protein concentration, the viscosity of blood, albumin,  albumin:globulin ratio, platelets, fibrinolytic activity, clotting factors XI and XIII are decreased.

questions.text:
The binding groove and effector cells associated with HLA class 1 molecules are:

HLA : Human Leukocyte Antigen

choices.text: Beta I and Alpha I, CD4 T cells
Beta II and Alpha I, CD4 T cells
Alpha I and Alpha II, CD8 T cells
Alpha II and Beta II, CD8 T cells

questions.solution:
The binding groove associated with human leukocyte antigen I (HLA I) is between its alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains, and the effector cells involved are CD8 T cells.

The human major histocompatibility complex (MHC) is called the HLA complex. MHC is a cluster of genes whose products are responsible for antigen presentation to T cells, transplant rejection, etc.

HLA complex of genes is present on the short arm of chromosome 6. It consists of three separate clusters of genes, labeled as class I, II, and III.

HLA class I molecules are present on all nucleated cells. They consist of a heavy peptide chain called the alpha chain that is linked to β-2 microglobulin, which is called the beta chain. The alpha chain further consists of three domains called alpha 1, 2 and 3 that protrude from the cell membrane, as shown in the image below.

There exists a groove between the alpha 1 and alpha 2 domains, where small peptides formed subsequent to protein antigens being processed by macrophages or dendritic cells, bind for presentation to CD8 T cells.

Following this, the CD8 cytotoxic killer cell destroys the target cell. However, the T cell can recognise the antigen only when presented as a complex with the MHC class I molecule and this is called MHC restriction.

HLA class I antigens are involved in graft rejections and cell-mediated cytolysis and are also components of hormone receptors.

HLA class II molecules are present on macrophages, dendritic cells, activated T cells and B cells. They too consist of an alpha and beta chain, each having a proximal and distal domain, as shown in the image below.

The antigen-binding site comprises the two distal domains, which are alpha 1 and beta 1 domains. Antigens are bound for recognition by CD4 T cells. They are principally involved in graft-versus-host-disease and mixed leukocyte reactions.

HLA class III molecules include complement components linked to the formation of C3 convertases, heat shock proteins and tumour necrosis factors.

 

Related Pearl: MHC Classes I and II

MHC Class I

MHC Class II

Expressed on all nucleated cells (except sperms) and platelets

Expressed on antigen-presenting cells: macrophages, B lymphocytes, dendritic cells

Consist of a polymorphic α, heavy-chain, linked non-covalently to β2-microglobulin

Heterodimer consisting of non-covalently associated α and β chains, both of which are polymorphic.

α chains are encoded by three genes- HLA-A, HLA-B, and HLA-C

Encoded by HLA-D, with subregions: HLA-DP, HLA-DQ, and HLA-DR.

Display antigenic peptides that are derived from viral and tumor proteins

Present antigens that are internalized into vesicles, and derived from extracellular microbes 

Class I complexes are recognized by CD8+ T cells

 

Class II complexes are recognized by CD4+ T cells

Endogenous peptide is the type of antigen presented to CD8+ T cells

 Exogenous antigen is the type of antigen presented to CD4+ T cells 

Presents antigen via the cytosolic pathway

 Presents antigen via the endocytic pathway 

Antigen binding site is present between α1/α2 groove

 Antigen binding site is present between α1/β1 groove 

α3 binds to CD8 molecules on cytotoxic T cells

 β2 binds to CD4 on helper T cells

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman comes for routine screening of fetal anomalies at 19 weeks of gestation. Her AFP (alpha-fetoprotein) is elevated. Which of the following is unlikely to be the underlying cause?
questions.solution:
Maternal serum alpha-fetoprotein (MSAFP) is not elevated in spina bifida occulta.

It is elevated in open neural tube defects. Spina bifida occulta is a closed neural tube defect and is not associated with elevated alpha-fetoprotein. 

Defects in the fetal integument- skin, mucous membranes such as meningocele, meningomyelocele, ventral wall defects, anencephaly, etc allow alpha-fetoprotein to leak into the amniotic fluid causing raised maternal serum levels. 

Note - MSAFP concentration is checked in the second trimester, between 15 to 20 weeks gestation.

Related Pearl: Conditions Associated with Abnormal MSAFP

Elevated levels

  • Underestimated gestational age
  • Multifetal gestations
  • Fetal death
  • Neural tube defects
  • Gastroschisis
  • Omphalocele
  • Cystic hygroma
  • Esophageal or intestinal obstruction
  • Liver necrosis
  • Renal anomalies
  • Cloacal exstrophy
  • Osteogenesis imperfecta
  • Congenital skin abnormality
  • Pilonidal cyst
  • Chorioangioma of placenta
  • Placenta intervillous thrombosis
  • Placental abruption
  • Oligohydramnios
  • Preeclampsia
  • Fetal growth restriction
  • Maternal hepatoma or teratoma
 Low levels 
  • Obesity
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Trisomies 21 or 18
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease
  • Overestimated gestational age

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman was found to have a liver tumor during an abdominal CT scan as shown in the image.  The tumor showed up as a hotspot on a Tc 99m radionuclide scan. Which of the following cells are responsible for this finding?
questions.solution:
The given CT image shows a hypervascular lesion in the liver with a central non-enhancing scar which is suggestive of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). FNH appears as a hotspot on Tc 99m sulfur colloid scans due to the presence of Kupffer cells.

FNH is the second most common benign tumor of the liver after hemangioma. It is commonly seen in young women. It is believed to be a hyperplastic response to an anomalous artery. Patients are mostly asymptomatic and FNH is often an incidental finding. If symptoms are noted, vague abdominal pain is the most common symptom.

On histological examination, cords of hepatocytes are seen with atypical biliary epithelium scattered throughout. 

Contrast-enhanced CT is diagnostic for focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH). It appears as a well-circumscribed lesion with a central stellate scar containing a large artery branching out in a spoke-wheel pattern. It shows intense homogeneous enhancement in the arterial phase and it is isodense as compared to the background liver in the venous phase.

The contrast-enhanced CT image of focal nodular hyperplasia (FNH) is shown below.

FNH show sufficient Kupffer cell (hepatic macrophages) activity to accumulate sulfur colloid tracer and appear as hyperintense (hotspot) on Tc 99m sulfur colloid scans.

These tumors do not have the risk of malignant transformation, therefore asymptomatic patients do not require treatment. Careful observation of symptomatic FNH with serial imaging is reasonable, as symptoms may resolve in a significant number of cases. Patients with persistent symptomatic FNH or an enlarging mass should be considered for resection.

If diagnostic uncertainty exists, resection may be necessary for histologic confirmation.

The adult liver consists of numerous cell types, including:

  • Hepatocytes - These are polyhedral cells with a central spherical nucleus, arranged in a single-cell layer. Every hepatocyte has contact with adjacent hepatocytes (with gap junctions for intercellular communication), bile canaliculus, and the space of Disse/perisinusoidal space (hepatocytes project multiple microvilli into this space for active transport of substances.)
  • Kupffer cells (hepatic macrophages) are phagocytic cells lining the sinusoids. 
  • Hepatic stellate cells (Ito cells/perisinusoidal cells) are involved in scar deposition in cirrhosis of the liver and have a role in vitamin A storage.
  • Sinusoidal endothelial cells - flat cells with a central nucleus, these are separated from hepatocytes by the space of Disse (perisinusoidal space). 

The microarchitecture of the liver is shown below.

Related Pearl: Liver tumors - commons

  • Most common tumor overall: Metastatic tumor
  • Most common primary benign tumor: Cavernous hemangioma
  • Most common primary malignant tumor: Hepatocellular carcinoma
  • Most common primary malignant liver tumor of early childhood: Hepatoblastoma
  • Most common tumor associated with arsenic / vinyl chloride: Angiosarcoma
  • Most common tumor associated with oral contraceptive / anabolic steroid: Hepatic adenoma
  • Most common tumor rupture spontaneously causing hemoperitoneum: Hepatic adenoma

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with seizures and headaches. MRI of the brain reveals a mass lesion. Histopathological examination of the mass is shown below. What is the most likely cell of origin of this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given histology shows syncytial or whorled clusters of epithelial cells. These histological features and the MRI showing a brain mass suggest meningioma. They arise from the meningothelial cells or arachnoid cap cells. 

Meningiomas are predominantly benign tumours, usually attached to the dura. They are predominantly seen in females and in patients with neurofibromatosis type 2, which is an autosomal disorder associated with multiple meningiomas, schwannomas, and ependymomas. 

Meningiomas are rubbery, rounded, or bosselated dural masses. They compress the underlying brain tissue. They present with headaches, seizures, or focal neurological deficits.

The tumor spreads sheet-like along the surface of the dura causing reactive hyperostotic changes in adjacent bones. They are mostly located in cerebral convexities. The lesions may be finely gritty due to numerous psammomatous calcifications.

Other options:

Option A: Oligodendrocytes are responsible for myelin formation in the neurons of the central nervous system. They are affected in diseases such as multiple sclerosis, and progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy.

Option B: Schwann cells are responsible for myelin formation in the neurons of the peripheral nervous system. They are affected in Guillain-Barre syndrome.

Option D: Ependymal cells are specialized cells lining the ventricles and spinal canal of the spinal cord. These cells produce cerebrospinal fluid and play a role in the fluid homeostasis of the nervous system.

questions.text: During dissection, the professor points to a structure in the popliteal fossa marked with the red arrow shown in the image below. He further mentions that damage to this structure would cause a high-stepping gait and an inability to dorsiflex the ankle. The structure marked is ______.
questions.solution:
The damaged structure is most likely a common peroneal nerve. It is also called the common fibular nerve. It descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa till the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris.

The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis which are the evertors of the foot and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

The common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (as shown in the image below)
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

 

 

Other options:

Option B: Sural nerve is a terminal branch of the tibial nerve and the common fibular nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation of the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third in the leg. In the foot, there is diminished sensation over the lateral malleolus and the lateral side of the fifth toe.

Option C: Saphenous nerve is the longest and largest cutaneous branch of the femoral nerve. Damage to this nerve results in a diminished sensation in the skin over the patella, medial side of the leg, and medial side of the foot.

Option D: Tibial nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. It is derived from the anterior divisions of L4, L5, S1, S2, and S3. In the popliteal fossa, this nerve is overlapped by two heads of gastrocnemius. Damage to this nerve paralyzes gastrocnemius, plantaris, soleus, and popliteus muscles.

Related Pearl: Sciatic nerve divisions and supply

sural nerve branch

- anastomoses: br. of peroneal nerve
- termination as: lateral dorsal cutaneous nerve

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the enzyme that does not contain the mineral deficient in this condition.
questions.solution:
The clinical features shown in the images are periorificial dermatitis and alopecia. These features along with the given clinical features in a young child are suggestive of acrodermatitis enteropathica, which is seen with zinc deficiency. 

Of the options given, arginase is the enzyme that does not contain zinc. 

Acrodermatitis enteropathica is a condition that occurs due to zinc deficiency and presents after weaning. Clinical features include failure to thrive, anorexia, diarrhea, recurrent infections, alopecia, male hypogonadism, and neurological manifestations like tremors, nystagmus, photophobia, hypogeusia, irritability, and night blindness. Skin manifestations such as vesiculobullous dermatitis on the extremities and perianal, perigenital, and perioral regions are commonly seen, as shown below. Affected infants require long-term supplementation with zinc.

There are almost 3000 zinc-containing metalloproteins, a vast majority of which are transcription factors and other DNA- and RNA-binding proteins. Zinc is an essential component of several metalloenzymes, including carboxypeptidase A, carbonic anhydrase II, adenosine deaminase, alkaline phosphatase, phospholipase C, leucine aminopeptidase, cytosolic form of superoxide dismutase, and alcohol dehydrogenase.

questions.text:
Which among the following enhance gallstone formation?
  1. Cholestyramine therapy
  2. Ileal resection
  3. Vagal stimulation
  4. High caloric diet
  5. Dyslipidemia
questions.solution:
Cholestyramine therapy, ileal resection, high caloric diet, and dyslipidemia are associated with an increased risk of gallstone formation in an individual.

Vagal stimulation causes contraction of the gall bladder and helps in the flow of bile. Whereas denervation of the vagus nerve leads to stasis of bile and leads to stone formation.

Cholesterol is synthesized in the liver. Its solubility is determined by the relative concentration of cholesterol, bile salts and phospholipids. Dyslipidemia causes altered levels of cholesterol, phospholipids, and bile salts in bile reducing the micelle concentration in the bile, leading to precipitation of insoluble cholesterol, hence the stone formation (lithogenic bile). 

Factors affecting gallstone formation: 

  • Bile stasis due to impaired gallbladder 
    • emptying
    • absorption
    • excretion
  • Lithogenic bile due to supersaturation
    • age 
    • sex
    • genetics
    • obesity 
    • diet (high-calorie intake)
  • Cholesterol nucleating factors
    • mucus 
    • glycoprotein
    • infection
  • Impaired enterohepatic circulation of bile
    • deoxycholate
    • cholestyramine
    • bowel transit time
    • faecal enteric flora
    • ileal resection
