questions.text: Which of the following vitamins help in the synthesis of the transporter responsible for the transport of fatty acids across the inner mitochondrial membrane?
questions.solution:
Carnitine is responsible for the transport of fatty acids or long-chain acyl-CoA across the inner mitochondrial membrane and vitamin C is required for the synthesis of carnitine. 

Vitamin C or ascorbic acid is involved in oxidation-reduction reactions. It acts as a coenzyme of the following enzymes.

  • Lysyl and prolyl hydroxylase: in the post-translational modification of procollagen to collagen
  • 7-α-hydroxylase: in the conversion of cholesterol to bile acids
  • Dopamine-β-hydroxylase: in catecholamine synthesis
  • Trimethyl lysine hydroxylase: in carnitine biosynthesis
  • Reduction of ferric to ferrous iron: it enhances the absorption of non-heme iron from the intestine.

Fatty acids are oxidized in the mitochondria to produce acetyl-CoA to produce energy. They must first be converted to acyl-CoA (active fatty acid) before they can be catabolized. 

Carnitine palmitoyltransferase - I (CPT- I) transports acyl-CoA across the inner mitochondrial membrane only in the presence of carnitine. The acyl group of acyl-CoA is transferred to carnitine. The acylcarnitine so formed can penetrate the inner mitochondrial membrane via the carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase. This transporter transfers the acyl group back to CoA, restoring acyl-CoA and liberating carnitine, which is moved back to the intermembrane space. Carnitine palmitoyltransferase -II catalyzes this reaction. The deficiency of this enzyme is a common cause of recurrent myoglobinuria.

Carnitine deficiency can lead to hypoglycemia and restrictive or dilated cardiomyopathy. It can also cause hepatic steatosis.

Related Pearl: Enzymes Involved in Fatty acid Transfer Across Mitochondrial membrane

Enzyme

Site of action

Action

Acyl-CoA synthetase (Thiokinase)

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Converts free fatty acid into Acyl CoA

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-I

Outer mitochondrial membrane

Transfers long-chain acyl group from CoA to carnitine, forming acylcarnitine.

Carnitine-acylcarnitine translocase

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Help Acylcarnitine to penetrate the inner membrane

Carnitine palmitoyl transferase-II

Inner  mitochondrial membrane

Along with carnitine palmitoyl transferase I oxidizes long-chain fatty acids in the mitochondria. 

Related Pearl: Beta-oxidation of Fatty Acids

Note: Carnitine palmitoyltransferase I (CPT1) is also known as carnitine acyltransferase I,

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of MEN 1 syndrome is found to have multiple duodenal ulcers. After a detailed evaluation, he is diagnosed with a neuroendocrine tumor in his duodenum. Which of the following maximally stimulates the hormone secreted by this tumor?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with MEN 1 syndrome and a neuroendocrine tumor is suggestive of a gastrinoma. It secretes the hormone gastrin and in normal individuals, oligopeptide tends to stimulate the secretion.

Oligopeptides and amino acids stimulate gastrin secretion in the stomach, of which tryptophan and phenylalanine are the most effective. Mechanical distension of the stomach, calcium, epinephrine, and vagal stimulation via gastrin-releasing peptide (GRP) or bombesin are other stimulating factors. 

Gastrin is a gastrointestinal hormone released by the G cells of the gastric antrum, duodenum and jejunum. G cells are flask-shaped with microvilli projecting from the apical surface. Gastrin stimulates gastric acid and pepsin secretion. It also promotes the growth of gastric and intestinal mucosa. This function is known as the trophic action of gastrin. Gastrin acts via the receptor CCKB.

Low pH of the stomach inhibits gastrin secretion by a negative feedback mechanism. Other inhibiting factors include somatostatin, secretin, glucose-dependent insulinotropic peptide (GIP), vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP), glucagon, and calcitonin.

Related Pearl: MEN 1 Syndrome Features

Chromosome 11q13 / MEN1 gene

Also known as Wermer’s syndrome

Characteristic tumors seen in:

  • Parathyroid adenoma – 90 % - Most common overall
  • Entero pancreatic tumors - Most common functioning tumor is gastrinoma (most common site is duodenum)
  • Pituitary adenoma – Most common is prolactinoma
  • Mnemonic – Par Pan Pit – in decreasing order of frequency

Associated tumors are:

  • Angiofibroma
  • Collagenomas
  • Adrenal cortical tumors
  • Lipoma
  • Neuroendocrine tumors - gastric, thymic, lungs
  • Meningioma
  • Pheochromocytoma
  • Carcinoid tumors, usually of the foregut

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: The type of joint marked in the below image is also seen in __________.
questions.solution:
The joint marked in the above image is the costotransverse joint, which is a synovial type of joint and it is also seen in costovertebral joint.

The various types of joints in the thoracic wall include:

Type of Joint  Examples 
Synovial joint

Costovertebral joint

Costotranverse joint

Interchondral joints
Primary cartilaginous joint/Synchondrosis Costochondral joint
Secondary cartilaginous/Symphyses joint Manubriosternal and xiphisternal joints

Sternocostal joints: These are the joints between the costal cartilages of the first seven ribs and the sternum.

  • The joint between the 1st costal cartilage and manubrium is a fibrocartilaginous joint (synarthrosis).
  • The joints between the 2nd to 7th costal cartilages and the sternum are synovial joints.

The interchondral joint between the costal cartilages of the 9th and 10th ribs is never synovial and is usually absent.

Related Pearl: Articulations of ribs

 Joints
  • Costovertebral: Rib to the vertebral body  
  • Costotransverse: Rib to the transverse process of vertebra
  • Costochondral: Rib to the costal cartilage

Articulations with the vertebrae

Ribs 2 to 9: 3 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the inferior costal facet of the vertebral body above
  • Head of the rib to the superior costal facet of the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Rib 1: 2 articulations

  • Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body
  • Tubercle of the rib to the transverse process of the corresponding vertebra

Ribs 10, 11 and 12: 1 articulation

  • 10th rib - upper border of the tenth thoracic vertebra near its pedicle
  • 11th, 12th ribs - Head of the rib to the corresponding vertebral body

Articulations with the sternum

Ribs 1- 7: True ribs - Articulate directly with a single costal cartilages 

Ribs 8 - 10: False ribs - Articulate with a common costal cartilage.

Ribs 11 and 12: Floating ribs - Do not articulate with the sternum

questions.text: Safe disposal of radioactive waste is by:
questions.solution:
Radioactive wastes are not covered under biomedical waste management. They are covered under the provisions of the Atomic Energy Act, 1962.

The rules of biomedical waste management do not apply to:

  • Radioactive wastes
  • Municipal solid waste
  • Lead acid batteries
  • E-waste    

Radioactive waste management depends on the hazard duration as some waste remains dangerous for hundreds of thousands of years, while others are hazardous for decades. Low and intermediate-level waste is usually stored near the surface, while high-level waste is ideally disposed of at depths of tens to hundreds of meters in stable geological formations like granite or clay. This deep geological disposal uses multiple barriers to prevent radiation leakage.

Related Pearl: Biomedical waste disposal

 

  Yellow bag (non-chlorinated)  

Type of Waste

  Treatment and Disposal Options

Human anatomical waste

Animal anatomical waste

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial
Soiled Waste: Items like dressings, cotton swabs, and plaster casts contaminated with blood and body fluids and bags containing residual discarded blood.

Incineration/Plasma pyrolysis/Deep Burial

or

Autoclaving/Microwaving/ Hydroclaving

Later - Shredding/mutilation
Discarded linen, mattresses, beddings contaminated with blood or body fluid, routine masks, and gowns

Non- chlorinated chemical disinfection
followed by incineration or Plazma
Pyrolysis or for energy recovery.
In absence of the above facilities, shredding, mutilation, or a combination of sterilization and shredding is used.

Microbiology, biotechnology, clinical laboratory waste

(Autoclave safe plastic bags used)

Blood bags, laboratory
cultures, stocks or specimens of microorganisms,
live or attenuated vaccines, human and animal cell cultures used in research, industrial laboratories, production of biological, residual toxins, dishes, and devices used for cultures.

Pre-treatment with nonchlorinated chemicals

Later - Incineration

Expired/discarded medicine, cytotoxic drugs

 Incineration/plasma pyrolysis/ disposal in a secured landfill
 

Chemical waste

Chemicals used in biological production and used or discarded
disinfectants.

Disposal- incineration/plasma
pyrolysis

Encapsulation- hazardous waste treatment, storage, and disposal facility.

Chemical liquid waste :
Liquid waste generated due to the use of chemicals in the production of
biological and used or discarded disinfectants, silver X-ray film
developing liquid,
discarded formalin,
infected secretions,
aspirated body fluids, liquid from laboratories and floor washings, cleaning, house-keeping and
disinfecting activities etc.

 

 After resource recovery, the chemical
liquid waste shall be pre-treated before mixing with other wastewater. 

 

  Red bag (non-chlorinated)  
 Type of Waste

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Recyclable contaminated waste

Contaminated waste tubing, bottles, intravenous tubes and sets, catheters, urine bags, syringes (without needles and fixed needle syringes with their needles cut), vacutainers with needles cut, and gloves.

Autoclaving/Microwaving/
Hydroclaving

Followed by Shredding/mutilation

And later, Energy recovery/Plastics to diesel or fuel oil/road-making

Not to be sent to landfill

 

  White (translucent)  
(puncture-proof, leak-proof containers)
Type of Waste

Treatment and Disposal Options

Waste Sharps including metals.

Needles, syringes with fixed needles, needles from needle tip cutter or burner, scalpels, blades, or any other contaminated sharp object that may cause puncture and cuts. This includes both used, discarded, and contaminated metal sharps

Autoclaving/ Dry heat sterilization

Followed by - Shredding/mutilation/
encapsulation

Later by - Iron foundries/sanitary landfill/waste sharps

 

   Blue  
(Puncture proof and leak proof containers with blue colored marking)

Type of Waste 

 Treatment and Disposal Options

Glassware

Broken or discarded and contaminated glass including medicine vials and ampules except those containing cytotoxic waste.

Metallic body implants

Sodium hypochlorite/Autoclaving/
Microwaving/Hydroclaving

Later - Recycling

 

 Note: Ash from the incineration of biomedical waste shall be disposed of at a common hazardous waste treatment and disposal facility. However, it may also be disposed of in a municipal landfill, if the toxic metals in incineration ash are within the regulatory quantities as defined under the Hazardous Waste (Management and Handling and Transboundary Movement) Rules, 2008 as amended from time to time.

questions.text: A G2P1 woman was diagnosed with placental accreta. Which of the following findings will be seen on the USG of this patient?
questions.solution:
Ultrasound imaging in a patient with placenta accreta shows large placental lacunae.

Ultrasound findings in placenta accreta:

  • Loss of normal hypoechoic retroplacental zone between uterus and placenta
  • Placental vascular lacunae
  • Placental bulging into the posterior bladder wall

The following image shows the placenta accreta with a large placental lacuna without any myometrial invasion.

 

Morbidly adherent placenta occurs due to the partial or total absence of the decidua basalis and imperfect development of the fibrinoid or Nitabuch layer. If the decidual spongy layer is lacking either partially or totally, then the physiological line of cleavage is absent, and some or all cotyledons are densely anchored.

Microscopically, placental villi attach to smooth muscle fibers rather than to decidual cells. This decidual deficiency then prevents normal placental separation after delivery.

It is of three types:

  • Placenta accreta - villi are attached to the myometrium.
  • Placenta increta - villi invade deep into the myometrium.
  • Placenta percreta - villi penetrate through the entire myometrium and to or through the serosa. 

 

Morbidly adherent placenta can lead to torrential post-partum hemorrhage. It is managed via C-section and peripartum hysterectomy.

Other options:

Option A: Ring of fire appearance is seen on color doppler in ectopic pregnancy.

Option C: Thick myometrium with retroplacental clots is seen in TAS in abruptio placenta.

Option D: Snowstorm appearance is seen in TAS in molar pregnancy.

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

questions.text: Elimination of disease in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts can be referred to as:
questions.solution:
Elimination of a disease refers to zero incidence of a disease.

  • Elimination: Reduction to zero (or a very low defined target rate) of new cases of an infectious disease in a defined geographical area as a result of deliberate efforts; continued measures to prevent re-establishment of transmission are required.
  • Eradication: Complete and permanent worldwide reduction to zero new cases of an infectious disease through deliberate efforts; no further control measures are required.

questions.text: After succumbing to burn injuries following a water heater accident, a patient is brought to the casualty with stable vitals. Fluids were started according to the standard burns protocol. A Foley's catheter drains around 12ml of urine. What is the best suited management?

choices.text: Check kinking of foley's and give iv fluids
Transfer of patient to hyperbaric oxygen chamber facility
IV fluids, Escharotomy and shift to ICU

questions.solution:
This patient has sustained circumferential burns, indicating the need for intensive intravenous fluid rehydration, an escharotomy (longitudinal incisions or skin cuts), and admission to the intensive care unit. Just continuance with fluids and shifting the patient to the ICU will not suffice.

 In cases of circumferential burns, it is imperative to do an escharotomy procedure due to the potential development of oedema or swelling beneath a nonexpanding eschar. Failure to address this condition may result in neurovascular impairment, ischemia, and irreversible damage. Following these first measures, it is recommended that patients be hospitalised for ongoing monitoring and administration of fluids.

It is often recommended to use an aggressive approach in the management of burns due to the potential risks they pose to patients, such as infection and dehydration. The optimal primary measure in the therapy of a patient who presents with a burn injury is the evaluation of the airway, namely to determine the presence of oral burns, and subsequent intubation if deemed necessary. Following this, it will be necessary for patients to have two large bore intravenous (IV) catheters and receive IV fluids, with the objective of adjusting urine output to a rate of 2 millilitres per kilogram per hour. Prophylactic administration of antibiotics is frequently employed, and it is recommended that patients receive the Tdap vaccine.

The fluid resuscitation requirement in a burn patient is calculated using the Parkland formula. It gives the total fluid requirement for the first 24 hours after surviving a burn. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

Parkland formula for an adult with 2nd-degree burns is given by: 2 x weight in kg x % TBSA

Other options 

Option B: Transferring this patient to a hyperbaric oxygen chamber facility need not be done as this patient is stable, and also because of the time spent transporting the patient elsewhere.

Option D: Moist dressings and discharge would be suitable solely in cases where the patient presents with a small, localized, and superficial burn.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: A 72-year-old woman underwent surgery for a cataract. All these complications can be expected shortly in post-op period except:
questions.solution:
Cystoid macular edema is a late complication following cataract surgery.

Cystoid macular edema is the collection of fluid between the outer plexiform layer and the inner nuclear layer of the retina centered around the fovea.

Clinical features include blurring, distortion, and micropsia. A fundus examination shows loss of the foveal depression, thickening of the retina, and multiple cysts. Optic disc swelling is sometimes present.

Fluorescein angiography shows a petaloid pattern due to dye accumulation in microcystic spaces in the outer plexiform layer. OCT shows retinal thickening with cystic hyporeflective spaces and loss of the foveal depression.

The image given below shows a petaloid pattern on fluorescein angiography seen in cystoid macular edema.

Other options:

Option A : Hyphaema (bleeding in the anterior chamber) can occur shortly after surgery due to trauma to blood vessels during the procedure.

Option B: Corneal edema can occur immediately postoperatively, particularly if the surgery involves significant manipulation of the cornea or if the endothelial cells are damaged.

Option D: Toxic anterior segment syndrome (TASS) is an acute, sterile inflammation of the anterior segment, often seen within 12 to 48 hours after cataract surgery. It can result from toxic substances used during the procedure or improper sterilization.

Related Pearl: Complications of cataract surgery

Early postoperative complications

Occurs within the first few days to 4 weeks.

  • Endophthalmitis
  • Retained lens matter
  • Corneal edema
  • Wound leak and dehiscence
  • Toxic anterior segment syndrome

Late postoperative complications

Occurs within months to years.

  • Posterior capsule opacification (most common)
  • Cystoid macular edema
  • Secondary glaucoma
  • Retinal detachment
  • Intraocular lens malpositions:
    • Windshield wiper syndrome— intraocular lens haptic rubs on the endothelium
    • Sunset syndrome—inferior subluxation
    • Sunrise syndrome—superior subluxation
    • Complete dislocation of the intraocular lens.

questions.text: A diabetic patient comes to you requesting a suitable carbohydrate diet that he must consume. Which of the following forms of carbohydrates may be advocated for this patient?
questions.solution:
Carbohydrate sources rich in polysaccharides are recommended for patients with diabetes as they have been found to increase beta cell mass and help alleviate pancreatic beta cell dysfunction. It has also been found to enhance the signalling pathways of insulin and reduce oxidative stress. Polysaccharide-rich sources include foods rich in fruits, grains,  vegetables and mushrooms. 

Dietary factors that are protective for diabetes mellitus are:

  • Higher intake of unsaturated fatty acids
  • A minimum daily intake of 20g of dietary fibre

Monosaccharides such as fructose and disaccharides such as sucrose are known to be deleterious if consumed by diabetics.

questions.text: A mother brings her infant to the pediatrician, worried about the noticeably small mandible of the child. Investigations reveal hypoplasia of the mandible and malformation of the ​middle ear. These features can be attributed to a developmental defect involving which of the following pharyngeal arches?
questions.solution:
The above-mentioned features are suggestive of the first arch syndrome, which can be attributed to a developmental defect involving the first pharyngeal arch. 

The first pharyngeal arch is known as the mandibular arch. The artery associated with the first arch is the maxillary artery and the nerve supply is provided by the maxillary and mandibular branches of the trigeminal nerve.

The derivatives of the first pharyngeal arch are:

i. Skeletal derivatives: It has 2 prominences,

  • Mandibular prominence (ventral)- The mandibular prominence has two components:
    • Meckel's cartilage- It forms the malleus, incus, spine of the sphenoid, and the sphenomandibular and anterior malleolar ligaments.
    • Mesenchyme surrounding the Meckel's cartilage undergoes membranous ossification to form the mandible.
  • Maxillary prominence (dorsal). The mesenchyme of this process forms the maxilla, zygomatic bone, and part of the temporal bone.

ii. Muscular derivatives include:

  • tensor tympani
  • tensor veli palatini
  • muscles of mastication
  • anterior belly of digastric
  • mylohyoid

Pharyngeal pouch derivatives include the auditory tube and middle ear cavity.

Related Pearl: Derivatives of Branchial Apparatus

Arch Nerve Skeletal derivatives Pouch Derivatives Muscle Derivatives Artery 

1st (mandibular arch)

 Trigeminal (V) - Maxillary and mandibular divisions
  • Incus
  • Malleus
  • Anterior ligament of malleus
  • Spine of sphenoid
  • Sphenomandibular ligament 
  • Auditory tube
  • Middle ear cavity 
  • Tensor tympani
  • Muscles of mastication 
  • Mylohyoid
  • Anterior belly of digastric
  • Tensor veli palatini
  • Maxillary artery

2nd (hyoid arch)

 Facial (VII)
  • Stapes
  • Styloid process (temporal)
  • Lesser cornu and upper hyoid
  • Stylohyoid ligament
  • Palatine tonsil
  • Tonsillar fossa 
  • Stapedius
  • Stylohyoid 
  • Facial Muscles (Buccinator, Platysma, Posterior belly of digastric)
  • Stapedial artery
  • Hyoid artery
3rd Glossopharyngeal (IX)
  • Greater cornu of hyoid
  • Lower part of hyoid body
  • Inferior parathyroids
  • Thymus 
  • Stylopharyngeus
  • Common carotid
  • Proximal internal carotid arteries 
4th Superior laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Thyroid cartilage
  • Corniculate cartilage
  • Cuneiform cartilage 
  • Superior parathyroids,
  • Parafollicular C cells of Thyroid (from ultimobranchial body)
 
  • Pharyngeal muscles
  • Larynx -Cricothyroid
  • Levator veli palatini
  • Right side: Right subclavian artery (proximal portion)
  • Left side: Arch of the aorta from the left common carotid to the left subclavian arteries
6th Recurrent laryngeal of Vagus (X)
  • Arytenoid cartilages
 		  
  • All intrinsic muscles of the larynx (except the cricothyroid muscle)
  • Right side: right pulmonary artery 
  • Left side: left pulmonary artery and ductus arteriosus

questions.text: A 70-year-old diabetic female complains of frequent urination, but no pain or burning micturition. She has an urgency to pass the urine but passes urine before reaching the lavatory. Which phase of the cystometrogram is likely to be altered in this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario given above is suggestive of urge incontinence or overactive bladder and Phase Ib, marked as 2 in the image, is shortened in this condition.

An overactive bladder is characterised by an uncontrolled contraction of the detrusor muscle in the bladder wall, causing an uncontrollable urge to urinate. This can happen anytime throughout phase 1b (2 in the diagram) of the cystometrogram, resulting in a shorter phase. 

A cystometrogram is a plot of intravesical pressure against the volume of fluid in the bladder. The curve shows three segments:

  • Ia- initial slight rise in pressure when the first increments in the volume are produced
  • Ib- long, nearly flat segment as further increments are produced
  • II- a sudden, sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered (not failure).
  • The dotted line- pressure-volume relation if the micturition had not occurred.

The flatness of segment Ib is a demonstration of the law of Laplace. The law of Laplace states that the pressure (P) in a spherical viscus is equal to twice the wall tension (T) divided by the radius (R). This is expressed as P= 2T/R. In the blad­der, the tension increases as the bladder gets filled. Since the radius also increases, there is only a slight increase in pressure until the bladder is relatively full.

questions.text: In a patient of colorectal carcinoma, the tumor encroaches the descending colon for which a surgical resection was done. Which of the following arteries is ligated during the procedure?
questions.solution:
Left colic artery is ligated for the tumor encroaching the descending colon.

Descending colon/ splenic flexure carcinoma is treated with left hemi-colectomy. The vessels to be ligated are left branch of the middle colic , the left colic, and the first branches of the sigmoid vessels 

Procedures performed for tumors of the colon are summarized below:

Tumor location Procedure of choice
Cecum/ Ascending colon 

Right hemicolectomy 

  • Ligation and division of the ileocolic, right colic, and right branch of the middle colic vessels 
  • Resection of cecum + approx 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction + ascending colon + hepatic flexure 
Hepatic flexure/Transverse colon

Extended right hemicolectomy

  • Ligation and division of the ileocolic, right colic, and trunk of middle colic vessels 
  • Resection of the cecum + approx 10 cm of the terminal ileum with ileocecal junction + ascending colon + hepatic flexure + proximal transverse colon (distal transverse colon and splenic flexure are also sometimes removed)
Splenic flexure/ Descending colon

Left hemicolectomy 

  • Ligation and division of the left branch of the middle colic vessels, the left colic vessel, and the first branches of the sigmoid vessels 
  • Resection of the transverse colon (left MCA territory) + Splenic flexure + Descending colon up to the sigmoid colon
Sigmoid colon Sigmoid colectomy, or LAR (Low anterior resection)
  • Ligation and division of the sigmoid branches of the inferior mesenteric artery.
  • Removal of the entire sigmoid colon and rectum

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with chronic fatigue, growth retardation, and epistaxis. On further evaluation, hepatosplenomegaly, thrombocytopenia, and anemia were found. X-ray of the femur showed Erlenmeyer flask deformity. Which of the following substances would accumulate in this patient?
questions.solution:
The case described above is Gaucher’s disease and it shows accumulation of glucosylceramide and glycosphingosine. 

Gaucher's disease is an inborn error of metabolism caused due to a deficiency of beta-glucocerebrosidase which causes the accumulation of glucosylceramide and glycosphingosine. It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder and the mode of inheritance is autosomal recessive. There is an accumulation of lipid-laden macrophages in the spleen, liver, and other tissues. 

 In this scenario, where beta-glucocerebrosidase is deficient, glucosylceramide is transformed by another enzyme ceramidase into glycosphingosine. 

Lysosomal lipid storage disorders:

Sphingolipidoses Enzyme deficiency Sphingolipid accumulated
Farber disease   Ceramidase Ceramide
Fabry disease   Alpha galactosidase Globotriosyl ceramide
GM1 gangliosidosis   Beta galactosidase GM1 ganglioside
                                            GM2 gangliosidosis
Tay Sach’s Disease   Beta Hexosaminidase A GM2 ganglioside
Sandhoff Disease   Beta Hexosaminidase A and B GM2 ganglioside
Gaucher Disease   Beta Glucosidase / Glucocerebrosidase Glucosyl ceramide  
Niemann Pick Disease   Sphingomyelinase Sphingomyelin
Metachromatic Leukodystrophy   Aryl sulfatase A Sulfogalactosyl ceramide
Krabbe Disease     Beta Galactosidase / Beta Galactocerebrosidase

Galactosyl ceramide

 

Gaucher's cells are formed as a result of the accumulation of massive amounts of glucocerebrosides within the phagocytes. The cells have a fibrillary cytoplasm and give a crumpled tissue paper appearance.

Erlenmeyer flask deformity also known as metaphyseal flaring is a radiographic appearance typically on a femoral radiograph demonstrating relative constriction of the diaphysis and flaring of the metaphysis.

There are three clinical subtypes - type I (chronic non-neuronopathic), type II (acute neuronopathic), and type III (intermediate). Clinical features include anemia, thrombocytopenia, hepatosplenomegaly, and neurological features depending on the subtype. 

Regular intravenous enzyme therapy is the first-line treatment for significantly affected patients. It is highly efficacious and safe in diminishing hepatosplenomegaly and improving hematologic values.

Eliglustat tartrate is a specific inhibitor of glucosylceramide synthase. Miglustat is a second-line drug provided orally.

Related Pearl: Examples of Sphingolipidoses (Lipids-Storage Disease)

S. No.

Disease

Enzyme Deficiency

Lipid

Accumulating

Clinical Symptoms

1

Tay–Sachs disease

Hexosaminidase A

Ganglioside

Mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness

2

Sandhoff's disease

Hexosaminidase A and B

Globoside & Ganglioside

Similar to Tay–Sachs disease but also has hepatosplenomegaly and skeletal dysplasias

3

Fabry's disease

α-Galactosidase

Globotriaosyl-ceramide

Skin rash, kidney failure (full symptoms only in males; X-linked recessive)

4

Metachromatic leukodystrophy

Arylsulfatase A

3-Sulfogalactosyl-ceramide

Mental retardation and psychologic disturbances in adults; demyelination

5

Krabbe disease

β-Galactosidase

Galactosylceramide

Mental retardation; myelin almost absent

6

Gaucher's disease

β-Glucosidase

Glucosylceramide

Enlarged liver and spleen, erosion of long bones, mental retardation in infants

7

Niemann–Pick disease

Sphingomyelinase

Sphingomyelin

Enlarged liver and spleen, mental retardation; fatal in early life

8

Farber's disease

Ceramidase

Ceramide

Hoarseness, dermatitis, skeletal deformation, mental retardation; fatal in early life

questions.text: A 26-year-old female, G2P1L1, undergoes an emergency C-section for prolonged labour. During the immediate postpartum period, she develops acute onset respiratory distress, cyanosis, and sudden hypotension. Her sensorium worsens in minutes requiring intubation. Which of the following mechanisms best explains her sudden deterioration?
questions.solution:
In the setting of an emergency C-section and sudden postpartum deterioration with acute respiratory distress, cyanosis, hypotension, and worsening sensorium, a diagnosis of amniotic fluid embolism (AFE) is highly suspected. AFE can lead to acute hypoxemia due to impaired oxygen exchange in the lungs. Therefore, mechanism of sudden deterioration in this case is type I respiratory failure.

AFE is a rare but catastrophic obstetric emergency. It manifests with sudden onset respiratory failure, cardiovascular collapse, and coagulopathy. In this case, amniotic fluid that has embolised to the pulmonary vasculature prevents diffusion of gases and results in a hypoxemic (PaO2 <60 mmHg) respiratory failure, which is classified as Type I respiratory failure.

Other options:

Type II respiratory failure (hypercapnic respiratory failure) involves elevated PaCO2, which is less typical in acute conditions like AFE. Though it can develop if the respiratory distress continues, leading to ventilatory failure. 

Type III is associated with post-operative atelectasis

Type IV relates to shock and inadequate perfusion due to circulatory failure, often seen in critically ill patients.

Related Pearl: Types of Respiratory Failure

Results from the inability to eliminate carbon dioxide effectively.

questions.text: A patient with allergic rhinitis was prescribed cetirizine which is a drug acting on the H1 receptor. What is the mechanism of action of this drug in relation to its receptor?
questions.solution:
Cetirizine is a second-generation H1 receptor antagonist. All H1 receptor antagonists act by inverse agonism at the H1 receptor site.

They act by constitutively reducing the activity of the receptor and compete with histamine binding to the receptor.

H1 antagonists are divided into first-generation and second-generation drugs. First-generation antihistamines have a strong sedative property and also block autonomic receptors. They include drugs like diphenhydramine, promethazine, chlorpheniramine, cyproheptadine, and cinnarizine.

questions.text: A 55-year-old man with ischemic heart disease and atrial fibrillation presents with sudden, severe, generalized abdominal pain and multiple episodes of vomiting. On examination, the pulse rate is 118 bpm, rhythm is irregularly irregular, and BP is 92/58 mm Hg. The abdomen appears soft, and non-distended, and bowel sounds are absent. Which of the following is the gold standard investigation for the diagnosis in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute mesenteric ischemia. For an acute arterial occlusive disease, the gold standard for diagnosis is angiography and that for management is laparotomy.

An embolus is the most common cause of acute mesenteric ischemia. Risk factors for acute mesenteric ischemia/embolus in the given clinical scenario are as follows:

  • Presence of an irregularly irregular pulse is suggestive of atrial fibrillation. 
  • Previous history of ischemic heart disease

The most important clue to an early diagnosis of acute mesenteric ischemia is the sudden onset of severe abdominal pain in a patient with atrial fibrillation or atherosclerosis. The pain is typically in the central abdomen and out of proportion to the physical findings. Associated symptoms can include nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. With the onset of bowel infarction, abdominal distension, peritonitis, and passage of bloody stools occur.

The gold standard for the diagnosis of an acute arterial occlusive disease is angiography and that for management is laparotomy. The goal of operative exploration is to resect the compromised bowel and restore blood supply via embolectomy.

Note:

A pulsatile abdominal mass is seen in the case of an abdominal aortic aneurysm. Acute pain and hypotension occur with rupture of the aneurysm, which requires an emergency operation.

Acute severe pancreatitis and peptic ulcer perforation have no association with atrial fibrillation. They usually present with pain over the upper abdomen, associated with guarding and rigidity on examination.

questions.text:
A woman presents with back pain, suprapubic discomfort, and a burning sensation on urination for the past three days. The urine analysis of the patient is given below. What is the most likely agent responsible for this patient’s symptoms?

Bacteria: 120000 CFUs

WBCs: 30-50 per HPF

Urine leukocyte esterase: Positive

Nitrite test: Positive

Indole: Positive
questions.solution:
The given symptoms and the laboratory tests showing a bacteria count of 120000 CFU, positive leukocyte esterase and nitrate-reducing, indole-positive organism suggest a diagnosis of urinary tract infection (UTI) due to E. coli.

E. coli is a gram-negative, flagellated rod. It is the most frequent cause of acute complicated urinary tract infections. It is a lactose fermenter and, hence, grows on MacConkey medium to produce pink colonies. Other biochemical features of E.coli are-

Biochemical reactions Result
Indole Positive
MR (Methyl Red) Positive
VP (Voges Proskauer) Negative
Citrate  Negative
Nitrate reduction Positive
Urease  Negative
H2S Negative
Gelatin hydrolysis  Negative

Therefore, E. coli is IMViC ++−−

Bacterial growth of >105 CFU/ml of urine is considered significant bacteriuria, along with a positive urine leukocyte esterase suggesting the presence of WBCs, indicates a UTI

The image below shows a positive Indole test.

Other options:

Proteus mirabilis, Klebsiella and enterobacter can cause UTI but are indole negative.

questions.text: During a hearing assessment of a patient, he is able to tell the direction from which the sound is heard. Which of the following is responsible for the detection of the direction of sound?
questions.solution:
The lateral superior olivary nucleus is responsible for the detection of the direction of the sound. It is the starting point for the localisation of sound.

The mechanism by which it detects the direction of the sound is by comparison of the difference in intensities of the sound reaching the two ears and sending the signals to the auditory cortex that can detect the direction.

Other options:

Option B: Lateral geniculate body is seen in the visual pathway. It has two principal functions:

  • It relays visual information from the optic tract to the visual cortex by way of optic radiation
  • To gate the transmission of signals to the visual cortex. It controls how much of the signal is allowed to pass to the cortex.

Option C: The nerve fibres stimulated by the hair cells lead to the spiral ganglion of Corti, which lies in the centre of the cochlea. The spiral ganglion neuronal cells send axons into the cochlear nerve. 

Option D: Nerve fibres from the spiral ganglion of Corti enter the dorsal and ventral cochlear nuclei located in the upper part of the medulla. At this point, all the fibres synapse, and second-order neurons pass mainly to the opposite side of the brain stem to terminate in the superior olivary nucleus.

Related Pearl: Central Auditory Pathway

E.Coli - MA (mnemonic)

Eighth nerve 

Cochlear nuclei 

Olivary complex 

Lateral lemniscus 

Inferior colliculus 

Medial geniculate body 

Auditory cortex

Most of the primary auditory cortex is in the temporal lobe, but the association cortices extend over much of the insular lobe and even onto the lateral portion of the parietal lobe.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old woman came to the general medicine OPD for evaluation of her complete blood picture during a routine checkup. The findings are shown below. She was taking iron tablets twice daily for the past 2 years after her last childbirth. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?

RBC count - 6.1 x 106/μL
WBC count - 4,620/mm3
Hematocrit - 35%, Hb- 9g/dl
Mean cell volume - 64 fL
Platelets - 256,000/mm3
Iron - 150 μg/dL (Normal- 60- 160 μg/dL)
Total iron-binding capacity - 275 μg/dL (Normal- 255- 450 µg/dl)

choices.text: Stop oral iron sulfate and prescribe iron dextran
Continue the present oral  iron therapy and test for ferritin
Stop iron therapy, and test for ferritin and haemoglobin electrophoresis.

questions.solution:
The next step in the management of the patient with the given laboratory findings suggesting microcytic hypochromic anaemia will be discontinuation of oral iron therapy and checking for ferritin and haemoglobin electrophoresis.

The laboratory values suggestive of microcytic anaemia, despite 2 years of oral iron therapy and the iron studies showing an increase in serum iron makes it unlikely to be an iron deficiency anaemia, hence, oral iron therapy should be stopped to prevent further iron overload. Assessment of ferritin level helps us to evaluate if she is iron-replete or iron-over-loaded.

The Mentzer index, calculated as the ratio of mean corpuscular volume (MCV) to red blood cell (RBC) count, is a valuable tool for differentiating between iron-deficiency anemia (IDA) and β-thalassemia trait. In this case, the patient presents with a low MCV and low mean corpuscular hemoglobin (MCH), which are characteristic of both IDA and thalassemia. However, the RBC count is elevated at 6.1 x 10⁶/μL, which is more indicative of thalassemia, as RBC counts are typically reduced in IDA. 

Mentzer Index=MCV ​⁄ RBC count

Substituting the values into the formula:

(MCV = 64 fL
RBC count = 6.1 x 10⁶/μL)
Mentzer Index​≈10.49.

Since the Mentzer index is less than 13, this further supports the likelihood of β-thalassemia trait rather than iron-deficiency anemia. Given these findings, the most appropriate management step is to discontinue oral iron therapy, assess ferritin levels, and perform hemoglobin electrophoresis to confirm the diagnosis of the β-thalassemia minor.

Related Pearl: Differential Diagnosis of Microcytic Anaemia

Investigation Iron- Deficiency Anemia Alpha or beta thalassemia Anemia of Chronic Disease
Serum Iron <60 µg/dL Normal/Increased Decreased
Serum Ferritin <20 µg/L Normal/Increased Increased
TIBC Increased Normal Decreased
Transferrin saturation <15% Normal Normal/Decreased
MCV Decreased  Decreased Normal/Decreased
RBC count Decreased Normal/Increased Normal/Increased

TIBC: Total iron-binding capacity

questions.text: A 2-year-old boy is brought to the pediatrician with an abdominal mass, hypertension, and bruising around the eyes.  A biopsy image of the adrenal gland tumor picked up on an abdominal CT scan is shown below. Amplification of which of the following oncogenes is associated with this tumor?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the biopsy are diagnostic of neuroblastoma, in which amplification of the N-MYC gene is seen. 

Neuroblastoma is a tumor arising from the neural crest cells. It is the most common intraabdominal tumor in children. It is associated with the amplification of the N-MYC protooncogene and tumor cell DNA content. These genetic characteristics have prognostic importance. The most common site of occurrence is the adrenal gland. 

Most cases are diagnosed before the age of five. Clinical features of the disease, vary depending on the site of the location of the tumor. It can present as an abdominal mass, periorbital ecchymoses, hypertension, and Horner syndrome. It is also associated with central hypoventilation syndrome, Hirschsprung disease, and neurofibromatosis type 1. 

CT scan will show the presence of tumor calcifications. A biopsy reveals the presence of small round blue cells with Homer-Wright pseudorosettes. 

 

Other examples of small, round blue cell tumours include: 

  • Medulloblastoma
  • Neuroblastoma
  • Retinoblastoma
  • Ewing’s sarcoma
  • Rhabdomyosarcoma

The treatment modality is chosen based on the patient age and tumor stage. Cytogenetic and molecular features are used to determine the treatment risk group and prognosis for each case. 

Other options:

Option B: C-MYC translocation is associated with Burkitt lymphoma.

Option C: H-RAS point mutations can cause bladder and kidney tumors.

Option D: Point mutations in K-RAS oncogene can result in colon, lung, and pancreatic tumors.

questions.text: A sample of peripheral blood showed the presence of an organism as given in the image below. Identify the primary vector responsible for the transmission of the infective form of this organism.
questions.solution:
The peripheral blood, showing the presence of sheathed microfilaria with a pointed tail free of nuclei, is suggestive of Wuchereria bancrofti. The primary vector responsible for the transmission of the infective stage is the Culex mosquito.

The infective form of Wuchereria bancrofti to humans is the third-stage filariform larva and is transmitted by the bite of mosquitoes, which also act as the intermediate hosts. The Culex mosquito is the primary vector, with Culex quinquefasciatus being the major vector in India and most of Asia. Aedes and Anopheles have also been implicated in various regions of the world.

Wuchereria bancrofti is a filarial nematode that causes lymphatic filariasis. The adult worms reside in the lymphatics, and mechanical obstruction by the adult worms or allergic inflammatory reaction to worm antigens is responsible for the clinical manifestations of lymphatic filariasis. 

The microfilaria are present in the blood and demonstrate nocturnal periodicity, appearing only during nighttime and migrating to vessels of the lung or kidneys during the daytime. Hence, a sample of peripheral blood for identification of the microfilariae is collected during the nighttime, between 10 pm and 4 am.

The image below shows the life cycle of Wuchereria bancrofti.

The image below shows the difference between microfilaria of various filarial nematodes.

Other options:

Option A: Chyrsops (Deerfly) is a vector transmitting the Loa loa worm, which causes Loasis, characterised by ‘Calabar’ or ‘fugitive’ swellings. The microfilaria of Loa Loa shows diurnal periodicity and is sheathed but has a column of nuclei extending up to its tail tip.  

Option C: Triatominae(kissing bugs) are vectors for Chagas disease, or American Trypanosomiasis, caused by the parasite Trypanosoma cruzi. Transmission occurs by rubbing the reduviid bug's faeces into bite wounds or the eye, blood transfusion, and transplacental spread.

Option D: Simulium (Blackfly) has been identified as the vector in filarial nematodes like Onchocerca volvulus and, in some cases, Mansonella Azzopardi. In the case of these nematodes, the microfilariae are unsheathed and show a non-periodic appearance in the peripheral blood.

Related Pearl: Filarial worms and their morphology

questions.text: Which of the following contrast agent can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis?
questions.solution:
The contrast agent that can cause nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is gadolinium.

Nephrogenic systemic fibrosis is a systemic condition that primarily affects the skin of patients with renal impairment. Increased numbers of fibrocytes result in skin thickening and plaque formation which evolves to cause flexion contractures, paraesthesia, and pruritus. As a result, gadolinium-containing contrast is contraindicated in patients with GFR under 30 ml/min

Recent research has also demonstrated radiologically and pathologically detected gadolinium deposition in brain tissue including the dentate nuclei, pons, globus pallidus, and thalamus in patients who have undergone multiple MRI scans using gadolinium-based contrast agents (GBCAs). The clinical significance of this deposition is as yet unknown. Gadolinium is the contrast agent used for MRI. It acts by reducing both the T1/T2 relaxation time of the tissue. The predominant effect is on T1, so post-contrast is a T1-weighted image. Since gadolinium ion is toxic Gd-DTPA is used.

Other options

Ditrazoate(option A), Ioxaglate(option C), and Iohexol(optiond D) are iodinated contrast agents. Ditrazoate is a high-osmolality contrast agent, Ioxaglate is an iso-osmolality contrast agent and Iohexol is a low-osmolality contrast agent.

They increase the risk of Contrast-induced nephropathy(CIN). Acute Kidney Injury Network (AKIN) criteria for AKI be applied for the diagnosis of CIN. AKI is diagnosed if any one of the following criteria is met:

  • Absolute serum creatinine increase >0.3 mg/dL in 48 hours
  • >50% increase in serum creatinine in 7 days
  • Urine output decreased to <0.5 mL/kg/h for at least 6 hours.

Hence alternative imaging methods, without iodinated contrast media, should be chosen in patients with considerably impaired renal function (CKD 4 or 5). In patients with moderate renal impairment (CKD 3) volume expansion with 0.9% saline at 100 mL/h beginning 6 to 2 hours before CT and continuing for 4 to 12 hours after should be done.

Related Pearl: Classification of iodinated contrast medias:

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient was diagnosed with constipation and was started on senna laxatives. After 5 months, the patient came to the hospital with complaints of nausea, vomiting, and abdominal cramping. The colonoscopy of the patient is shown. The diagnosis of this patient is ____________
questions.solution:
The above colonoscopy image depicts a black pigmentation of colonic mucosa that is indicative of melanosis coli. Chronic use of anthraquinone laxatives like senna and cascara sagrada can cause melanosis coil.

As the laxative travels down the intestinal tract, it remains in its inactive form until it reaches the large intestine. Once in the large intestine, the molecules transform into their active form. These active forms of laxative lead to cell damage in the lining of the intestine and death by apoptosis and create a dark pigment, lipofuscin, which eventually lines the large bowel. Eventually, these dead cells are taken up by macrophages. Melanosis coli can occur within only a few months of chronic laxative use. 

Classification of Laxatives

  • Bulk-forming 
    • Dietary fiber: Bran, psyllium/ispaghula, methylcellulose, calcium polycarbophil
  • Stool softener: Docusates (DOSS), Liquid paraffin
  • Stimulant purgatives
    • Diphenylmethanes: bisacodyl, sodium picosulphate
    • Anthraquinones: senna, cascara sagrada
    • 5-HT4 agonist: prucalopride
    • Fixed oil: castor oil
    • Prostaglandin analogue- lubiprostone
  • Osmotic purgatives
    • Magnesium salts: sulfate, hydroxide
    • Sodium salts: sulfate, phosphate
    • Sodium potassium tartrate
    • Lactulose

The main indication of laxatives is the prevention and treatment of acute and chronic constipation.

Docusates are associated with side effects like cramps, abdominal pain, and hepatotoxicity on prolonged usage. Liquid paraffin may be associated with foreign body granulomas, lipid pneumonia, and vitamin deficiencies. Bisacodyl may cause allergic reactions.

questions.text:
A 25-year-old male with sputum-negative but radiologically diagnosed tuberculosis undergoes CBNAAT testing, which reveals resistance to both rifampicin and isoniazid. Subsequent LPA and liquid culture DST show sensitivity to all drugs in shorter MDR regimens. He was started on a shorter bedaquiline-containing MDR regimen, two weeks following which his ECG showed the following finding. Which of the initiated medications is least likely to cause this abnormality?

LPA- Line Probe Assay

DST- Drug sensitivity testing

MDR- Multi-drug resistant
questions.solution:
The ECG in the given image of the patient on bedaquiline containing MDR regimen shows QTc prolongation. Although clarithromycin causes QT prolongation, it is not a part of the shorter MDR regimen and is hence the answer. 

A shorter MDR regimen consists of the following:

Intensive phase (4-6 months) Continuation phase (5 months)

Clofazimine

Isoniazid (high dose)

Levofloxacin

Bedaquiline (6 months)

Pyrazinamide

Ethambutol

Ethionamide

Clofazimine

Levofloxacin

Pyrazinamide

Ethambutol

Drugs from the short MDR, such as bedaquiline, clofazimine, and levofloxacin, cause QT interval prolongation, and hence the patients should be closely monitored. A baseline ECG should be taken before commencing the treatment and repeated during the treatment.

Clarithromycin is recommended as a first-line therapy for mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), along with ethambutol and rifamycin.

Related Pearl: ATT Regimen for TB Patients

As per the latest recommendations from National Tuberculosis Elimination Programme (NTEP), treatment of TB is now based primarily on drug susceptibility testing. This is irrespective of new cases, previously treated cases or recurrent TB cases. 
All cases of TB are treated with Drug Sensitive TB Regimen, as long as the patient is sensitive to isoniazid and rifampicin. (No classification into category I or II)

Type of TB Case Intensive Phase Continuation Phase
New and previously treated cases (H and R sensitive) 2 months H R Z E 4 months H R E

Classification based on drug resistance. 

The cases are classified as:

  • Mono-resistant (MR): A TB patient, who is resistant to one 1st line anti-TB drug only.
  • Poly-Drug Resistant (PDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to more than one 1st line anti-TB drug, other than Rifampicin and isoniazid. 
  • Rifampicin Resistant (RR): A TB patient, who is resistant to rifampicin with or without resistance to other drugs. Patients, who have rifampicin resistance, should be managed as if they are an MDR TB case.
  • Multi-Drug Resistant (MDR): A TB patient, who is resistant to both isoniazid and rifampicin.
  • Extensively Drug-Resistant (XDR): A MDR TB patient who is additionally resistant to a fluoroquinolone (ofloxacin, levofloxacin, or moxifloxacin) and at least one additional group A drug (as of 2021, these are bedaquiline and linezolid)

Standard DR TB regimen

Regimen class Drugs Comments
H mono-resistant/ poly-drug resistant TB regimen Lfx R E Z for 6 months

6 months long

Oral drugs only
BPaLM regime (New MDR regime by WHO) Bdq Pa Lzd Mfx for 6 months

6 months long
9- 11 months shorter oral bedaquiline regime (Shorter MDR)

Intensive Phase:

Lfx Bdq(6 months) Cfz Z Hh E Eto for 4-6 months

Continuation phase:

Lfx Cfz Z E for 5 months

9-11 months long totally

Injectables used in Intensive phase.
Longer MDR TB regimen Bdq(6 months or longer) Lfx Lzd Cfz Cs 

18-20 months long

Oral drugs only

This regimen is used for XDR TB patients for 20 months.

 

Criteria for patients to receive standard Drug Resistant TB regimen:

Standard Drug Resistant TB regimen Inclusion criteria Exclusion criteria
H mono-resistant/poly-drug resistant TB regimen Isoniazid resistant TB with rifampicin sensitive No specific criteria
BPaLM regimen (New MDR TB regimen by WHO)
  1. MDR/RR-TB or pre-XDR-TB ( MDR/RR-TB and resistance to fluoroquinolones). 
  2. Those with confirmed pulmonary TB and all forms of extrapulmonary TB (except for TB involving CNS, osteoarticular, and miliary TB).
  3. Patients >14 years of age.
 Pregnant and lactating women
9- 11 months shorter MDR TB regimen Patient with rifampicin resistant pulmonary or extra pulmonary TB Non drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • Pregnancy
  • Any extra pulmonary disease in PLHIV
  • Disseminated meningeal or central nervous system TB
  • Intolerance to any drug in the shorter MDR TB regimen
Drug sensitivity test based criteria:
  • If DST/DRT result for FQ or SLI is resistant (XDR TB)
  • Presence of InhA mutation
  • Resistant to Z 
Longer MDR TB regimen Patients in whom shorter MDR TB regimen cannot be considered due to any reason None

Legend

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical finding of the syphilitic interstitial keratitis?
questions.solution:
Mooren ulcer is not a clinical finding of the syphilitic interstitial keratitis.

Clinical signs of the syphilitic interstitial keratitis:

  • Initial progressive stage: Ground-glass appearance. This is due to the presence of hazy patches in the deeper layers of the cornea.
  • Florid stage: 'Salmon patch' appearance. It is due to the deep vascularization of the cornea, consisting of a radial bundle of brush-like vessels. 
  • Stage of regression: In this stage, the cloudiness disappears and the vessels become obliterated. Although they cease to carry blood, they remain permanently as fine opaque lines known as the 'ghost vessels'

Mooren ulcer is a rare, degenerative, superficial, marginal ulcer initiated by autoimmune lysis of the epithelium with consequent release of the collagenolytic enzymes. It is usually a diagnosis of exclusion.

questions.text: Urea and Kreb's cycle are linked by which of the following?
questions.solution:
Urea and Kreb's cycle are linked by Fumarate.

The ammonia from all over the body reaches the liver and is detoxified to urea (major end product of protein catabolism) by liver cells and excreted by the kidney, it partly takes place in mitochondria and partly in cytoplasm.

The products of the urea cycle obtained by cleavage of argininosuccinate are arginine and fumarate by the enzyme arginosuccinate lyase, this fumarate enters the Kreb's cycle (also known as the citric acid cycle) to get finally converted to oxaloacetate, hence also referred to as the urea bicycle.

questions.text: While working in a tertiary care centre,  a  5-year-old girl presents to you with polyuria, polydipsia, and nocturnal enuresis for the past one year. A water deprivation test is done and shows low urine osmolality on stopping the intake of water. On desmopressin administration, there is a 7% increase in urine osmolality.  All of the following can be used in the treatment of this condition except?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with an increase in urine osmolality of 7%, which is an insignificant rise, is suggestive of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI). Water restriction is not a treatment option.

Treatment of nephrogenic diabetes insipidus:

  • Adequate water intake along with a low-sodium diet
  • Thiazide diuretics act by 
    • Volume contraction increases the responsiveness of other parts of the tubule
    • Increase the AQP2 channels independent of vasopressin
  • Potassium-sparing diuretics (triamterene and amiloride): Amiloride is the drug of choice for lithium-induced DI
  • Prostaglandin synthesis inhibitor (indomethacin)

NDI in children can occur due to rare genetic causes that occur early in life and are more severe or acquired causes. The causes include:

  • Congenital (X-linked recessive, AVP V2 receptor pathogenic variants, autosomal recessive or dominant, aquaporin-2 water channel pathogenic variants)
  • Drug-induced (lithium, demeclocycline, cisplatin, methoxyflurane, foscarnet)
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypokalemia
  • Infiltrating lesions like sarcoidosis and amyloidosis
  • Vascular (sickle cell anemia)
  • Mechanical (polycystic kidney disease, bilateral ureteral obstruction)
  • Solute diuresis (glucose, mannitol, sodium, radiocontrast dyes)
  • Idiopathic

Note:

Patients with central diabetes insipidus are administered desmopressin.

In patients with primary polydipsia, fluid restriction increases and brings back the plasma osmolality and sodium to normal. This increases the levels of ADH, which results in increased urinary osmolality.

Related Pearl: Water Deprivation test in Diabetes Insipidus

Procedure: Start the test at 4 am by checking the baseline urine osmolality. Deprive the patient of water till 12 pm (8 hours), and then re-check urine osmolality. 

  Urine osmolality before water deprivation Urine osmolality after water deprivation Urine osmolality after desmopressin administration
Normal  Normal  Increases No change
Central DI Low No change >50% increase from baseline
Nephrogenic DI Low No change <10% increase from baseline
Primary polydipsia Low Increases No change


Note: Normal urine osmolality- 500-850 mOsm/L

questions.text:
A 35-year-old man with Type 1 Diabetes is brought to the emergency department with acute onset of abdominal pain, dizziness, and confusion. His family reports a week of increasing fatigue and generalized weakness. He was recently treated for a respiratory infection. On examination, he is hypotensive (BP: 85/55 mmHg) and tachycardic (HR: 110 bpm). What is the next step in the management of this patient?



Lab results:

Blood glucose: 80mg/dl

S.Sodium: 120meq/L

S.Potassium: 5.2meq/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a patient with signs of shock, hyperkalemia, hyponatremia, and fatigue strongly suggests an adrenal crisis, a life-threatening condition often triggered by stress (e.g., infection) in patients with chronic adrenal insufficiency. After initial stabilization, the next step in evaluation is to measure the serum cortisol levels. 

An adrenal crisis is an emergency typically occurring in patients with marginal adrenocortical function who are subjected to a physiological stressor. Clinical findings include shock, abdominal pain, fever, and occasionally hypoglycemia. Mineralocorticoid deficiency is the primary pathogenic mechanism. 

Primary adrenal insufficiency manifests with weakness and fatigue, weight loss, hyperpigmentation, hypotension, and electrolyte imbalance(hyponatremia and hyperkalemia). Adrenal destruction from autoimmune causes is the most common cause. It is often associated with other autoimmune disorders like type I diabetes mellitus, followed by infectious etiology predominantly tuberculous, adrenal replacement by metastatic tumor, and adrenal hemorrhage (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome). 

Treatment includes large-volume IV fluid resuscitation and hydrocortisone/dexamethasone. 

Other options: 

Option A: After the diagnosis of adrenal insufficiency has been made, a morning ACTH level is determined to differentiate between primary and secondary adrenal insufficiency.

Option C: Patients whose serum cortisol levels fall below thresholds should undergo provocative testing with a high-dose cosyntropin stimulation test. A positive test is highly suggestive of adrenal insufficiency. 

Option D: Serum aldosterone levels are used in hyperaldosteronism.

Related Pearl: Causes of Adrenocortical Insufficiency

Primary adrenal insufficiency:

  • Anatomical destruction of gland
  • Autoimmune (Addison's disease)
  • Isolated autoimmune adrenalitis (polygenic)
  • Infections - HIV, tuberculosis, fungi
  • Surgical removal
  • Acute hemorrhagic necrosis (Waterhouse-Friderichsen syndrome)
  • Amyloidosis, sarcoidosis, hemochromatosis
  • Metastatic carcinoma
  • Cytotoxic agents – mitotane
  • Enzyme inhibitors – metyrapone, ketoconazole
  • Congenital adrenal hypoplasia
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 1 (AIRE1 gene on 21q22)
  • Autoimmune polyendocrinopathy syndrome type 2 (polygenic)
  • X-linked adrenal hypoplasia (DAX1 gene on Xp21)
  • Adrenoleukodystrophy (ALD gene on Xq28)

Secondary adrenal insufficiency:

Hypopituitarism due to hypothalamic or pituitary disease

  • Neoplasm
  • Infiltration (sarcoidosis)
  • Infection (tuberculosis, pyogenic, fungal)

Suppression of HPA axis

  • By endogenous steroids from tumor
  • By exogenous steroids

questions.text: Which clinical symptom will not be present in the patient whose X Ray is shown?
questions.solution:
The given X-ray is of eagle syndrome. A patient with this condition will not have ear discharge.

Eagle syndrome, also called kerato-stylohyoidal syndrome, is characterised by an elongated styloid process or calcified stylohyoid ligament.

Etiology: Usually, this condition is seen post-tonsillectomy or post pharyngeal trauma. It is more common in Females (3:1).

Clinical Presentation:

  • Commonly bilateral
  • Presentation 1: Classic Eagle syndrome
    • Dull and persistent pharyngeal pain often referred to the ear.
    • Pain exacerbated by rotation of the head.
    • A palpable mass or a bulge in the tonsillar fossa.
    • Other associated symptoms like dysphagia, foreign body sensation, tinnitus and cervicofacial pain may be seen.
  • Presentation 2: Stylocarotid syndrome
    • Compression of the internal or external carotid artery by medially or laterally rotated styloid process.

Treatment: Styloidectomy in those not responding to conservative treatment with analgesics.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develops multiple and bilateral breast lumps that regress after cessation of treatment. ​The biopsy image is given below. Which of the following is incorrect regarding her condition?

choices.text: It is the most common benign breast tumor in females.
Overexpression of the transcription factor HOXB13 is frequently seen.
The epithelial component is hormonally responsive.

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this scenario is a fibroadenoma. Two-thirds of fibroadenomas harbor driver mutations in MED12 while overexpression of the transcription factor HOXB13 is associated with a severalfold increase in risk of developing adenocarcinoma of the prostate.

Fibroadenomas are the most common benign tumor of the female breast. They are frequently multiple and bilateral and usually occur in women<30 years of age. The epithelial component is hormonally responsive and is responsible for the increase in size during lactational changes or during pregnancy.

Almost half the women receiving cyclosporin A after renal transplantation develop multiple and bilateral fibroadenomas that regress after cessation of treatment.

Complex fibroadenomas are grouped with “proliferative changes without atypia” and are associated with a 1.5-2-times increased risk of subsequent cancer. Complex fibroadenomas contain cysts larger than 0.3 cm, sclerosing adenosis, epithelial calcifications, or papillary apocrine change.

Interesting fact: Fibroadenomas are sometimes called "Breast mouse" due to their high mobility within the breast.

Histological image of Fibroadenoma showing proliferation of ducts arranged in intracanalicular (compressed) and pericanalicular pattern surrounded by fibromyxoid stroma

According to recent studies,two-thirds of fibroadenomas harbor driver mutations in MED12. The pathogenesis of the remainder is uncertain.

questions.text: An adolescent presented with the following vesicular lesions 4 days after developing a fever. Which of the following would you expect to see on Tzanck smear microscopy in this condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows multiple vesicular lesions on the trunk suggestive of chickenpox or varicella caused by the varicella-zoster virus. Varicella-zoster shows multinucleated giant cells on microscopy with a Tzank smear.

Tzanck smear is a cytological examination of skin blisters. After rupturing the roof of the blister, the floor is scraped with a blade, and the material is transferred onto a microscopic slide and fixed. Slides are stained with Giemsa, Wright’s stain or toluidine blue and examined under the microscope, which shows multinucleated giant cells with faceted nuclei and homogeneously stained ground glass chromatin(Tzanck cells) as shown below.

Other options:

Option A: Acantholytic cells with Guarnieri bodies are seen in variola or smallpox.

Option B: Henderson Paterson bodies are eosinophilic bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum as shown in the image below.

Option D: Necrotic cells are seen in toxic epidermal necrolysis (TEN)

Related Pearl: Tzanck Smear in Dermatology

The Tzanck smear, introduced by the Frenchman Tzanck, is a simple to perform, inexpensive bed side cytological test that aids in the diagnosis of vesicular, pustular and bullous diseases, in particular herpes.

The sensitivity of the Tzanck smear exceeds 80%, and the specificity 90% when the investigators are experienced.

Preparation of Tzanck smear:

  • Viral infections and Blistering disorders - fresh vesicle or intact blister is de-roofed and base is scraped 
  • Suspected tumors - any crust should be removed from ulcerated tumors, and non-ulcerated tumors should be incised with a sharp, pointed scalpel and sample is then obtained with either a blunt scalpel or a small curette
  • The smear should preferably be fixed immediately using Formol-Zenker solution since significant artifacts can result from drying.
  • Tzanck smear can be stained by a variety of methods, most commonly by Giemsa stain. Other stains used are hematoxylin and eosin, Wright, methylene blue, Papanicolaou and toluidine blue. 

Results in Tzanck Smear:

A typical Tzanck cell is a large round keratinocyte with a hypertrophic nucleus, hazy or absent nucleoli, and abundant basophilic cytoplasm. The basophilic staining is deeper peripherally on the cell membrane ("mourning edged" cells) due to the cytoplasm's tendency to get condensed at the periphery, leading to a perinuclear halo.

Immunobullous Disorders 
Pemphigus Vulgaris Multiple acantholytic cells (Tzanck cells)
Staphylococcal Scalded Skin Syndrome (SSSS) Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with very few inflammatory cells
Toxic Epidermal Necrolysis(TEN) Necrotizing or degenerating basal cells with scattered inflammatory cells and fibroblasts 
Bullous pemphigoid (BP), Stevens-Johnson syndrome (SJS) and erosive lichen planus No acantholytic cells ; Many leucocytes
Cutaneous Infections 
Herpes simplex, varicella, herpes zoster Ballooning degeneration and multinucleated giant cells are seen
Molluscum contagiosum Diagnostic intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies), the largest known inclusion bodies (30-35 microns)
Vaccinia, orf, milker's nodules and variola Acantholytic squamous keratinocytes , eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion called a "Guarnieri body"
 Leishmaniasis Leishman-Donovan (LD) bodiesgrouped together in a typical "swarm of bees" fashion, within large macrophages (Wright's cells)
Bullous Impetigo Dyskeratotic acantholytic cells with abundant neutrophils and clusters of coccoid bacteria
Genodermatoses 
Hailey-Hailey disease Multiple acantholytic cells; Direct Immunofluorescence Negative
Darier's Disease "Corps ronds" are isolated keratinocytes with a round shape and an acidophilic cytoplasm. The corps grains are seen as small, hyaline, acidophilic ovoid bodies resembling pomegranate seeds.
Cutaneous Tumours 
Squamous Cell Carcinoma Atypical Squamous Cells
Basal Cell Carcinoma Clusters of Basaloid cells

 

Image : Tzanck smear , showing three multinucleated giant cells in center.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a part of the obstetric criteria for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody syndrome?

choices.text: ≥ 1 unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus ≥10 weeks
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery <37 weeks
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery <34 weeks

questions.solution:
Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks(not <37 weeks) is an obstetric criterion for diagnosis of antiphospholipid antibody (APLA) syndrome. 

Antiphospholipid antibody syndrome is an autoimmune disorder that is commonly associated with fetal death, preterm delivery, early-onset preeclampsia, and fetal growth restriction due to placental insufficiency and thromboses. Pregnancy loss usually occurs before ten weeks.

Diagnosis of APLA requires at least one clinical criterion and one laboratory criterion:

  • Clinical
    • Obstetric criteria - 
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond ten weeks, or
      • Severe preeclampsia or placental insufficiency requiring delivery before 34 weeks or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before ten weeks
    • Vascular - One or more episodes of arterial-venous or small vessel thrombosis in any organ or tissue
  • Laboratory criteria(2 positive tests at least 12 weeks apart) - 
    • Presence of lupus anticoagulant, or
    • Anticardiolipin antibodies, or
    • Anti-β2 glycoprotein antibody

Specific therapy in pregnancy: Aspirin plus heparin therapy is the most effective regimen. Women are treated with low-dose aspirin and heparin for up to 34 weeks. Unfractionated heparin and low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) are equally effective and safe. Corticosteroids are used only in secondary APLA syndrome (associated with SLE) and not in primary APLA syndrome. 

Prophylaxis:

  • Women with prior thromboembolic events - prophylactic anticoagulation throughout pregnancy and six weeks postpartum with either heparin are recommended. Serial sonographic assessment of fetal growth and antepartum testing should be done in the third trimester due to the risk of fetal growth abnormalities and stillbirths.
  • For women without prior thromboembolic events, acceptable regimes include - 
    • Close antepartum maternal observation with or without prophylactic heparin along with postpartum anticoagulation for 4 to 6 weeks or
    • Surveillance alone, or
    • Prophylactic heparin + low dose aspirin (if a prior history of recurrent abortion or stillbirth)

Note: The new 2023 ACR/EULAR criteria is an update from the revised Sapporo criteria with the clinical criteria, which includes an entry criterion of at least one positive antiphospholipid antibody within three years of identification of a clinical criterion, followed by scoring with weighted criteria divided into six clinical domains (macrovascular venous thromboembolism, macrovascular arterial thrombosis, microvascular, obstetric, cardiac valve, and hematologic) and two laboratory domains (lupus anticoagulant,  IgG/IgM anticardiolipin ELISA and/or IgG/IgM anti-β2 -glycoprotein I antibodies) This has increased the specificity in diagnosing APS.

questions.text: Image of an entry wound is given below, which of the following accurately reflects possible range of firing?
questions.solution:
There is a single circular wound about the diameter of the muzzle, there is no soiling, tattooing, and singeing. All these features are suggestive of contact shot.

Characteristics Contact shot Close Shot Near Shot Distant Shot
Range  In-touch with skin 2.5-7.5 cm 30-60 cm >60 cm
Size Largest size Bullet size Smaller Smallest

Other findings
