Tattooing -ve +ve +ve -ve
Singeing -ve +ve -ve -ve
Abrasion collar -ve +ve +ve +ve
Grease collar -ve +ve +ve +ve

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy was brought for psychiatric evaluation for intellectual disability. On examination, his IQ was 49. His facial features are as shown below. DNA testing is done to confirm the diagnosis. What is the trinucleotide repeat mutation associated with this syndrome?
questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette showing moderate mental retardation, long face, and large ears is suggestive of Fragile X syndrome associated with CGG trinucleotide repeat mutation on X chromosome.

The normal FMR1 gene contains CGG repeats. When the number of trinucleotide repeats is excessive, abnormal methylation of the region results in transcriptional suppression of FMR1 and the absence of familial mental retardation protein (FMRP).

Clinical features: X linked disease which predominantly affects males.

  • Moderate to severe mental retardation
  • Long face with a large mandible
  • Large everted ears
  • Large testicles (macroorchidism)
Disease Repeats Clinical features
Fragile X- syndrome   CGG Mental retardation, large ears, and jaws, macroorchidism in males

Myotonic Dystrophy

(chromosome 19)

   CTG Muscle loss, cardiac arrhythmia,
cataracts, frontal balding
Huntington’s disease   CAG Affective disorder
Spinocerebellar ataxia type 1   CAG Progressive ataxia, dysarthria,
dysmetria.
Friedreich's ataxia   GAA Progressive ataxia,
dysarthria, hypertrophic
cardiomyopathy.

Related Pearl: Intelligence Quotient

  • The intelligence quotient is a score that can be obtained from several standardized tests to assess human intelligence.
  • Historically, IQ = Mental age x 100/ Chronological age
  • Here, the mental age is obtained from intelligence tests.
  • Higher the IQ, the more brilliant is the person.
  • Classification of IQ according to Levine and Marks (1928) is as follows:

questions.text: A patient comes to the OPD complaining of sensory loss over the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third of the leg. He recalls undergoing a nerve reconstruction surgery. Which other region is supplied by the affected nerve?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette of weakness at the mentioned site, post nerve reconstruction surgery, suggests sural nerve involvement which also supplies the foot's lateral aspect marked as 2.

Sural nerve injury causes sensory loss over the posterior and lateral aspects of the distal third of the leg and lateral side of the foot and fifth toe. It is often used as an autologous peripheral nerve graft as it is readily identified and easy to harvest.

The lower limb is the largest donor site for perforator-based flaps. Commonly used flaps include anterolateral thigh flaps, superior and inferior gluteal artery perforator flaps in breast reconstruction, vascularised fibular flaps for reconstruction of deficient bone, vascularised tensor fascia lata flaps for tendon reconstruction, vascularised sural nerve flaps for nerve reconstruction, and gracilis muscle flap for reanimation of paralyzed muscle.

questions.text: Which of the following points is false about the Albers-Schonberg disease?

choices.text: Ostietis of the mandible is relatively common
Bones appear dense and sclerotic on X-rays
X-ray of vertebrae show rugger-jersey sign
It is caused due to defective osteoblastic activity

questions.solution:
Albers–Schönberg disease is also called as Osteopetrosis/Marble bone disease. It is caused due to a defect in the osteoclastic activity. All the other options are true regarding this disease.

It is a disorder involving defective bone resorption due to a mutation of CLCN7 (in osteoclasts). Clinical features include macrocephaly, developmental delay, anaemia (reduced bone marrow cavity), and hepatosplenomegaly (compensatory extramedullary hematopoiesis). Osteitis of the mandible is relatively common due to an alteration in the vascularity.

Blood investigations show low serum calcium and phosphorus levels with elevated parathyroid hormone (PTH) and normal vitamin D levels. Plain radiographs are usually diagnostic. Diffuse bone sclerosis with clubbing of metaphyses. Bone within the bone appearance and "sandwich" appearance of the vertebral bodies can be seen. Radiolucent bands of sclerotic vertebrae are often seen and are referred to as rugger-jersey sign.

Symptomatic treatment and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation can be done.

questions.text: Which of the following vaginal infections requires treatment of an asymptomatic male partner?
questions.solution:
The male partner should be treated with a single dose of oral metronidazole for Trichomonas infection.

Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection caused by the protozoan parasite Trichomonas vaginalis. It can cause symptoms such as vaginal discharge, itching, and irritation in females, and urethritis or prostatitis in males.

Since trichomoniasis is transmitted through sexual contact, both partners should be treated simultaneously to prevent reinfection.

The treatment is the oral dose of metronidazole 500 mg twice daily for 7 days or a single oral dose of metronidazole 2 g  

Other Options: 

Option A: Candida albicans is the fungus responsible for most cases of vaginal yeast infections (vulvovaginal candidiasis). It is not considered a sexually transmitted infection, and treatment of male partners is generally not necessary unless they have symptoms of a yeast infection.

Option B: Bacterial vaginosis is an imbalance of bacteria in the vagina and is not typically considered a sexually transmitted infection. Treatment of male partners is not routinely recommended. 

Option D: Herpes is a viral infection caused by the herpes simplex virus (HSV). While it can be sexually transmitted, the treatment of male partners may not be routinely necessary unless they are also infected or experiencing symptoms of genital herpes. Studies have shown no improvements in outcomes on routine treatment of asymptomatic partners of HSV-infected patients.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: A 57-year-old female diabetic patient presented with complaints of abdominal pain and weight loss. The lab investigations are suggestive of obstructive jaundice. Serum IgG4 level was found to be elevated. Which of the following statements is false regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: An MRI is likely to reveal a sausage-shaped pancreas

questions.solution:
The clinical features and characteristic elevated serum IgG4 levels are diagnostic of autoimmune pancreatitis. NSAIDs are not used in the treatment.

Patients with autoimmune pancreatitis present with features of obstructive jaundice, weight loss, and mild abdominal pain.

On radiography, the sausage-shaped appearance of the pancreas on the T2 weighted MRI is diagnostic of autoimmune pancreatitis. Serum IgG4 level is considered the best serological marker for AIP. However, in the absence of typical radiographic findings, the elevation of IgG4 is not sufficient to make the diagnosis of AIP.

Most of the cases may resolve spontaneously, however, corticosteroid therapy is still provided as it causes increased remession of AIP. Initially, prednisone is given at a dose of 0.6 mg/Kg for 2 weeks. If there is clinical and radiological improvement, the dose of prednisone is gradually tapered by 5 mg/week.

Shown below is an MRI image of autoimmune pancreatitis showing a sausage-shaped pancreas.

Related Pearl: Laboratory Findings in Acute Pancreatitis

  • Elevated serum amylase and serum lipase
    • Serum amylase level rises immediately and peaks in few hours and returns to normal in 3–5 days
    • Serum amylase level lacks specificity
    • Serum amylase levels do not correlate with the severity of pancreatitis.
    • Serum lipase is more specific, and it is more useful when the patient presents 24–48 hours later
  • Hyperglycemia
  • Hypocalcemia, hypoalbuminemia
  • Leukocytosis
  • Elevated serum levels of hepatic enzymes like alanine aminotransferase (ALT)
  • Azotemia, due to prerenal acute renal failure in case of severe fluid loss

Related Pearl: Ranson Prognostic Criteria for Acute Pancreatitis

Ranson's prognostic criteria at presentation
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis
Age >55 years >70 years
Blood glucose level >200 mg/dL >220 mg/dL
White blood cell count >16,000 cells/mm3 >18,000 cells/mm3
Serum LDH level >350 IU/L  >400 IU/L
Serum Aspartate aminotransferase level  >250 IU/L  >250 IU/L

 

Ranson's prognostic criteria after 48 hours of admission
Parameter Non-gallstone pancreatitis Gallstone pancreatitis 
Hematocrit fall
 >10% >10%
Serum calcium level <8 mg/dL <8 mg/dL
Base deficit >4 mEq/L >5 mEq/L
Blood urea nitrogen level increase 

≥5 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration

 ≥2 mg/dL despite IV fluid hydration
Fluid sequestration
  >6 L  >4 L
PaO2  <60 mm Hg  Not available

Ranson score ≥3 defines severe pancreatitis.

Score Interpretation

  • 0 to 2 points: 0% to 3% mortality
  • 3 to 4 points: 15% mortality
  • 5 to 6 points: 40% mortality
  • 7 to 11: nearly 100% mortality

questions.text: You observe a patient in the neurology ward with dysphagia, dysarthria, and dysphonia. On examination, brisk jaw jerk is seen. Imaging studies reveal bilateral corticobulbar lesions. What is the possible diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient presenting with dysphagia, dysarthria, dysphonia, and brisk jaw jerk along with an imaging finding of bilateral corticobulbar lesions points to a diagnosis of pseudobulbar palsy. 

Bilateral corticobulbar lesions produce pseudobulbar palsy which is an example of upper motor neuron palsy. It has the following features:   chewing, weakness of the facial muscles, dysarthria, palatal weakness and regurgitation of fluids, dysphagia, and dysphonia.

Other options:

Option A - Syringomyelia is a disease of the central spinal cord, caused by an enlargening syrinx within the central canal leading to compressive symptoms. It is characterized by wasting of muscles in the lower neck, shoulder, asymmetric or absent reflexes in the arms, and arms along with loss of pain and temperature sensation in the upper limbs.  

Option B - Syringobulbia occurs when the syrinx of syringomyelia extends into the medulla. It is characterized by palatal or vocal cord paralysis, episodic vertigo tongue weakness with atrophy, and horizontal nystagmus. 

Option C - Bulbar palsy presents with lower motor neuron paralysis which include clinical features such as fasiculations, hypotonia, increased muscle wastage, absent Babinski's sign, decreased muscle stretch reflexes and segmental distribution of weakness more distally while pseudobulbar palsy presents with upper motor neuron paralysis features such as increased spasticity, hypertonia, involvement of lower part of the face, rigidity and brisk reflexes.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient came to you with the complaints of swelling of the right lower limb. During the examination, you noticed that the edema was non-pitting, and you were not able to pinch the skin on the dorsum of the toes on the right foot, as shown in the image given below. The edema did not reduce upon elevation of the limb, however, there were no irreversible skin changes. What is the Brunner grading in this patient?
questions.solution:
Non-pitting oedema, which does not reduce on elevation, having a positive stemmer sign (as shown in the above image) with no irreversible skin changes would be classified as grade II according to Brunner's grading.

Stemmer’s sign is seen in lymphedema. When the skin on the dorsum of the toes cannot be pinched, the stemmer's sign is said to be positive. It occurs due to subcutaneous fibrosis.

Clinical classification of lymphedema: Brunner's Grading

Grade Clinical features
Subclinical (latent) No clinically apparent lymphoedema (excess interstitial ﬂuid and histological abnormalities in lymphatics and lymph nodes)
I Edema pits on pressure and swelling largely or completely disappears on elevation and bed rest.
II Edema does not pit and does not signiﬁcantly reduce upon elevation, positive Stemmer’s sign.
III Edema is associated with irreversible skin changes, i.e. ﬁbrosis, papillae.

questions.text:
A 9-year-old boy is being considered for prophylaxis after being exposed to his younger sibling with diphtheria. His vaccination status is unknown. His throat cultures are negative. What is the next step in the management of this patient?

IM-Intramuscular
questions.solution:
This patient has a history of exposure to a diphtheria patient and has negative cultures, with an unclear vaccination history. The next step in the management is oral erythromycin + Td vaccination. 

All household contacts of diphtheria should be closely monitored for 7 days. Culture should be taken from both the throat and nose. After culture, all contacts should receive the following:

  • Antibiotic prophylaxis (benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin), regardless of immunization status.
  • If fewer than three doses of diphtheria toxoid have been given, or vaccination history is unknown, an immediate dose of diphtheria toxoid, Td vaccine should be given and the primary series completed according to the current schedule.
  • If more than 5 years have elapsed since the administration of the diphtheria toxoid-containing vaccine, a booster dose should be given.
  • If the most recent dose was within 5 years, no booster is required.

At least two successive negative cultures obtained 24 hr apart after completion of therapy are needed to confirm the elimination of the organism.

Choose one of the following antibiotics for prevention:

Antibiotics Dosage
IM benzathine penicillin: a single dose

1. For children aged ≤ 5 years: administer 60k units

2. For those > 5 years: administer 1.2 lakh units
Oral erythromycin 

For children: 40 mg/kg/day, administered in divided dose, 10 mg per dose, every 6 hours

For adults: 1 g/day for adults, administered in divided dose, 250 mg per dose every 6 hours

Treat for total 7 days

Oral Azithromycin 

(As an alternative)

Children: 10-12 mg/kg once daily, to a max of 500mg/day.

Adults: 500mg once daily.

Treat for total 7 days

questions.text: A 56-year-old AIDS patient presented with fever and signs of meningitis. The latex agglutination test of cerebrospinal fluid revealed antigens of Cryptococcus neoformans. How did the patient most likely acquire this infection?

choices.text: Consumption of spores in contaminated food or water
Inhalation of infectious particles in respiratory secretions from an infected person
Inhalation of oocysts from cat feces
Inhalation of yeast cells from pigeon droppings

questions.solution:
The patient acquired cryptococcosis by inhaling yeast cells from pigeon droppings.

Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus neoformans, which is an opportunistic fungus. It may cause infection in immunocompromised persons, particularly those who have HIV/AIDS and those who are on corticosteroid therapy. 

Patients complain of headache, neck stiffness, and disorientation. 

Cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) pressure, protein concentration, and cell count are elevated, whereas the glucose is normal or low. In microscopy, specimens are often examined in wet mounts, both directly and after mixing with India ink. CSF, urine, and blood are used for the detection of capsular antigen using latex slide agglutination or enzyme immunoassay methods.

Combination therapy of amphotericin B and flucytosine is used in the management of cryptococcal meningitis.

questions.text: All of the following are true regarding a Wolfe graft except:
questions.solution:
Wolfes graft is a type of full-thickness graft. The best cosmetic appearance is seen with a full-thickness graft.

Full-thickness skin grafts include the epidermis and the complete layer of the dermis. They are used for smaller areas of skin replacement where good elastic skin is required.

Full-thickness grafts are associated with,

  • The greatest amount of primary contraction
  • The least amount of secondary contraction
  • The highest durability
  • The best cosmetic appearance

As a result, they are frequently used in reconstructing superficial wounds on the face and the hands.

  Full-thickness skin graft (Wolfe) Split thickness skin graft (Thiersche)
Structure Epidermis + complete dermis ± fat Epidermis + part of dermis
Donor site location Post auricular, supra/infra-clavicular. 
Never axillary		 Thigh > buttocks
Donor site wound Must be sutured Requires only dressing and can be reused
Recipient site Must be well vascularised. Small area May be inadequately vascularized. Larger area (achieved by meshing)
Graft features
Durability High Low
Contracture Primary > secondary High secondary contracture
Uptake Require more care to ensure uptake High-reliability
Cosmetic result Good Poor (abnormal pigmentation)

questions.text: Which of the following methods is used to demonstrate the oxygen requirements of the bacterium?
questions.solution:
The culture method used to demonstrate the oxygen requirements of a bacterium is stab culture. It is also used for demonstrating other properties like gelatin liquefaction. 

The image below shows stab culture. It is prepared by puncturing a suitable medium with a long, straight, charged wire. The oxygen-requiring bacteria will grow on the surface, and the bacteria that do not require oxygen will grow at the bottom.

Other methods used in bacterial culture:

  • Lawn culture/carpet culture: It is used for bacteriophage typing and antibiotic sensitivity testing. It is prepared by flooding the surface of the plate with a liquid culture.
  • Streak culture: It is routinely used for the isolation of bacteria in pure culture from clinical specimens. It is prepared by picking the specimen using platinum loops or straight wires and transferring it onto a well-dried plate. The inoculum is then distributed thinly over the plate by streaking it with the loop in a series of parallel lines, in different segments of the plate.
  • Pour plate culture: It gives an estimate of viable bacterial count in a suspension. It is prepared by adding appropriate dilutions of the inoculum (of 1 ml) to the molten (40-45°C) agar, which is mixed and poured into sterile petri dishes. After incubation, colonies are seen to be distributed throughout the depth of the medium. 
  • Liquid culture: These are preferred for inocula containing antibiotics and other inhibitory substances. It is prepared by inoculating liquid cultures in tubes, bottles, or flasks by touching with a charged loop, pipettes or syringe. 

Related Pearl: Organisms and selective Culture Media

questions.text: A 50-year-old female patient presented to the OPD with complaints of intermittent bloating, abdominal pain, and chronic diarrhea with greasy stools. Her past medical history is significant for systemic sclerosis, diabetes mellitus and hypertension. The lactulose breath test shows a higher-than-normal reading after 1 hour. What is the likely complication she has developed?
questions.solution:
The above patient is a case of systemic sclerosis who has now presented with symptoms of malabsorption and rapid increase in the hydrogen breath test over the normal limit. Systemic sclerosis can lead to decreased gut motility due to progressive fibrosis of the gut muscles, leading to an increased risk of developing  SIBO (Small intestinal bacterial overgrowth). 

SIBO is a condition characterized by overgrowth of bacteria in the small bowel. this can lead to bloating, flatulence, and secretory diarrhea.

Risk factors for SIBO:

  • Surgically created blind loops
  • Short bowel syndrome
  • Decreased intestinal motility
  • Resection of ileocecal valve
  • Type 2 diabetes mellitus
  • Decreased gastric acid secretion

Diagnosis is by small bowel cultures or Lactulose hydrogen breath test which shows more than 20ppm of hydrogen. Treatment is with an antibiotic like rifaximin. 

Related Pearl: Manifestations of systemic sclerosis

Organ

Manifestations

Skin

Endothelial injury and microvascular disease causing chronic ischemia

Alimentary Tract

Affected in approximately 90% of patients.

Progressive atrophy and collagenous fibrous replacement of the muscular is most severe in the esophagus.

The lower two-thirds of the esophagus often develops a rubber-hose–like an inflexibility.

Gastroesophageal reflux and Barrett metaplasia and strictures.

Musculoskeletal System

Hypertrophy and hyperplasia of the synovial soft tissues

Joint destruction is not common in systemic sclerosis.

Inflammatory myositis

Kidneys.

The most prominent are the vascular lesions.

Interlobular arteries show intimal thickening as a result of deposition of mucinous or finely collagenous material

Lungs.

The lungs are involved in more than 50% of individuals

Pulmonary hypertension and interstitial fibrosis

Pulmonary fibrosis

Heart

Pericarditis with effusion, myocardial fibrosis, and thickening of intramyocardial arterioles

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Seen in systemic sclerosis.

questions.text: Two infants born on simultaneous days in a hospital had similar deformities as shown below. Both of the infant's mothers were suffering from similar medical condition. Which is the most common cardiac anomaly in an infant born to such mothers?
questions.solution:
The most common cardiac anomaly born to infants of diabetic mother is ventricular septal defect.

In the given image of two infants, both are suffering from sacral agenesis, which is part of the caudal regression syndrome. Caudal regression syndrome is overall the most specific anomaly in infants of diabetic mother. The increased sugar in fetus results in congenital anomalies.

Most common system affected in infants of diabetic mother is the cardiovascular system, among which the most common anomaly is ventricular septal defect while most specific is transposition of great  arteries.

It is also to be noted that most common group of anomalies noticed in infants of diabetic mother is neural tube defects.

questions.text: While examining a neonate, the corner of her mouth was touched and she turned her head and opened the mouth in that direction. When does this reflex get fully developed?
questions.solution:
The reflex described above is the rooting reflex. It is fully developed by 34 to 36 weeks of gestation, appears by 28-32 weeks of gestation, and becomes less prominent by one month postnatal. 

Stimulation of the baby's mouth results in the mouth turning in the direction of the stimulus and making sucking (rooting) motions. This helps in proper attachment and sucking during initiation of breastfeeding.

Related Pearl: Timeline for primitive reflexes

35 weeks of gestation

According to Ghai Essential Paediatrics, 9th edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 4 months of age. According to Nelson Paediatrics, 21st edition, tonic neck reflex disappears by 6 months of age. Hence, the answer depends on the reference chosen by the examiner.

questions.text: In a patient diagnosed with autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, all of the following manifestations are commonly seen except?
questions.solution:
In the case of autosomal dominant polycystic kidney disease, all of the above manifestations are usually seen except congenital hepatic fibrosis, which is commonly associated with autosomal recessive polycystic kidney disease.

ADPKD is associated with mutations in PKD1, encoding polycystin 1, and PKD2, encoding polycystin 2. The multiple expanding cysts of both kidneys ultimately destroy the renal parenchyma and cause renal failure. Cysts arise from the tubules throughout the nephron and, therefore, have variable lining epithelia.

The common extrarenal manifestations of ADPKD include: 
  • Hepatic cysts - most common 
  • Seminal vesicle cysts - can result in infertility
  • Arachnoid membrane cysts - usually asymptomatic, may increase the risk of subdural hematoma
  • Pancreatic cysts 
  • Splenic cysts
  • Intracranial berry aneurysms
  • Subarachnoid haemorrhages
  • Mitral valve prolapse 

Related Pearl: Cystic Diseases of the Kidney

Features  Adult PKD Childhood PKD
Mode of inheritance Autosomal dominant Autosomal recessive
Mutation in genes PKD1, PKD2 PKHD1
Proteins produced Polycystin 1, polycystin 2 Fibrocystin
Chromosomes involved 16p, 4q 6p
Extrarenal manifestations 

Multiple cysts in the liver (most common), pancreas, spleen

Berry aneurysms in the circle of Willis - SAH

Colonic diverticuli

Mitral valve prolapse

 Congenital hepatic fibrosis

Other cystic diseases:

Medullary sponge kidney - 

  • Sporadic in origin
  • Characterized by medullary cysts
  • Associated with hematuria, recurrent renal stones, and normal renal function

Multicystic renal dysplasia - 

  • Characterized by irregular, enlarged, multicystic kidneys
  • Associated with ureteropelvic obstruction, ureteral agenesis, or atresia 
  • Bilateral multicystic renal dysplasia  is associated with renal failure

Simple renal cysts - 

  • Characterized by single or multiple cysts with normal-sized kidney
  • Associated with microscopic hematuria

questions.text:
A G2P1L1 female visits the antenatal clinic during her 4th month of gestation. She had received two doses of Td vaccine during her last pregnancy. You still recommend that she receives 2 doses of Td for the current pregnancy. What is the likely interval between her two pregnancies?

Td- Tetanus and Diphtheria
questions.solution:
The likely interval between her two pregnancies is 5 years (beyond 3 years) because she was recommended the full schedule of 2 Td doses in the current pregnancy.

Recommendations for tetanus vaccination in pregnant women:

Category Td vaccination recommendation
Previously immunized pregnant women
  • A booster dose is considered sufficient as long as the patient has been immunized within the past 3 years.
  • If the previous immunization was beyond 3 years, 2 doses of Td are administered 4 weeks apart.
  • Ideally, Td-2 or booster doses are given before 36 weeks of pregnancy.
  • Td is given to a woman in labor if she has not previously received Td.
Unimmunized pregnant women
  •  Two doses of tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine should be given, the first as early as possible during pregnancy and the second at least a month later and at least 3 weeks before delivery.
  • These doses may be given at 16–36 weeks of pregnancy.

The tetanus and adult diphtheria (Td) vaccine is a combination of tetanus and diphtheria toxoids, with a lower concentration of diphtheria antigen (d), as recommended for older children and adults.

The MoHFW recommends the replacement of the TT vaccine with the Td vaccine for all age groups, including pregnant women. A dose of 0.5 mL is administered via the intramuscular route in the upper arm.

questions.text: Consider the cycle showing management sequence of sudden disaster. Which of the following is correctly matched?
questions.solution:
The letter C is correctly matched as reconstruction.

The correct sequence is:

A - Response

B - Rehabilitation

C - Reconstruction

D - Mitigation

E - Preparedness

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presents to the clinic with complaints of a painless lump on the lateral aspect of his left knee. The radiograph of the patient is shown below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette and the given radiograph showing pedunculated growth in the metaphyseal region projecting away from the epiphysis suggest the diagnosis of osteochondroma. 

Osteochondromas are benign bone tumours that are commonly present in the adolescent age group. They usually present as painless masses in long bones like the femur or humerus. 

They are seen as well-defined bony protuberances, which may be pedunculated or sessile. Pedunculated osteochondromas point away from the joint, towards the diaphysis. The cortex and cancellous bone of osteochondroma blend with that of the host bone. MRI shows a classical cartilaginous cap. Osteochondromas usually grow with skeletal maturity and stop once growth stops.

Osteochondroma can turn into low-grade chondrosarcoma, but the malignant transformation is extremely rare. It should be suspected in the following cases:

  • Growth after skeletal maturity
  • Lucency in the bone
  • Additional scintigraphic activity
  • Cortical destruction
  • Pain after puberty
  • Soft tissue mass
  • Thickened cartilage cap >2 cm

Treatment is not indicated if the lesion does not produce symptoms. Excision can be done for large lesions with local pressure effects.

Other options:

Option A: Enchondroma is an intramedullary tumour of hyaline cartilage. They are asymptomatic and discovered incidentally. They are usually seen in individuals aged 20 to 50 years in the tubular bones of the hands and feet. Radiographically, it appears as a central lesion with well-defined, rounded edges and a thin rind of reactive sclerosis.

Option B: Chondroblastoma is a benign tumour and presents as a painful mass that causes effusion or stiffness. On X-rays, they are seen as round or oval lytic lesions in the epiphysis. The bony cortex is not breached but can appear expanded. The common sites are the ends of long bones. Microscopically, chondroblastoma consists of a sheet of chondroblasts embedded in the chondroid matrix. The calcification is often present and surrounds individual cells, giving the appearance of ‘chicken wire.’

Option D: Giant cell tumour or osteoclastoma is a benign but locally aggressive tumour. It usually affects young adults, with a peak incidence in the age group of 20–45 years. It presents as a painful mass. A plain radiograph reveals an eccentric, expansile, lobulated lytic lesion in the epiphysis. There is minimal calcification within the tumour. Biopsy reveals osteoclast-like giant cells scattered among round or spindle-shaped mononuclear cells.

questions.text: A 14-year-old child presented with multiple hyperpigmented lesions of around size 15-20 mm in the trunk and extremities. Similar lesions of size 2-3 mm were found in his axillary and inguinal regions. An ocular examination showed the lesions given in the image. A genetic syndrome is suspected. On which chromosome, is the defective gene present and what is the pattern of inheritance seen here?
questions.solution:
The given images show Lisch nodules seen in neurofibromatosis-1. The NF1 gene on chromosome 17q11 is involved. It is an autosomal dominant neurocutaneous syndrome. 

Neurofibromatosis -1 is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutation in gene located on chromosome 17. It is characterised by neurofibromas, cafe-au-lait spots, axillary freckling and Lisch nodules. Lisch nodules are hamartomas of the iris.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed severe abdominal pain, vertigo, and convulsions after consumption of the seeds shown in the image. The active principle of this plant which is a toxalbumen is known as _____ and it acts by inhibiting ______
questions.solution:
The seeds shown in the image are of the Abrus precatorius plant. Abrin is a toxalbumen toxin of this plant and it acts by inhibiting protein synthesis.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius are:

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen)
  • Abrine (an amino acid)
  • Abralin (a glucoside)

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, thereby, resulting in cell death. The clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, weakness, cold perspiration, trembling, weak rapid pulse, and miosis. Faintness, vertigo, dyspnea, and convulsions can also occur. If taken by injection, painful swelling, ecchymosis with inflammation, and necrosis are seen at the site of injection.

Medicolegal Importance:

  • It is a commonly used cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as Sui (meaning needle in Hindi).
  • These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles and dried in the sun, and used to kill cattle by driving it deep into the animal body by blowing through a hollow bamboo pipe.

Option A- Ricin is the toxic principle of the Ricinus communis plant. It causes the burning of oral mucosa similar to alkali burn, severe abdominal pain, hemolysis, convulsions, uremia, collapse, and death. 

Related Pearl: Plant poisons

Datura stramonium (Jimsonweed) : Flower and fruit are poisonous

Ricinus communis : Seed is poisonous

Digitalis purpurea 

Atropa belladonna

Calotropis gigantea

questions.text: A young man presents to an emergency room with sudden onset of the chest and epigastric pain. An ECG done reveals no abnormality. On palpation, you hear a crunchy sound of the chest and rigidity in the epigastric region. An X-ray chest of the patient is given below. Which among the following contrasts is contraindicated in confirming the diagnosis using fluoroscopy?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with crunchy sound on chest palpation and an x-ray showing pneumothorax (white arrow) and pleural effusion (black arrowhead) in the chest points towards a diagnosis of esophageal perforation. Water-insoluble contrast media like barium sulphate is contraindicated to confirm the diagnosis using fluoroscopy. 

Esophageal perforation most commonly occurs due to iatrogenic instrumentation. Spontaneous perforation occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis—Boerhaave syndrome. Clinically, patients typically will have pain in the chest and epigastric region. On examination, abdominal rigidity and a crunchy sound on chest palpation (Hamman's sign) due to subcutaneous emphysema from leakage of air into subcutaneous space are seen. 

The classic chest radiographic findings include pneumomediastinum, left pleural effusion, and left pneumothorax.

Low-osmolar water-soluble contrast medium like iopamidol is used for the diagnostic workup for a suspected case of esophageal perforation instead of barium contrast to prevent barium-related inflammation of the mediastinum. However, if water-soluble contrast media is not available, diluted barium can be used.

Barium sulfate is not normally absorbed during its passage through the digestive tract. However when the integrity of the gut wall is compromised or when there is abnormal communication between the esophagus and trachea, it can overflow into the lungs, mediastinum, intraperitoneal cavity, and tissue around the rectum and cause inflammation. Hence, it is contraindicated in these cases.

Contraindications to use of barium:

  • Esophageal perforation: Iodinated contrast media like iopamidol and iohexol are used; gastrograffin can also be used but is not preferred due to risk of aspiration pneumonitis.
  • Tracheoesophageal fistula: dianosil, the water-soluble non-ionic agent is used.
  • Duodenal perforation: iohexol or gastrograffin is used.

The image given below shows contrast esophagogram showing leakage of dye through the leak/perforation site:

 

The image given below shows an axial CT thorax showing extraluminal air surrounding the esophagus and trachea:

questions.text: A 30-year-old man was brought to the casualty after being found unresponsive at home with two emptied packets of valproic acid tablets.  On examination, the patient was hypotensive and PR- 100 bpm. IV fluids were administered. Gastric lavage performed yielded a few fragments of the tablet. Which of the following is a specific antidote used to treat this patient's toxicity?
questions.solution:
Intravenous administration of carnitine is the specific antidote that can be used to manage this patient's valproate drug toxicity.

Valproate therapy reduces carnitine levels in tissues, potentially impacting mitochondrial function and leading to hyperammonemia and microvesicular steatosis. Genetic factors also play a role, as individuals who are heterozygous for mutations in the gamma polymerase gene, which is primarily present in mitochondria, are more susceptible to valproate-induced liver damage.

Valproate is an anti-epileptic medication and is also used as a mood stabilizer in manic episodes as well as in bipolar disorder. The repetitive firing caused by the depolarization of cortical or spinal cord neurons is inhibited by valproate. It also prolongs the sodium channel inactivation. Valproate can cause idiosyncratic hepatic toxicity and interfere with the conversion of ammonia to urea leading to hyperammonemia. Valproate is contraindicated in patients with genetic defects in urea metabolism.

The side effects of valproate (mnemonic: VALPROATE)

Vomiting
Alopecia
Liver toxicity
Pancreatitis
Rash
Obesity
Anorexia
Teratogenicity
Edema

It causes congenital anomalies like neural tube defects (Spina Bifida), clefts, and cardiac anomalies. The intelligence quotient score of school-going children who were exposed in utero to valproate is found reduced. It also contributes to poor cognitive development in children. Folate supplementation reduces the chances of neural tube defects.

Other options :

Option A: Glucagon is the specific antidote used in the treatment of beta-blocker drug toxicity.
Option C: N-acetylcysteine is the specific antidote used in the treatment of acetaminophen drug toxicity.
Option D : Isoniazid, an anti-TB drug, leads to pyridoxine deficiency resulting in peripheral neuropathy. Hence pyridoxine supplementation is included in ATT regimens. 

Related Pearl: Important Adverse Effects of Anti-epileptic Drugs

questions.text: All of the following are included among the major criteria of the modified Duke's criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis, except _____.

choices.text: Echocardiography showing endocardial involvement with definite vegetations
Coxiella burnetii anti-phase I IgG antibody titer greater than 1:800
At least two consecutive positive blood cultures for Coxiella burnetii

questions.solution:
Single positive blood culture for Coxiella burnetii is one of the major criteria of modified Duke's criteria for the diagnosis of infective endocarditis. All other options are true.

Infective endocarditis is associated with bacterial or fungal infection of the valvular or endocardial surface of the heart. The definitive diagnosis can only be established by histological and microbiological examinations of the vegetation.

However, a diagnostic schema called, modified Duke criteria, is usually used for diagnosis. The criteria are based on clinical, laboratory, and echocardiographic findings commonly encountered in patients with endocarditis, as described below.

The diagnosis is made based on the presence of

  • Two major criteria, or
  • One major and three minor criteria, or
  • Five minor criteria.

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: An elderly man presented with weight loss, easy fatiguability, and bone pain for 6 months duration. A bone marrow aspirate showed characteristic cells as in the image below. Cytogenetic studies revealed the presence of t(15:17). Which of the following drugs can be highly effective for the above condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of an elderly man presenting with constitutional symptoms, bone marrow aspirate showing faggot cells, and cytogenetic studies demonstrating the presence of translocation (15:17) is suggestive of acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). Among the given drugs tretinoin (All-trans-retinoic acid) is highly effective for the treatment of (APL).

Faggot cells are cells with multiple Auer rods clustered together within a single cell that resemble a bundle of sticks or twigs.

APL is associated with the production of a fusion gene PML-RARα due to the above-mentioned translocation. Tretinoin binds to the RARα-RXR dimer. It thus prevents the formation of the PML-RARα fusion gene dimerization and also degrades the already formed PML-RARα fusion genes. This leads to blockade of myeloid precursor cell differentiation into cells of different lineage.

Tretinoin alone can induce temporary remission but induction therapy with tretinoin and daunorubicin/doxorubicin produces complete remission. 

The most serious adverse effect of the treatment of tretinoin is 'retinoic acid syndrome'. It comprises breathlessness, fever, pleural/pericardial effusion, and pulmonary infiltrates. The occurrence of this can be prevented by pretreatment with dexamethasone.  

Other options:

Option B- Gemcitabine is a difluoro cytidine analog. It is mainly indicated in patients with nonresectable or metastatic pancreatic tumors, nonsquamous,  non-small cell lung tumors, ovarian and bladder cancer. 

Option C- Idarubicin is an anthracyline that can be used along with tretinoin in induction therapy for APL. It is indicated with cytarabine for the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia. 

Option D- Imatinib is a BCR-ABL tyrosine kinase inhibitor expressed by chronic myeloid leukemia.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman was brought by her relatives with complaints of insomnia, agitation, and restlessness. She was yelling about how the world is going to end and she has been assigned to save everyone. She had a history of multiple similar episodes in the past. Which of the following neurotransmitters is least likely to be involved in her condition?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of mania. Glutamate is least likely to be inolved in the pathogenesis of mania. Glutamate is more commonly involved in the mediation of neurocognitive effects of severe recurrent depression.

Norepinephrine and serotonin are the most commonly implicated neurotransmitters in the pathophysiology of mood disorders.

Dopamine has been shown to play a significant role in the development of mania.

The defining characteristics of mania are increased talkativeness, rapid speech, decreased need for sleep racing thoughts, distractibility, increase in goal-directed activity, and psychomotor agitation.

Some other hallmarks of mania are elevated or expansive mood, mood lability, impulsivity, irritability, and grandiosity.

In general, a manic patient should be treated with both a medication that alleviates acute mania, such as olanzapine, risperidone, or haloperidol, and also a medication for stabilization to prevent future mood episodes, such as lithium or valproic acid.

Psycho-education and psychotherapy are powerful long-term tools for patients with bipolar disorder as well as for their families or caregivers. In-depth, insight-oriented psychotherapy is not an appropriate treatment for mania.

questions.text: A man is under suspicion of smuggling cocaine in his body at the local airport. He is asymptomatic and an X-ray of the abdomen was done and is shown below. The next best step in the management of this case would be:
questions.solution:
The given scenario with an X-ray showing multiple cylindrical capsules (marked as *) in the stomach and intestine is consistent with body packing. The next best step in the management of this case would be to initiate whole-bowel irrigation.

 

The X-ray reveals that the packs are largely intact and unruptured. Since he is asymptomatic, the next step in management would be to give single-dose activated charcoal and institute whole-bowel irrigation with polyethylene glycol electrolyte solution to hasten packet elimination gently.

Body packing involves swallowing packets of illegal drugs like heroin, cannabis, morphine, and cocaine to smuggle the same. Usually, the drugs are packed by first carefully wrapping them in latex or plastic. These are swallowed and later excreted with the help of laxatives.

Similarly, a person who smuggles these drugs by consuming or stuffing drugs in the rectum or the vagina is referred to as a body stuffer. This generally occurs due to the non-availability of time. Radiography is not as helpful in these cases. Drug toxicity may be seen in body stuffers due to systemic absorption of the drug.

Other options:

Option A: Sometimes, drugs like heroin or cocaine that have the same radiodensity as feces, may be difficult to detect on X-rays. A CT scan helps to identify the same in this scenario.

Option B: Endoscopy or colonoscopy to remove the drugs is not done because any manipulation can rupture the packets, leading to their toxicity. 

Option D: Surgery is indicated in those patients who exhibit the symptoms of toxicity due to the rupture of packets.

questions.text: A young woman presents with ocular redness, foreign body sensation, and excessive tearing following the use of a contact lens. An interface contrast microscopy from her corneal scraping is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of ocular redness, watering and foreign body sensation in a contact lens wearer and the demonstration of polygonal cysts in interface contrast microscopy suggest Acanthamoeba keratitis. 

Acanthamoeba keratitis is an infection of the eyes that typically develops from the entry of the amebic cyst through abrasions on the cornea. Most of the cases are associated with the use of contact lenses and individuals who swim or bathe in contaminated water. 

Patients usually present with photophobia, excessive tearing, redness, and foreign body sensation, which can be bilateral in contact lens users. Pain is disproportionate to the degree of keratitis due to perineural invasion. It presents as a ring lesion or ring stromal infiltrate as shown below. 

Diagnosis of amoebic keratitis is made by the demonstration of the cyst in corneal scrapings by wet mount, histology, and culture. The cysts are smaller (12-25 micrometers) and polygonal or star-shaped.

Topical administration of biguanides or chlorhexidine with or without diamidine agents can be used for the management of acanthamoeba keratitis. In severe cases penetrating keratoplasty can be done.

Other options:

Option A: Herpes simplex keratitis is caused by recurrent herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection in the cornea characterised by a superficial dendritic ulcer, epithelial keratitis, reduction in corneal sensation and geographic ulcer.

Option C: A fungal corneal ulcer is usually caused by trauma with vegetative or organic matter. The corneal ulcer appears dry with delicate feathery finger-like extensions. A sterile, immune ring (yellow line of demarcation), as well as multiple, small satellite lesions, may be present.

Option D: Mooren's ulcer is a peripheral ulcerative keratitis (PUK) due to autoimmune origin. It starts as patches of grey infiltrate at the corneal margin which then progresses to the whole cornea.

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

questions.text: For a community’s well water, Horrock’s apparatus first shows the 3rd cup changing color to blue. What will be the required dose of bleaching powder for disinfecting 9100 litres of water?
questions.solution:
The dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) gms for 455 litres of water, where n is the number of the first cup that shows distinct blue color.

In this scenario, the dose of bleaching powder required to disinfect 455 litres of water is (3 x 2) = 6 grams.

Since 9100/455 = 20. The amount of bleaching powder required to disinfect 9100 litres of water = 6 x 20 = 120 grams.

Related Pearl: Horrock’s Apparatus

  • Horrock’s Apparatus is used to estimate the chlorine demand of water.
  • This is widely used in the disinfection of wells to find out how much bleaching powder is required.
  • Contents of this water-testing apparatus:
    • 6 white cups of 200 ml each and one black cup with a circular mark
    • 2 metal spoons (each holds 2g of bleaching powder)
    • 7 glass stirring rods and 1 special pipette
    • Two droppers
    • Starch-iodide indicator solution
  • Procedure:
    • Use 2g of bleaching powder to create a thin paste in the black cup. It is now called the Chlorine stock solution.
    • The six white cups are filled with the water to be tested
    • Add one drop of the stock solution to the 1st cup, two drops to the 2nd cup, three drops to the 3rd cup, and so on till adding six drops to the 6th cup.
    • Stir the cups and wait for half an hour.
    • Add 3 drops of starch-iodide indicator to each cup
    • Development of blue color in the apparatus indicates free residual chlorine. 
    • The first cup which develops this color gives an estimate of the amount of bleaching powder needed to disinfect 455 Litres of the sample water.
  • Chlorine demand or the dose of bleaching powder required is given by (n x 2) g for 455 liters of water, i.e., (n x 2) g of bleaching powder is required to disinfect 455 liters of water. Here, n represents the position of the cup (1, 2, 3, etc.) that was first to show a distinct blue color.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the triangle of doom?

choices.text: The apex is at the deep inguinal ring
Lateral border is formed by vas deferens
Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve is also a content

questions.solution:
Medial border of the triangle of doom is bounded by vas deferens.

The triangle of doom is bounded:

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection
  • Apex is at the deep inguinal ring

The contents of the triangle of doom include

  1. External iliac vessels
  2. Deep circumflex iliac vein
  3. Femoral nerve
  4. Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

Surgical importance of triangle of doom: Staples and sutures to fix the mesh in hernioplasty are avoided in this space , to avoid injury to the external iliac vessels and the femoral nerve.

Note:

Myopectineal orifice is an Osseo-Myo-aponeurotic tunnel. It is through this tunnel all groin hernias occur.

It is bounded:

  • Medially by the lateral border of the rectus sheath.
  • Above by the arched fibers of the internal oblique and transversus abdominis muscle.
  • Laterally by the iliopsoas muscle.
  • Below by the pectin pubis and fascia covering it.

Related Pearl: The Triangle of Doom

The triangle of doom is bounded

  • Medially by the vas deferens
  • Laterally by the vessels of the spermatic cord (gonadal vessels)
  • Inferiorly by peritoneal reflection

Apex oriented superiorly at internal ring.

The contents of the space include

  • External iliac vessels
  • Deep circumflex iliac vein
  • Genital branch of the genitofemoral nerve

questions.text: Which of the following conditions aggravates digoxin toxicity?
questions.solution:
Hypercalcemia aggravates digoxin toxicity.

Conditions aggravating digoxin toxicity:

  • Hypokalemia
  • Hypercalcemia
  • Hypomagnesemia
  • Hypernatremia
  • Inhibitors of P-glycoprotein: Amiodarone, quinidine, verapamil, diltiazem, cyclosporine, itraconazole, propafenone, and flecainide (they decrease digoxin clearance)
  • Drugs causing hypokalemia: Diuretics, corticosteroids, amphotericin B

Digoxin is a cardiac glycoside used to treat heart failure and control ventricular rate in atrial fibrillation/flutter.

It inhibits Na+/K+ ATPase, a membrane-bound transporter, thereby increasing the intracellular sodium levels. As a result, there is less expulsion of calcium from the cell by the sodium-calcium exchanger (NCX). Increased calcium inside the myocyte leads to an increase in cardiac contractility.

The most common cardiac manifestations of digitalis toxicity are ventricular tachycardia, partial-to-complete A-V block, severe bradycardia, and atrial fibrillation/flutter.

Adverse effects of digoxin:

  • Cardiovascular toxicity of digoxin includes extreme bradycardia, atrial fibrillation, and AV block, and in patients with structural heart disease, it can cause ventricular extrasystoles, bigeminy, ventricular tachycardia, and fibrillation.
  • GI toxicity includes anorexia, nausea, and vomiting.
  • It can cause headache, fatigue, and sleeplessness.
  • In the eye, it can cause altered color perception and halos.

Purified Fab fragments from ovine antidigoxin antisera (Digibind) are used as antidote for digoxin toxicity.

questions.text: Which layer of the cornea is affected in lattice corneal dystrophy?
questions.solution:
Stroma is affected in lattice corneal dystrophy.

The corneal dystrophies are a group of progressive, usually bilateral, variable corneal opacifying disorders, many of which are associated with decreased vision and discomfort. Based on layers of the cornea involved, they are classified into epithelial, Bowman layer, stroma, and Descemet membrane and endothelial dystrophies.

Lattice corneal dystrophy

Lattice dystrophy affects the stromal layer of the cornea. The classic form of lattice corneal dystrophy has an autosomal dominant inheritance and is caused due to a defect in the TGFB1 gene. It is characterized by the presence of recurrent corneal erosions at the end of the first decade of age. The blurring of vision usually occurs later. 

On examination, a fine filamentous lattice that spares the periphery can be seen. It is associated with generalized stromal haze and reduced corneal sensation.

Histopathology will show the deposition of amyloid. These deposits stain with congo red stain and exhibit green birefringence on a polarised microscope.

It is treated by penetrating or deep lamellar keratoplasty.

 

 

Other corneal dystrophies that affect stroma are:

  • Granular corneal dystrophy

 

  • Schnyder corneal dystrophy

 

  • Congenital stromal corneal dystrophy

 

  • Fleck corneal dystrophy
  • Francois central cloudy dystrophy
  • Macular corneal dystrophy
  • Posterior amorphous corneal dystrophy
  • Pre-Descemet corneal dystrophy.

Other images of corneal dystrophies which affect layers other than stroma

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the OPD with complaints of hesitancy, straining, and a poor stream of urine. He gives a history of pelvic injury one year back. What will be the investigation of choice for this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of urethral stricture due to trauma. The investigation of choice is retrograde urethrogram (RGU)

In RGU, the urethra is visualized with the instillation of contrast into the anterior urethra (penile urethra and bulbar urethra). It is helpful for diagnosing anterior urethral abnormalities.

The following image shows an RGU with bulbar urethral stricture:

The common causes of urethral stricture are:
 
Inflammatory Traumatic Iatrogenic
  • Urethritis
  • Balanitis xerotica obliterans (BXO)
  • Bulbar urethral injury
  • Pelvic fracture urethral disruption injury
  • Urethral instrumentation including catheterization and transurethral prostatectomy
  • Radical prostatectomy
  • Radiotherapy for prostate cancer

 

 

Clinical features include hesitancy of micturition, straining to void and a poor urinary stream. Diagnosis is made by uroflowmetry, urethroscopy, urethrography and ultrasound scanning. Retrograde cystourethrography is the investigation of choice.

The management of a urethral stricture depends on the site, the length, and the cause of the stricture. They include:

  • Endoscopic urethrotomy - The stricture is released using a knife passed through a rigid urethroscope.
  • Urethroplasty - Excision of the stenosed length of the urethra and re-anastomosis is done. A buccal mucosa graft can be used to bridge the gap. It is considered when a stricture is due to trauma or recurred following endoscopic treatment. 
  • Urethral dilation - The urethra is stretched using urethral dilators. This is a blind procedure and it can cause injury. Hence, it is not done frequently.
  • Intermittent self-dilatation - In patients with recurrent strictures who are unable to undergo urethroplasty, then intermittent self-dilatation with soft hydrophilic catheters is done on a daily basis.

In voiding cystourethrogram, after injecting contrast into the bladder using a Foleys catheter, the posterior urethra (membranous urethra and prostatic urethra) is visualized during micturition. It is the investigation of choice for vesicoureteric reflux (VUR) and posterior urethral valve.

questions.text: Which among the following statements is true regarding symmetric intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR)?

choices.text: It is caused by placental insufficiency
Insult on fetal growth occurs early

questions.solution:
The insult on fetal growth occurs at an early stage in symmetrical intrauterine growth restriction.

Asymmetric intrauterine growth restriction (IUGR) is associated with a brain-sparing effect, unlike symmetric IUGR, where there is no sparing of head growth.

IUGR is often classified as follows: 

Symmetric IUGR

Asymmetric IUGR
Insult on fetal growth occurs early, as a result, head circumference, length, and weight are equally affected. Insult occurs in late gestation, producing a relative sparing of head growth.
It is caused by genetic, chromosomal disorders, or TORCH infections. It is caused by placental insufficiency, pregnancy-induced hypertension, or maternal medical diseases.

 

Note: The Ponderal index can be used to determine the degree of fetal malnutrition. It is calculated as the ratio of body weight in grams to length in cm expressed as PI = [weight {in gram} × 100] ÷ length {in cm}³. The normal value of the ponderal index is 2-2.5. Ponderal index > 2 is suggestive of symmetrical IUGR whereas value < 2 is suggestive of asymmetrical IUGR.

questions.text: A 30-year-old diabetic man presented with the following lesions over his shins. The lesion had initially started off as small, firm brown papules which later enlarged to plaques and showed a positive Koebner's response. Which of the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lesions are highly pruritic and tender
Skin biopsy is indicated in all cases
Squamous cell carcinoma is a commonly seen complication

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of necrobiosis lipoidica. Ulceration is a common complication associated with this.

Necrobiosis lipoidica diabeticorum (NLD), a rare, chronic, granulomatous skin disorder commonly associated with diabetes mellitus. It is more frequently seen in females and is thought to be related to microangiopathy, where small blood vessels are damaged, leading to skin changes.

NLD typically starts as red or brown papules that progressively enlarge into well-demarcated patches or plaques. These lesions often have an atrophic, yellowish-brown center with elevated borders and can be slightly depressed in the middle. Most lesions are found on the shins (over the tibiae), but they can also occur elsewhere on the body. The lesions are generally asymptomatic but can become painful if ulceration occurs(Option B). Lesions may either resolve spontaneously or become chronic and persistent, increasing the risk of complications like ulceration.

NLD can often be diagnosed based on its clinical appearance alone, and a skin biopsy is typically not necessary unless the presentation is atypical or there is concern about other conditions. (Option C)

Common complications include ulceration especially in long standing lesions. It usually occurs later in the disease course and is often triggered by trauma. Squamous Cell Carcinoma can occur in chronic non healing ulcer but it is a rare complication. (Option D)

Treatment is usually not required for most cases. However, if lesions are bothersome, treatment options include topical steroids, topical tacrolimus, or PUVA therapy (psoralen plus ultraviolet A), although the effectiveness of these treatments is variable.

questions.text: A 20-year-old patient is admitted to the emergency department due to breathlessness and hypotension after blunt trauma to the chest. Which of the following is an ECG finding of the condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points to a case of cardiac tamponade, and ECG 1 shows electrical alternans (alternating amplitude of QRS complexes).

Electric alternans is a specific finding caused by the anteroposterior swinging of the heart with each contraction. When the heart is nearer to the chest wall, it leads to an increased amplitude deflection on the ECG, whereas a lower amplitude deflection is seen when the heart moves away from the chest wall.

Cardiac tamponade is characterised by the accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space, leading to impairment of diastolic relaxation of the cardiac chambers. This leads to a decline in cardiac output.

Clinical presentation: 

  • Acute cardiac tamponade - Within minutes, due to trauma, rupture of the heart or aorta, or as a complication of an invasive diagnostic or therapeutic procedure. Presents as cardiogenic shock.
  • Subacute cardiac tamponade - occurs over days to weeks and can be associated with neoplastic, uremic, or idiopathic pericarditis. Symptoms include dyspnea, chest discomfort or fullness, peripheral oedema, and fatigue.

The characteristic signs of cardiac tamponade include:

  • Tachycardia and hypotension
  • Pericardial rub
  • Pulsus paradoxus - this is a paradoxical reduction in the systemic blood pressure (>10 mm Hg) on inspiration. In tamponade, with an increase in venous return to the right side (during inspiration) of the heart, the interventricular septum bows towards the left ventricle (fixed total heart volume), thereby reducing left heart volume. This leads to a reduction in stroke volume and systemic blood pressure.
  • Beck's triad - this is a triad of findings in tamponade that consists of hypotension, muffled heart sounds, and elevated jugular venous pressure with prominent x descent and absent y descent

The echocardiography shows a swinging heart sign, which is characteristic of cardiac tamponade. The pericardial pressures exceed the left ventricular diastolic filling pressures, causing the collapse of heart chambers, IVC plethora, and respiratory variation in volumes and flows.

In a patient with clinical features suggestive of tamponade, the best course of action is performing pericardiocentesis, preferably carried out under echocardiographic guidance. Definitive management includes emergency thoracotomy or sternotomy. In cases of recurrent tamponade, a small catheter may be left in place to drain subsequent collections of fluid. 

Other options:

Option B: ECG shows the absence of P waves pointing towards Atrial Fibrillation. There is rapid and irregular atrial activation, which is transmitted through the atrioventricular node. The conducted ventricular rate is usually rapid and irregularly irregular. It can vary from 110-160 beats/minute.

Option C: ECG showing narrow QRS complexes without P waves and pseudo R waves in aVR lead suggests paroxysmal supraventricular tachycardia (PSVT). It is a regular, narrow QRS complex tachycardia, most often caused by an atrioventricular nodal re-entrant circuit.

Option D: The ECG shows ST-elevation in the high lateral leads (I and aVL) and V5 and V6. In addition, there is reciprocal ST depression in the inferior leads (III and aVF), with associated ST depression in V1, V2, and V3, all in favour of lateral wall myocardial infarction.

Related Pearl: JVP waveform and the abnormalities

1) The a-wave corresponds to atrial contraction.

Abnormality Conditions
Prominent a-waves Pulmonary hypertension, right atrial thrombus/ mass, and tricuspid stenosis
Cannon a-waves

Complete AV block, ventricular tachycardia, and premature atrial/ junctional/ ventricular beats
Absent a-waves Atrial fibrillation

 

2) The c-wave corresponds to the bulging of tricuspid valve into right atrium during ventricular contraction.

 

3) The x-descent corresponds to atrial relaxation during atrial diastole.

Abnormality Conditions
Absent x-descent Severe tricuspid regurgitation
Rapid x-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

4) The v-wave corresponds to the venous filling of right atrium.

Abnormality Conditions
Dominant v-waves Tricuspid regurgitation

 

5) The y-descent corresponds to the passive emptying of the right atrium into right ventricle.

Abnormality Conditions
Prolonged y-descent Tricuspid stenosis
Rapid y-descent

Constrictive pericarditis and isolated severe tricuspid regurgitation
Absent y-descent Cardiac tamponade

 

Related Pearl: Causes of Pulsus Paradoxus

Physiological causes

Obesity

Pregnancy

Cardiovascular causes

Cardiac tamponade – most common cause

Constrictive pericarditis ( in 1/3rd cases )

Massive pulmonary embolism

Severe CCF

Hypovolemic shock

Respiratory causes

Severe obstructive lung disease

Acute severe asthma

Severe emphysema

Tension pneumothorax

questions.text: Individual variability in nutrient requirements considers the distribution of needs within a population, establishing a safe level to cover 97.5% of individuals. This principle does not apply to which of the following?
questions.solution:
The concept of individual variability in nutrient requirements defines the Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) to cover 97.5% of individuals in a population. This principle applies to all nutrients except for energy.

The RDA reflects the variability in nutrient requirements among individuals within a population. It is based on the assumption that nutrient needs follow a normal distribution, meaning that the RDA is set to cover approximately 97.5% of individuals. This corresponds to the mean +2 SD, indicating a safe nutrient intake level. For energy, however, both excessive and inadequate intake can pose risks, making the approach different from that used for other nutrients.

Bioavailability is crucial in determining how much of a nutrient must be consumed to meet dietary needs. It involves the release of the nutrient from food, its absorption in the intestines, and the body’s response to it. For certain nutrients, such as iron, the dietary intake may need to be significantly higher than the actual requirement due to low bioavailability, particularly in cereal-based diets. While the RDA indicates the level needed to meet most individuals' requirements, it should not be used as a strict benchmark for individual assessment, especially if other nutrient intakes are inadequate.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient presented with myocardial infarction and was planned for urgent percutaneous coronary intervention. Bivalirudin was used as an anticoagulant in this patient. Which of the following statements is true about the drug used?

choices.text: It is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor
Antidote of bivalirudin toxicity is protamine
No dose adjustments required in renal failure patients
It is contraindicated in heparin induced thrombocytopenia

questions.solution:
Bivalirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor administered only parenterally. 

It is a synthetic polypeptide that can be used in patients undergoing PCI (percutaneous coronary intervention) or coronary bypass surgery for STEMI and NSTEMI as an anticoagulant along with antiplatelet drugs like aspirin. It is a specific, reversible direct thrombin inhibitor with quick onset and short-lasting anticoagulant action. It is administered intravenously. Bleeding is an important adverse effect of this drug.

Protamine does not antagonize bivalirudin's action, and there is no specific antidote to it (option B). Bivalirudin undergoes renal excretion and proteolysis, and thus, dose adjustments may be needed in patients with renal impairment (option C). It is often indicated in the treatment of heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT) (option D).

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: A 21-year-old female patient who is known to have Bell's palsy presented with dryness in her left eye. Ocular examination reveals mild punctate epithelial defects and dryness of the cornea. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient with clinical features of dry eye and unilateral facial nerve palsy likely has a diagnosis of exposure keratopathy. 

Exposure keratopathy is the drying of the cornea despite normally produced tears. It occurs due to incomplete eyelid closure, also known as lagophthalmos.

Lagophthalmos can be caused by conditions such as facial nerve palsy, parkinsonism (reduced muscle tone), lid scarring, and proptosis. 

Clinical features include dry eyes, symptoms and signs of mild punctate epithelial changes and epithelial breakdown. 

Treatment depends on whether the exposure is reversible or permanent. Reversible exposure can be treated with artificial tears and eye ointments. The eyelid can be taped closed at night or external barriers like bandage silicone hydrogel or scleral contact lenses can be used. Permanent exposure requires permanent tarsorrhaphy. For facial nerve palsy, a gold weight can be inserted into the upper eyelid.  

Other options: 

Option B - Neurotrophic keratopathy is the loss/reduction of corneal sensation that occurs due to loss of innervation by the trigeminal nerve. It may be due to stroke, trigeminal ganglion ablation for neuralgia, diabetes, etc. 

Option C - Mooren ulcer is an autoimmune disorder that results in progressive peripheral corneal ulceration. This is characterized by severe pain and the involvement of the superficial one-third of the corneal stroma.

Option D - Herpes simplex keratitis is caused by the Herpes simplex virus (HSV). The patient complains of ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis. 

The below image shows the characteristic dendritic ulcers of herpes simplex keratitis-

Related Pearl: Ocular lesions of Herpes Simplex

  • Cornea
    • Fine epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Coarse epithelial punctate keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
  • Conjunctiva: acute follicular conjunctivitis
  • Skin lesions

Recurrent herpes:

  • Active epithelial keratitis
    • Punctate epithelial keratitis
    • Dendritic ulcer
    • Geographical ulcer
  • Stromal keratitis
  • Disciform keratitis
  • Diffuse stromal necrotic keratitis
  • Trophic keratitis (meta-herpetic)
  • Herpetic iridocyclitis

questions.text: A 7-year-old child came with complaints of recurrent nosebleeds. On further investigations, it is found that the patient is suspected to have Glanzman’s thrombasthenia. What is the single best lab test that can be used to differentiate it from other platelet disorders?
questions.solution:
The platelet aggregation test is abnormal only in Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, making it the key diagnostic tool for differentiating it from other platelet and coagulation disorders.

Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of Glycoprotein IIb/IIIa, an integrin that allows platelets to bind to fibrinogen, facilitating platelet aggregation. As a result, platelets fail to aggregate in response to agonists like Adenosine Diphosphate (ADP), leading to defective clot formation and severe bleeding. Despite this, coagulation tests such as Prothrombin Time (PT), Partial Thromboplastin Time (PTT), and platelet counts are normal, except for a prolonged bleeding time.

Another platelet disorder, Bernard-Soulier syndrome, results from a deficiency in the Glycoprotein Ib-IX complex and impairs platelet adhesion. Like Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, Bernard-Soulier syndrome shows a prolonged bleeding time with normal coagulation test results. However, the platelet aggregation test is normal in Bernard-Soulier syndrome, as this disorder affects platelet adhesion rather than aggregation.

The Ristocetin aggregation test is used to diagnose von Willebrand disease and Bernard-Soulier syndrome, where aggregation in response to ristocetin is absent. In Glanzmann’s thrombasthenia, however, platelets aggregate normally with ristocetin but show defective aggregation with other agonists like ADP and collagen. (Option A)

In Bernard-Soulier syndrome, the defect lies in the Glycoprotein Ib-IX receptor, while in von Willebrand disease, the defect is due to abnormal or deficient von Willebrand factor (vWF).

questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding indicators used to measure the various fluid compartment volumes?

choices.text: Tritium oxide for total body water

questions.solution:
125I-albumin is used to measure plasma volume by indicator-dilution method, not total blood volume.

In an indicator-dilution method, an appropriate indicator is first placed in the fluid compartment, whose volume has to be measured. Once the indicator is evenly distributed throughout the fluid in the compartment, analyzing the amount of the indicator that becomes diluted helps assess the volume of the corresponding fluid compartment.

125Iodine-albumin and Evan's blue dye can also be used to measure the plasma volume. Whereas, total blood volume can be measured using an indicator substance like 51Chromium labelled red blood cells.

Total blood volume can also be calculated after measuring hematocrit using the equation:

Total blood volume = Plasma volume / 1- hematocrit

Note- Blood volume refers to the total amount of fluid circulating within the arteries, capillaries, veins, venules, and chambers of the heart at any time and includes RBCs, WBCs, platelets and plasma. Plasma volume is a component of the total blood volume and accounts for around 60% of the total blood volume
