questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding emergency contraception?

choices.text: Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose can be used for emergency contraception
Ulipristal 3 mg can be used for emergency contraception

questions.solution:
Ulipristal 30 mg taken within 5 days is used for emergency contraception.

Ulipristal is a synthetic progesterone hormone receptor modulator. It attaches to the progesterone receptor and prevents/delays ovulation, and suppresses the endometrium thereby preventing implantation.

Emergency contraceptives act by various methods. They can make the endometrium unsuitable for implantation. They can also delay or inhibit ovulation or prevent fertilization by altering the tubal transport of sperm and/or ova.

Levonorgestrel 1.5 mg single dose can be used for emergency contraception. Alternatively, levonorgestrel 0.75 mg one tablet can be taken within 72 h of unprotected intercourse and another 12 h later.

questions.text: A 25-year-old pregnant woman presents with complaints of easy fatiguability. Her blood examination showed mild anemia with target cells. Hemoglobin electrophoresis showed HbA2 levels of 6% with normal HbF and the Mentzer index was 6. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is β Thalassemia minor.

The presence of mild anemia, peripheral smear showing target cells with 6% HbA2, and normal HbF, with a Mentzer index of 6 indicate that this is a case of thalassemia minor.

β Thalassemia minor is a clinical syndrome caused due to heterozygous expression of one normal (β) gene and one abnormal β-thalassemia(β0/+) gene. It can either be present as β+/β or as β0/β. This occurs due to point mutations of the β thalassemia gene on chromosome 11. The predominant mechanisms are:

  • Splicing mutations are the most common cause of β+ thalassemia
  • Promoter region mutations are associated with β+ thalassemia
  • Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause of β0 thalassemia.

These mutations cause a diminished synthesis of β globin chains leading to anemia by decreased synthesis of normal HbA (α2β2) and decreased survival of red cells and their precursors due to imbalance in α and β globin synthesis and elevated γ and δ chain synthesis leading to increased HbF and HbA2 respectively.

β Thalassemia minor is more common clinically than other forms. These patients are usually asymptomatic or present with symptoms of mild anemia. Peripheral blood smear typically shows hypochromic, microcytic red cells with basophilic stippling, and target cells as shown in the image.

Diagnosis is confirmed by hemoglobin electrophoresis that reveals typical raised levels of HbA2 (α2δ2) ranging between 4-8% with normal HbF (α2γ2) levels. The Mentzer index of <12 is seen in thalassemia minor syndrome.

Thalassemia minor seldom requires treatment and if indicated is usually in patients after surgery, following childbirth, or to manage complications. Blood transfusions are the preferred modality of treatment.

β Thalassemia major (option C) is a clinical syndrome caused due to homozygous expression of abnormal abnormal β-thalassemia genes in the form of β+/β+, β+/β0, or β0/β0. The etiology is similar as described above. There is the complete absence or only minimal synthesis of the β globin chain. The predominant type of hemoglobin is HbF with very low HbA and normal to mildly increased HbA2.

Blood smears show severe red cell abnormalities, including marked anisocytosis and poikilocytosis, microcytosis, and hypochromia. Target cells, basophilic stippling, and fragmented red cells also are common. The reticulocyte count is elevated. A radiographic image of the skull shows the classic 'crew cut' appearance.

The patients usually present with severe transfusion-dependent anemia and do not survive without them. Extramedullary hematopoiesis leads to hepatosplenomegaly and enlarged and distorted bony prominences over the face leading to the characteristic 'chipmunk facies.'

β-thalassemia intermedia is a third genetically heterogeneous β-thalassemia variant of moderate severity. This category includes milder variants of β+/β+ or β+/β0-thalassemia. The Mentzer index is 12-14 in thalassemia intermedia.

Other options:

Option A - Iron deficiency anemia is the most common cause of microcytic anemia. It is characterized by the presence of microcytic hypochromic red cells with pencil cells. It can be differentiated from β Thalassemia minor by examining the blood smear and serum levels of iron, total iron-binding capacity, and serum ferritin. A definitive differentiation can be made in the favour of iron deficiency anemia when the Mentzer index is >14. 

Option B - α Thalassemia trait is caused by the deletion of two α-globin genes from a single chromosome (α/α,−/−) or the deletion of one α-globin gene from each of the two chromosomes (α/−, α/−). Patients present with symptoms similar to β thalassemia minor but there are normal or low HbA2 levels.

Note:

Mentzer index is defined as mean corpuscular volume per red cell count, i.e. MCV/RBC count. It is used to differentiate between iron deficiency anemia and thalassemia trait as follows:

  • >14: Iron deficiency anemia
  • 12-14: Intermediate
  • <12 Thalassemia trait 

Related Pearl: Thalassemia syndromes

Normally each individual carries 4 functional alpha chain genes and 2 functional beta chain genes. Alpha and beta-thalassemia are inherited disorders in which there is reduced production of alpha-globin or beta-globin chains, respectively.

  • Alpha thalassemia: Gene deletion is the most common cause of reduced α-chain synthesis.
  • Beta +- thalassemia: The most common cause is splicing mutation.
  • Beta 0- thalassemia: Chain terminator mutations are the most common cause.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is diagnosed with hypertension. He is currently on lithium therapy for bipolar disorder. Which antihypertensive can be prescribed for this patient?
questions.solution:
The drug atenolol would be the preferred antihypertensive in this patient with concomitant usage of Lithium for bipolar disorder as the other drugs can precipitate lithium toxicity.

Lithium toxicity occurs with concomitant use of 

  1. Thiazide diuretics(chlorthalidone) (Option A)
  2. Angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitors (Lisinopril) (Option B)
  3. Angiotensin II receptor blocker (Losartan) (Option D)
  4. Nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (indomethacin)
  5. Tetracyclines (doxycycline)
  6. Loop diuretics (furosemide)

These act by increasing the tubular reabsorption of lithium, resulting in decreased excretion of lithium and thereby increasing the serum lithium levels, causing toxicity.

Lithium toxicity: 

Serum lithium level greater than 1.5 mEq/L are considered toxic. Acute intoxication is characterized by vomiting, profuse diarrhea, coarse tremor, ataxia, dysarthria, and convulsions. It may progress to cardiac arrhythmias, coma, and death.

Treatment is supportive which includes dialysis, continuous cardiac monitoring, intubation if needed.

Adverse effects of Lithium:

Central nervous system: Lithium at therapeutic levels cause fine tremors and at toxic levels cause coarse tremors. Incoordination, ataxia, and slurred speech can occur at peak serum concentrations.

Lithium enters into the distal tubular cells in kidney via luminal ENaC. However, it accumulates in the distal tubular cells due to the inability of Na+K+ATPase to secrete lithium via basal membrane. Thereby, lithium inhibits GSK-3ß, leading to vasopressin insensitivity, downregulation of aquaporin-2 channels, and nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients present with polyuria and polydipsia. Amiloride blocks entry of lithium into renal distal tubule ENaCs and is used to treat lithium induced nephrogenic diabetes insipidus.

Lithium therapy is associated with hypothyroidism and hypercalcemia related to hyperparathyroidism. Lithium therapy causes significant weight gain.

T wave flattening in ECG occurs in few patients on lithium. At toxic levels, sinus bradycardia, AV block, and cardiac arrhythmias occur. Allergic reactions including dermatitis, folliculitis, and vasculitis can occur with lithium use.

Lithium use in early pregnancy causes Ebstein anomaly in the fetus. Fetal lithium exposure is associated with neonatal goiter, CNS depression, hypotonia (floppy baby syndrome), and cardiac murmur.

Due to all these adverse effects, patients on lithium therapy should have routine monitoring of serum electrolytes, serum calcium, thyroid profile, renal function tests, ECG, and serum lithium levels.

Related Pearl: Lithium in bipolar disorder

Guidelines for Lithium therapy
Indications:
Mania, hypomania, bipolar disorder, etc.

Blood levels of lithium:

For therapeutic purpose (treatment of acute mania) : 0.8-1.2 mEq/L

For prophylaxis (to prevent relapse of bipolar disorder): 0.5-0.8 mEq/L

Toxic levels of lithium: >/= 1.5 mEq/L
Contraindications:
  • CKD
  • Heart disease
  • Hyponatremia or diuretic use
Baseline studies:
  • BUN (Blood Urea Nitrogen), Creatinine, Calcium, Urine analysis
  • Thyroid function test
  • ECG in patients with coronary risk factors
Acute adverse effects:
  • Tremor, ataxia, weakness
  • Polyuria, polydipsia
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Cognitive impairment
Chronic adverse effects:
  • Nephrogenic diabetes insipidus
  • Thyroid dysfunction
  • Hyperparathyroidism

questions.text: A female patient comes to the OPD with complaints of  passage of blood instead of urine at night. She is found to have a mutation of the PIGA gene. Her lab investigations include a Ham test. What does this test detect?

choices.text: Lysis of RBCS in alkaline pH
Lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH

questions.solution:
The given history of passage of blood instead of urine at night and mutation of the PIGA gene points towards a likely diagnosis of paroxysmal nocturnal hemoglobinuria (PNH). Ham test or acidified serum lysis test detects lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation. 

PNH is a chronic acquired hemolytic anemia that occurs due to mutations in the phosphatidylinositol glycan complementation group A (PIGA) gene. PIGA is an enzyme that is essential for the synthesis of certain membrane-associated complement regulatory proteins.

Thus, PNH blood cells are deficient in three glycosylphosphatidylinositols (GPI) linked proteins that regulate complement activity:

  • Decay accelerating factors or CD55
  • Membrane inhibitor of reactive lysis or CD59
  • C8 binding protein

Clinically, the patient would have hemolysis, pancytopenia, and a tendency for venous thrombosis. Intravascular hemolysis may be nocturnal and paroxysmal or chronic hemolysis without the dramatic hemoglobinuria. Some patients may complain of recurrent attacks of abdominal pain that may be related to thrombosis in abdominal veins. Investigations show iron deficiency anemia (due to chronic hemoglobinuria), and elevated LDH levels (Option A).

The gold standard for the diagnosis of PNH is flow cytometry. It provides a sensitive means for detecting red cells that are deficient in GPI-linked proteins such as CD59.

Investigations in PNH include:

  • Flow cytometry (gold standard) - deficiency of CD59 and CD55
  • Ham test (acidified serum lysis) - lysis of RBCs in a mildly acidic pH due to complement fixation
  • Bone marrow biopsy -
    • Hypercellularity with erythroid hyperplasia is seen in classical presentations
    • Patients who develop pancytopenia will have hypocellular bone marrow
  • Imaging - to evaluate venous thrombosis 

Eculizumab is used in treatment. It is a monoclonal antibody that prevents the conversion of the complement C5 to C5a.

questions.text: A female patient on medication for recurrent muscle pain presents with hematuria and flank pain. Investigations revealed a shrunken kidney with papillary necrosis and calcification. Which of the following drugs was she most likely on?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the findings of papillary calcifications and necrosis is suggestive of analgesic nephropathy. The patient was most likely on phenacetin-aspirin-caffeine.

Analgesic nephropathy is a renal disease characterized by tubulointerstitial nephritis and renal papillary necrosis. It occurs due to excessive prolonged use of a combination of analgesics, especially phenacetin-aspirin-caffeine. Paracetamol is another drug that is implicated. It is more common in women and a history of chronic headaches, arthralgias, and abdominal pain which necessitated the chronic use is usually present. 

Flank pain with or without hematuria might indicate a ureteral obstruction due to the sloughed papilla secondary to necrosis. It increases the risk for urinary tract malignancies. 

NSAIDs are a group of drugs with analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antipyretic properties. The effects are exerted by blocking the synthesis of prostaglandins. The COX-1 and COX-2 enzymes are inhibited. These enzymes are the first steps in the production of prostanoids, thromboxane A2, and other prostaglandins.

Other side effects of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDS) include agranulocytosis, cystitis, hematuria, thrombosis, and dyspepsia.  

Other options:

Options A and C: Both cyclosporine and tacrolimus are calcineurin inhibitors (CNI), used as immunosuppressants that can cause CNI nephrotoxicity. Acute kidney injury can be due to thrombotic microangiopathy or toxic tubulopathy. Chronic CNI nephrotoxicity is seen commonly in transplant patients. It presents with a decline in glomerular filtration rate, hypertension, and hyperkalemia.

Option D: Lithium, commonly used in manic-depressive disorders can lead to nephrogenic diabetes insipidus. Patients present with polyuria and polydipsia. Rarely, it can cause tubulointerstitial nephritis.

questions.text:
A 20-year-old medical student presented with 6 months of generalized body ache, which increases with stress and does not respond to NSAIDs. She also complains of sleep disturbances and low mood. On examination, there is increased pain sensitivity and tender bony prominences. Investigations are given below. The most probable diagnosis is:
  • Routine blood and urine- normal
  • ESR- normal
  • anti-CCP- normal
  • Viral markers-  IgG against HbsAg +
  • Chest and pelvic X-ray- normal
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis for the given clinical scenario is fibromyalgia.

The examination findings of tender bony prominences and increased pain sensitivity with associated low mood favour the diagnosis of fibromyalgia. Flaring up symptoms during stress and not having pain relief with NSAIDs also support the diagnosis of fibromyalgia.

Fibromyalgia is a diagnosis of exclusion. Other possible conditions like anemia, TB, infections like UTI, rheumatoid arthritis, etc. have to be excluded.

Fibromyalgia is characterized by chronic musculoskeletal pain and tenderness. It is more common in females. Patients with fibromyalgia have an increased prevalence of other syndromes associated with pain and fatigue, including chronic fatigue syndrome, chronic headaches, irritable bowel syndrome, interstitial cystitis/painful bladder syndrome, and other pelvic pain syndromes.

Treatment strategies include physical conditioning, strength training, exercise programs, and cognitive-behavioral strategies

Other options: 

Option A: Normal levels of ESR and anti-CCP antibodies (Anti-cyclic citrullinated peptide) exclude the diagnosis of rheumatoid arthritis.

Option B: Ankylosing spondylitis improves with exercise, unlike this case. Moreover, it might show sacroiliitis on the pelvic radiographs and responds well to NSAIDs. 

Option C: Hepatitis B infection is included in the differential diagnosis of fibromyalgia but the presence of IgG against HbsAg points towards vaccination rather than active infection which would show IgM antibodies against various antigens of Hep B.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding the reflex depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts the inverse stretch reflex and it can be stimulated by a passive stretch as well as an active contraction (Option D).

When the tension in the muscle increases and surpasses a limit, contraction suddenly ceases and the muscle relaxes. This relaxation in response to an overt stretch is called the inverse stretch reflex.

The receptor involved in this reflex is the Golgi tendon organ (Option B). The Golgi tendon organ consists of a net-like collection of nerve endings that are arranged in series (Option C) within the muscle fibers. This arrangement allows for Golgi tendon organs to be stimulated by both active contraction and passive stretch of the muscle, unlike muscle spindles. One Golgi tendon organ innervates 3-25 muscle fibers. 

The afferents from the Golgi tendon organ are the Ib myelinated nerve fibers. The Ib nerve fibers synapse with inhibitory interneurons present in the spinal cord, which in turn synapse with the motor neurons supplying the muscles. Thus, this is a disynaptic reflex (Option A).

questions.text: All of the following muscles are paralysed in injury to median nerve at the hand except?
questions.solution:
Adductor pollicis is supplied by the ulnar nerve, hence, it is not paralyzed in injury to the median nerve at the hand.

Median Nerve in the hand supplies lateral two lumbricals and thenar muscles which include abductor pollicis brevis, flexor pollicis brevis, and opponens pollicis. Cutaneous nerve supply of the median nerve at hand is over the lateral 3 1/2  digits and their nail beds.

Paralysis of the thenar muscles presents as ape or monkey-like thumb deformity.

questions.text: A 32-year-old man presented with acute dyspnea, tachypnea, and high grade fever. His SpO2 was 88%. His chest X-ray findings are shown below. Which of the following is less likely to be considered as a differential?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario, along with the chest X-ray finding, is suggestive of acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS), and tuberculosis is less likely to be a causative disease.

Acute respiratory distress syndrome is a clinical syndrome characterised by acute onset, severe dyspnea, tachypnea, hypoxemia, and pulmonary infiltrates leading to respiratory failure. Etiological factors can be divided into direct and indirect causes of lung injury as follows:

  • Direct lung injury-
    • Pneumonia
    • Aspiration of gastric contents
    • Near drowning
    • Toxic inhalation injury
    • Pulmonary contusion.
    • COVID-19
  • Indirect lung injury-
    • Sepsis
    • Severe trauma like burns, flail chest, pulmonary contusions, head trauma, multiple bone fractures
    • Transfusions
    • Drug overdose
    • Multiple transfusions
    • Pancreatitis
    • Drug overdose.

There are three stages in the development of ARDS:

  1. Exudative phase: Occurs for the first seven days of the illness. The alveolar-capillary endothelial cells and type I pneumocytes are injured, with a breach in the tight alveolar barrier. Proinflammatory cytokines like IL-8, IL-1, TNF-α, and LT-B4 lead to the recruitment of neutrophils and the development of a hyaline membrane in the alveoli.
  2. Proliferative phase: Occurs from day 7-21. Recovery from mechanical ventilation is seen in most patients. Some patients may develop pulmonary fibrosis in this stage. Histological recovery is seen in this phase with a shift to lymphocyte-predominant infiltrates. Type II pneumocytes proliferate and secrete surfactant with subsequent differentiation to Type I pneumocytes.
  3. Fibrotic phase: Is associated with increased mortality. Extensive alveolar duct and interstitial fibrosis are seen.

Chest X-ray features in ARDS:

Chest x-ray features usually develop 12-24 hours after initial lung insult due to proteinaceous interstitial oedema. A hyaline membrane occurs within one week due to type 1 pneumocyte damage. There are diffuse bilateral coalescent opacities consistent with pulmonary oedema. 

Severity classification of ARDS:

  • Mild: 200 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 300 mmHg
  • Moderate: 100 mmHg < Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 200 mmHg
  • Severe: Pao2/Fio2 ≤ 100 mmHg

Management:

  • Mechanical ventilation with low tidal volume and high PEEP.
  • Prone ventilation
  • Extracorporeal membrane oxygenation
  • Early neuromuscular blockade

Tuberculosis commonly causes respiratory failure in patients with extensive pulmonary parenchymal involvement, but it is an infrequent cause of ARDS.

questions.text: The patterns of the structures on the palate shown below can be used to determine a person's identity. This study is known as:
questions.solution:
Rugoscopy/palatoprint involves the study of rugae in the anterior part of the hard palate which are specific to an individual and permanent.

They are used in the same way as fingerprints and have been classified as :

1) primary rugae - > 5mm

2) secondary rugae - 3-5mm

3) fragmented rugae - 2-3mm 

Methods of identification using different prints:

Cheiloscopy - evaluation of lip prints (Option B)

Ridgeology - evaluation of friction ridges on fingerprints (Option C)

Poroscopy - evaluation of sweat pore openings on fingerprint ridges (Option D)

Podography - evaluation of footprints

Dactylography - evaluation of fingerprints

Edgeoscopy is a method of identification through the examination of the unique details and characteristics found along the edges of individual fingerprint ridges.

questions.text: An 8-year-old  child is brought with complaints of pain in the neck and right shoulder with a restricted range of motion. He also experiences difficulty walking. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical history of a child with pain in the neck and right shoulder with a restricted range of motion and difficulty in walking with the clinical image showing winging of the right scapula suggests a diagnosis of facioscapulohumeral dystrophy. 

Facioscapulohumeral dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder with weakness of facial and shoulder girdle muscles as the earliest and most severe manifestation. Facial weakness causes rounded and puckered lips and the inability to close eyes while sleeping. Scapular winging is a prominent feature even in infants. There is flattening of the deltoid contour and wasting of the triceps and biceps. There is gradual weakness of muscles of the hip girdle and thighs, which eventually undergo atrophy, leading to Gower's sign and Trendelenburg gait. Lumbar lordosis and kyphoscoliosis are common complications.

Other options:

Option B- Long thoracic nerve palsy can cause scapular winging, most- commonly medial winging, due to traumatic injuries and nontraumatic events due to dysfunction of the serratus anterior.

Option C- Klippel Feil syndrome consists of a triad of low posterior hairline, short neck and decreased cervical range of motion.

Option D-Subacute combined degeneration (SACD) is due to the deficiency of vitamin B12. Pernicious anemia, partial gastrectomy, and Diphyllobothrium latum infestation can lead to this condition. The most severely affected regions in SACD are the posterior columns at the cervical and upper thoracic levels as well as the lateral corticospinal tracts and the cerebral cortex.

questions.text: A 42-year-old patient presents with pulsatile tinnitus, which disappears temporarily with pressure over the left carotid.  Otoscopy reveals a reddish blue mass behind an intact tympanic membrane, suggestive of a glomus tumor. On increasing the ear canal pressure with a Siegel's speculum, which of the following is likely to occur?

choices.text: Patient complains of vertigo and develops nystagmus towards affected ear
Patient complains of vertigo and develops nystagmus towards normal ear
Tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches

questions.solution:
On increasing the ear canal pressure with a Siegel's speculum in a patient with a glomus tumor, the tumor pulsates vigorously and then blanches. This is known as the pulsation sign/ brown sign.

Glomus tumors are the most common benign tumors of the middle ear. The tumors comprise paraganglionic cells and arise from glomus bodies which resemble carotid bodies. Glomus bodies are present in the dome of the jugular bulb and on the promontory along the course of the tympanic branch of the IX cranial nerve. 

They are most commonly seen in females between the ages of 40-50 years. They are very slow-growing, thus it may take years before changes in symptoms are appreciated. It follows the rule of 10s - 10% are familial, 10% are multicentric, and 10% are functional (secrete catecholamines).

Depending on the area from which it arises, glomus tumors are classified into two types: 

  • Glomus jugulare, arising from the dome of the jugular bulb
  • Glomus tympanicum, arising from the promontory of the middle ear

The presentation of glomus tumors is as follows:

  • Intratympanic presentation
    • Progressive hearing loss
    • Pulsatile tinnitus is synchronous with pulse and can be stopped by carotid pressure
    • Otoscopy: red reflex through the intact tympanic membrane
    • Rising sign when tumor arises from the floor of the middle ear
    • Pulsation or Brown sign: when the ear canal pressure is raised with Siegel's speculum the tumor pulsates and blanches. This reverses when pressure is released.
  • Polyp presentation
    • Profuse bleeding
    • Otorrhea if there is a secondary infection
    • Red vascular polyp filling the meatus that bleeds easily
  • Cranial nerve palsies
    • Dysphagia and hoarseness with unilateral paralysis of the soft palate, and pharynx due to IX and X
    • Vocal cord paralysis due to X
    • Weakness of the trapezius and sternomastoid muscles XI
    • Atrophy of half of the tongue XII
  • Audible bruit over the mastoid

They can be diagnosed by CT scan, MRI, four-vessel angiography, brain perfusion and flow studies, embolization, and biopsy. It is treated by surgery, radiation, embolization, or a combination of them. 

Siegel’s speculum examination in patients with labyrinthine fistula would result in patients complaining of vertigo and developing nystagmus. The quick component of nystagmus would be towards the affected ear in serous labyrinthitis and towards the normal ear in purulent labyrinthitis.

questions.text: A 51-year-old man who is a smoker for the past 2 decades is diagnosed with lung carcinoma. The tumor is located in the periphery of the lung and CT-guided biopsy reveals the following histopathology. Markers such as synaptophysin and CD56 are positive. Which of the following is not classically seen in this patient?

choices.text: Immunohistochemistry showing high levels of  BCL2 protein
Hyponatremia  due to inappropriate ADH secretion can be seen
Preinvasive phase is commonly seen in major bronchi
Cushing Syndrome due to ACTH production can be seen

questions.solution:
There is no known preinvasive phase seen in small cell carcinoma of the lung. This patient's clinical features and the histological image showing the basophilic staining of the vessel wall (Azzopardi effect) are suggestive of a small cell carcinoma of the lung.

Chromogranin, synaptophysin, and CD56 are the markers for small cell lung carcinoma.

Paraneoplastic syndromes associated with small cell carcinoma of the lung are Cushing Syndrome due to ACTH production and hyponatremia due to inappropriate ADH secretion.A majority of small-cell carcinomas (90%) show high levels of antiapoptotic BCL2 protein on Immunohistochemistry.

This tumor originates from neuroendocrine progenitor cells (Kulchitsky cells), which are present in the lining bronchial epithelium.

Histology of small cell lung carcinoma shows clusters of small cells with scant cytoplasm, ill-defined cell borders, finely granular nuclear chromatin (salt and pepper pattern), and absent or inconspicuous nucleoli. The cells are round, oval, or spindle-shaped, and nuclear molding is prominent.

questions.text: A 12 year-old-boy, who is a known case of atopic dermatitis, went to play in a nearby farm after which he developed runny nose and sneezing. His symptoms subsided after he came back home. But he developed the same symptoms again on the next day even without going to the farm. These symptoms occurring on the next day are chiefly mediated by:
questions.solution:
The given scenario describes pollen allergy. The symptoms occurring on the next day point to late phase reaction that is chiefly mediated by eosinophils.

The development of symptoms again without a second exposure to the allergen is known as the late phase reaction of allergic response. This is chiefly mediated by leukocyte infiltration into the tissues, especially the eosinophils. 

Allergic response/ type 1 hypersensitivity usually develops within minutes of exposure to the allergen. This response is chiefly mediated by the activation of mast cells. But, in some cases, there is a second response that develops 2 to 24 hours after exposure to the allergen. This second response does not require second exposure to the allergen. This is known as late phase reaction. This occurs because of the leukocyte infiltration of the tissues which also keeps this response continued for many days.

questions.text: A carpenter presented with irritation and blurring of vision in both eyes for 1 week. A wooden piece penetrated into his right eye 4 weeks back while working. On evaluation, the visual acuity of the left eye was 6/12 and there is only perception of light in his right eye. Fundoscopic examination revealed subretinal deposits corresponding to Dalen-Fuch's nodules. Which type of hypersensitivity reaction is involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
This patient with bilateral redness and irritation, subretinal deposits corresponding to Dalenn Fusch nodules on fundoscopy, and a history of ocular trauma likely has sympathetic ophthalmitis. The pathophysiology of this condition is due to delayed type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. 

Sympathetic ophthalmitis is a granulomatous pan-uveitis that usually occurs after penetrative trauma. It can also develop after intraocular surgery. Both the injured eye (exciting eye) and fellow eye (sympathizing eye) develop panuveitis. Trauma to the ciliary region (dangerous zone) poses an increased risk. It presents between 2 weeks and 3 months after the inciting event in trauma-induced cases. 

It is a type 4 hypersensitivity reaction. According to the allergic theory, the uveal pigment in the injured eye acts as an allergen that causes uveitis in the other eye. Dalen-Fuchs nodules (proliferation of pigment epithelium), exudative retinal detachment, and optic disc swelling can be seen on fundoscopy. A sunset glow appearance can persist due to residual chorioretinal scarring.

Clinical features include redness and irritation in the "exciting eye", and irritation, photophobia, and loss of accommodation in the "sympathizing eye". Anterior uveitis develops in both eyes, and the severity of inflammation is markedly different in both eyes. 

Fundus examination will reveal exudative retinal detachment, vasculitis, and optic disc swelling. Dalen Fuch's nodules are local granulomas due to the proliferation of lymphocytes and epithelioid cells and are located between RPE and Bruch's membrane.

Investigations include optical coherence tomography, B scan ultrasonography, fluorescein angiography, and ultrasound.

Treatment mainly involves steroids. High-dose oral prednisolone is given for several months and gradually tapered according to the response. Immunosuppressant drugs such as methotrexate, cyclosporine, and azathioprine can be used as steroid-sparing agents, or in resistant cases.

Historically, enucleation of the injured eye if performed soon after the injury has been shown to reduce the incidence. However, with advancing surgical techniques, an increasing number of traumatically injured eyes are deemed to be salvageable.

questions.text: Which of the following types of leprosy would have the following finding as its most prominent histologic feature?
questions.solution:
The finding marked with red arrows in the given image is Grenz zone and it is prominently seen in the case of lepromatous leprosy.

The Grenz zone is a narrow area of the papillary dermis uninvolved by the underlying pathology. The Grenz zone is most prominent in lepromatous leprosy as there are scarce granulomas to fill this space. It may also be seen in the borderline spectrum, but is not necessarily characteristic.

Dermal tuberculoid granulomas, consisting of groups of epithelioid cells with giant cells, are found in tuberculoid leprosy. The granulomas are elongated and generally run parallel to the surface, following neurovascular bundles. The granulomas extend up to the epidermis, thereby obscuring the Grenz zone.

Grenz zone is also seen in Granuloma faciale and B cell lymphomas.

questions.text:
Match the following .
1. Bhore committee a. Committee on multipurpose workers
2. Jungalwalla committee b. 3 million plan
3. Kartar singh committee c. Integration of Health Service
4. Shrivastava committee d. Village Health Guide scheme
questions.solution:
The correct match is 1-b, 2-c, 3-a, 4-d.

1. Bhore committee b. 3 million plan
2. Jungalwalla committee c. Integration of Health Service
3. Kartar Singh Committee a. Committee on Multipurpose Workers

questions.text: The histopathological finding given in the image below is most likely to be present in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
The histopathological section has giant cells with a central ring of nuclei with a clear peripheral cytoplasm suggestive of the Touton giant cell. It is seen in xanthoma.

TOUTON GIANT CELL:

Touton giant cells are characterized by central eosinophilic cytoplasm and annulus of nuclei surrounded by a foamy, lipid-filled pale outer ring. These cells are seen in:

  • Fat necrosis
  • Xanthogranuloma
  • Dermatofibroma
  • Xanthoma

Other options

Options A and D: Langhans' giant cells are seen in tuberculosis and leprosy.  Langhans’ giant cells have a horseshoe-shaped nuclei arrangement at one pole of the cell. These are formed by the fusion of epithelioid cells. They are not phagocytic but secrete interleukins and help in inflammation.

Option C: Sarcoidosis: There are non-caseating granulomas composed of epithelioid macrophages with giant cells. There is no central necrosis. They are called naked granulomas as they are minimally surrounded by lymphocytes.

Laminated calcium and protein-containing bodies called Schaumann bodies (shown in the image below) and star-shaped inclusions called asteroid bodies are also found in the giant cells of most of these granulomas. These are not pathognomonic to sarcoidosis and can also be found in other granulomatous diseases like tuberculosis.

questions.text: A female patient presents with sudden onset palpitations, sweating, breathlessness, and a feeling like she is being choked. Physical examination and routine investigations were within normal limits. Which of the following is false about this condition?

choices.text: Occurs only in the presence of a trigger

questions.solution:
This clinical vignette describes a classic panic attack, which can occur even in the absence of an identifiable trigger.

A panic attack is a sudden surge of intense fear or discomfort that may last from minutes to hours. Recurrent panic attacks can point to a panic disorder.

Panic attacks can also be seen in other disorders such as specific phobias, social phobias, and post-traumatic stress disorder. Unexpected panic attacks occur at any time and are not associated with any identifiable situational trigger. Attacks in patients with social and specific pho­bias are usually expected in response to a specific stimulus.

Some panic attacks are neither unexpected nor expected attacks and are known as situationally predisposed panic attacks. They may or may not occur on exposure to a specific trigger, or may occur immediately after exposure or after a considerable period of time.

Four or more of the following should be present to label it a panic attack:

  • Palpitations, pounding heart, or tachycardia
  • Perspiration
  • Trembling 
  • Breathlessness or a sensation of smothering
  • Feelings of choking
  • Chest pain or discomfort
  • Nausea or abdominal distress
  • Dizziness, unsteadiness, light-headedness, or fainting 
  • Chills or heat sensations
  • Paresthesias
  • Derealization (feelings of unreality) or depersonalization (feeling detached from oneself)
  • Fear of losing control 
  • Fear of death

Alprazolam and paroxetine can be used for the medical management of panic disorders. Cognitive and behavior therapies can also prove effective. 

Related Pearl: Anxiety disorders

Feature

  • Dyspnea
  • Tachypnea
  • Palpitations
  • Sweating

  • Tightness
  • Paresthesias
  • Emotional and cognitive
    symptoms

    about to happen.

2. At least 1 attack followed by one or both of the following > 1 month:

  • Worry about an additional panic attack or consequences
  • Changes in behaviour related to attacks (ex: avoidance)

3. Panic attack not attributable to substance abuse or another medical condition.

4. Panic attack not explained by another mental disorder.

Treatment of Panic disorder:

Immediate: Benzodiazepines
Long term: SSRI/ SNRI and or cognitive behavioural therapy

a variety of topics (job, health, finances, etc.) > 6 months.

  • Restlessness

First line: CBT, SSRIs or SNRIs

questions.text: The growth chart of a child depicting changes in head circumference is shown below. Which of the following conditions is he most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
The given growth chart shows head circumference >2 standard deviations / 97th percentile above the mean, signifying macrocephaly. Achondroplasia is one of the causes of macrocephaly.

Achondroplasia is an autosomal dominant disorder caused by mutations in the gene encoding for fibroblast growth factor receptor type 3. It typically manifests at birth with short limbs, a long, narrow trunk, and a large head with midfacial hypoplasia and a prominent forehead (disproportionate short stature). The limb shortening is greatest in the proximal segments, and fingers often display a trident configuration. 

Infants usually exhibit delayed motor milestones, often not walking alone until 18-24 months. This is because of hypotonia and mechanical difficulty balancing the large head on a normal-sized trunk and short extremities. Intelligence is normal until central nervous system complications develop. Life span is normal for most children.

Important causes of macrocephaly:

  • Megalencephaly (enlargement of the brain parenchyma               
    •  Benign familial
    • Neurocutaneous syndromes such as neurofibromatosis, tuberous sclerosis
    • Leukodystrophies: Alexander, Canavan diseases
    • Lysosomal storage diseases: Tay–Sachs, mucopolysaccharidosis
    • Others: Sotos, Fragile X syndrome
  • Increased cerebrospinal fluid
    • Hydrocephalus
    • Benign enlargement of subarachnoid space
  • Enlarged vascular compartment
    • Arteriovenous malformation
    • Subdural, epidural, subarachnoid, or intraventricular haemorrhage
  • Increase in the bony compartment
    • Bone disease: Achondroplasia, osteogenesis imperfecta
    • Bone marrow expansion: Thalassemia major
  • Miscellaneous causes
    • Intracranial mass lesions: Cyst, abscess, or tumour
    • Raised intracranial pressure: Idiopathic pseudotumor cerebri, galactosemia

Children with asymptomatic familial megalencephaly or benign enlargement of subarachnoid space do not require treatment. Infants with hydrocephalus may require neurosurgical intervention.

All the other options are causes of microcephaly.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravida is diagnosed with an acute infection of an organism at 10 weeks of gestation. The life cycle of the organism is shown below. Which of the following can be used to prevent vertical transmission of the infection to the fetus in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given life cycle with both schizogony and gametogony in the definitive host cats is suggestive of Toxoplasma gondii. Spiramycin can be administered for cases of acute infection in early pregnancy to reduce vertical transmission to the fetus.

Spiramycin can be administered for cases of acute infection in early pregnancy to reduce vertical transmission. It does not cross the placenta and, therefore, cannot be used to treat an infected fetus. Pyrimethamine-sulfonamide (to be avoided in the first trimester) is used when a fetal infection is confirmed or in maternal infections after 18 weeks. (Option B)

Congenital toxoplasmosis occurs due to transplacental transmission from an affected pregnant woman or during the delivery of the fetus. The severity is higher when the infection is acquired in early pregnancy. The characteristic triad consists of chorioretinitis, hydrocephalus, and diffuse intracranial calcifications. Other manifestations include hydrops fetalis, intrauterine growth retardation, prematurity, peripheral retinal scars, persistent jaundice, and mild thrombocytopenia.

The diagnosis is made by the detection of IgM anti-toxoplasma antibodies (IgG crosses the placenta). IgM immunosorbent agglutination assay (ISAGA) and IgA ELISA are the most useful diagnostic tests.

Other options:

Option A: Suramin is effective for the early stages of T. brucei rhodesiense infection, where the CNS is not involved, as it cannot penetrate the blood-brain barrier.

Option D: Doxycycline is not used to treat toxoplasmosis and is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its teratogenic effects on bones and teeth.

questions.text: A known asthmatic patient on salbutamol was recently started on haloperidol for schizophrenia. He now complains of feeling restless and irritable with an irresistible urge to move. What is the treatment for this patient's symptoms?
questions.solution:
The clinical vignette points towards akathisia following haloperidol ingestion. In an asthmatic patient, the drug of choice is benzodiazepines like lorazepam. 

Haloperidol has a high risk of developing extrapyramidal side effects (EPS) such as akathisia, dystonia, and tardive dyskinesia. The first line drug for the management of akathisia is propranolol, but if there is a contraindication to the use of beta blockers, then the preferred drug would be a benzodiazepine. 

Akathisia consists of motor restlessness accompanied by subjective feelings of inner tension and discomfort referable chiefly to the limbs characterized by frequent repetitive stereotyped movements, and an inability to sit still for more than a short period. It usually occurs during the first few months of drug use. It is due to the decreased dopamine in the ventral tegmental area and substantia nigra.

Treatment:

  • Slow dose titration schedule, dose reduction, or switching to a less potent antipsychotic
  • First-line drugs - beta-blockers
  • Second-line drugs - benzodiazepines like lorazepam
  • Third-line drugs - anticholinergic agents like trihexyphenidyl, and benztropine.

Other options: 

Option A: Propranolol is the first-line drug for the treatment of restlessness in acute akathisia. Such non-selective beta-blockers are an absolute contraindication to bronchospastic conditions such as bronchial asthma.

Option C: Amantadine is used in treating bradykinesia due to dopamine antagonism in parkinsonism which is also an EPS. EPS-associated parkinsonism manifests as bradykinesia, variable tremors, rigidity, mask facies, and short shuffling gait. It is managed by dose reduction, antiparkinsonian agents and later amantadine can be tried. 

Option D: Valbenazine is used in managing tardive dyskinesia, which occurs months to years after the usage of such antipsychotic drugs. It is characterized by involuntary movements of the tongue, lips, face, trunk, and extremities in the form of orofacial dyskinesia, choreiform movements, tic-like movements, stereotypy, and possibly dystonia.

questions.text: A man who sustained a crush injury during an earthquake was rescued. His blood pressure was stable and no internal bleeding was detected. A significant reduction in his urine output was noted after some time. Investigations showed urine/plasma creatinine ratio < 20 and urinary sodium of 50 mEq/L. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis based on the clinical vignette given is intrinsic acute kidney injury (AKI). The history of crush injury is suggestive of rhabdomyolysis leading to AKI.

AKI is defined as a decline in kidney function within 7 days, resulting in the accumulation of nitrogenous waste and other toxic metabolites usually excreted in the urine. It includes a variety of conditions that share some common features such as elevated creatinine levels and reduced urine output. It is broadly divided into three categories:

  • Prerenal azotemia 
  • Intrinsic parenchymal disease
  • Postrenal obstruction

Intrinsic causes can further be divided into acute tubular necrosis, acute glomerulonephritis, and acute interstitial nephritis. Ischemia and nephrotoxins are the main causes of acute tubular necrosis. Nephrotoxins can be exogeneous such as vancomycin, cisplatin, and iodinated contrast agents used for CT imaging. Endogenous toxins include myoglobin, uric acid, and hemoglobin. Crush injuries, heat stroke, and myopathies can result in rhabdomyolysis releasing large amounts of myoglobin. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is usually ≤ 40.

In acute tubular necrosis, urinary sodium is >20 mEq/L. 

Prerenal azotemia arises due to a reduced renal plasma flow. Common causes include hypovolemia, liver failure, and congestive heart failure. The urine/plasma creatinine ratio is ≥ 40 and urinary sodium is usually <20mEq/L.

Bladder outlet obstruction, urethral obstruction, and benign prostatic hyperplasia lead to postrenal azotemia. Urinary sodium can be variable.

More causes of AKI are given below:

questions.text:
A 30-year-old woman is being evaluated for hypertension. She is a known case of Type 2 Diabetes mellitus which is controlled with diet and exercise. She is currently on Furosemide, Amlodipine, and Telmisartan. Her hypertension is only partially responsive to medications. She has peripheral edema along with muscle weakness. Her ECG findings are shown. Which screening test is to be done for this patient's condition?

Vitals and Labs:

BP:170/120

Pulse: 70/min

Temp: 98.9 F

Serum K: 2.4 mmol/L

Serum Na: 140 mEq/L
questions.solution:
The given clinical features of weakness, low potassium, edema, and hypertension refractory to 3 medications are suggestive of Primary Hyperaldosteronism.

ECG features of low potassium are:

  • Increased P wave amplitude
  • Prolongation of the PR interval
  • Widespread ST depression and T wave flattening/inversion
  • Prominent U waves (best seen in the precordial leads V2-V3)

Excess aldosterone leads to increased sodium and water retention and potassium excretion resulting in hypokalemia, volume expansion, and hypertension. Serum sodium tends to be normal due to concurrent fluid retention. 

Diagnostic screening for mineralocorticoid excess is not currently recommended for all patients with hypertension. It is advised in those who exhibit hypertension associated with drug resistance, hypokalemia, an adrenal mass, or onset of disease before the age of 40 years.

The accepted screening test is the concurrent measurement of plasma renin and aldosterone with subsequent calculation of the aldosterone-renin ratio (ARR); serum potassium needs to be normalized before testing. ARR screening is positive if the ratio is >750 pmol/L per ng/mL per hour, with a concurrently high normal or increased aldosterone.

Diagnostic confirmation is done by saline infusion test, which involves the IV administration of 2 L of physiologic saline over a 4-hour period. Failure of aldosterone to suppress <140 pmol/L (5 ng/dL) is indicative of autonomous mineralocorticoid excess. Alternative tests:

  • oral sodium loading test (300 mmol NaCl/d for 3 days)
  • fludrocortisone suppression test (0.1 mg q6h with 30 mmol NaCl q8h for 4 days).

If plasma aldosterone concentration is more than >10 ng/ml after saline infusion test is suggestive of primary hyperaldosteronism. This has to be followed with a CT scan to find out the cause which may be bilateral adrenal hyperplasia or unilateral adenoma (Conn syndrome).

Resistant hypertension is defined by high blood pressure despite using three antihypertensive drug classes at maximum doses, often including a calcium channel blocker, a renin-angiotensin system blocker, and a diuretic. It may also apply to patients needing four or more medications to reach target blood pressure. 

Other Options:

Option A: Adrenal Vein Sampling is done before surgery to know which side is hyperactive.

Option C: The saline infusion test is the confirmatory test done if ARR is positive.

Option D: A CT Scan is used to find the cause after the diagnosis is established. It is not used as a screening test.

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of the frequent dropping of handheld things and tripping while walking. On examination, the patient appeared as shown in the image below. Strength is 4/5 in the intrinsic muscles of the hand. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing the patient with frontal balding, and a typical hatchet-faced appearance are suggestive of type 1 myotonic dystrophy.

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused due to CTG trinucleotide repeat in DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

It is associated with weakness in the distal muscles of the wrist, fingers, and foot. Involvement of the palatal, pharyngeal, and tongue muscles causes dysarthria and dysphagia. Involvement of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles leads to respiratory insufficiency. Proximal muscles remain unaffected.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. ECG shows conduction abnormalities in the form of first-degree heart block. Electromyography may show myotonia in DM1, however, it is patchy in DM2. Creatine kinase levels in the serum may be normal or mildly elevated.

The histopathological finding of muscle biopsy in both DM1, and DM2, shows internalized nuclei seen in individual muscle fibers, and the presence of several atrophic fibers with pyknotic nuclear clumps.

Treatment is mainly symptomatic. However, mexiletine is indicated for both DM1 and DM2 help in reducing myotonia.

Other options:

Options A and B: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies present with proximal muscle weakness. These are x-linked recessive dystrophies. Therefore, family history would reveal that mainly men in the family are affected.

Option D: In Pompe's disease or acid maltase deficiency is a glycogen storage disease. Affected children present with hypotonia, myocardiopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Respiratory muscle weakness leading to ventilatory insufficiency may be a prominent feature.

questions.text: A patient presented with the following finding after accidentally spilling hydrofluoric acid over his hand. What is the preferred initial treatment for his condition?
questions.solution:
The initial treatment of hydrofluoric acid skin burns is with the application of calcium carbonate gel.

Immediate first aid to help prevent severe injuries from a chemical burn include:

  • Carefully remove the chemical and any contaminated clothing
    • Remove the chemical and contaminated clothing from contact with the skin and eyes
    • Do not wipe the skin as this may spread contamination
    • If the chemical is dry, brush it off the skin
    • Use gloves or other protective materials to cover hands and, if possible, carefully cut away clothing such as T-shirts, rather than pulling them off over the head
  • Rinse the affected area using as much clean water as possible
    • Rinse the affected area continuously with clean water as soon as possible
    • Try to make sure the water can run off the affected area without pooling on the skin
    • Only use water– do not rub or wipe the area

In very few cases initial management by lavage with water is not useful. Ex: Phosphorous used in some military devices and elemental sodium seen in laboratory explosions.

In hydrofluoric acid burns, initially, calcium gluconate gel is applied topically. Severe burns or burns to large areas of the hand can be subsequently treated with Bier’s blocks containing calcium gluconate 10 % gel. If the burn is with a concentration of greater than 50 %, then acute early excision is indicated due to the chance of hypocalcemia and arrhythmias. Split skin graft application to a hydrofluoric acid wound should be delayed and must not be done initially. 

Note - Although topical calcium gluconate is usually preferred, topical calcium carbonate gels may also be used for treating burns as they are also effective in providing calcium ions to complex the  free fluoride ions to prevent further toxicity.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman evaluated for symptoms of chest discomfort and dyspnea was diagnosed with retrosternal goiter. CECT of the chest shows the extension of the goiter into the posterior mediastinum. This condition is best managed by
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a retrosternal goitre extending into the posterior mediastinum is best managed by median sternotomy. 

Retrosternal goitres that are at most risk of requiring conversion to an open sternotomy approach 

  • Malignant cases
  • Revision cases
  • Goitres extending into the posterior mediastinum
  • The diameter of the goitre exceeds that of the thoracic inlet
  • Goitres that reach the carina
  • Goitres that extend below the inferior margin of the aortic arch

>95% of retrosternal goitres can be removed through the transcervical approach. For a primary mediastinal goitre whose boundaries are completely within the chest, resection is often achieved through median sternotomy or thoracotomy to ensure that the vessels supplying the tumour are properly ligated. Removing the tumour through a cervical approach can result in uncontrolled bleeding and is generally avoided. 

If the gland is fixed and immobile or too large to deliver through a cervical approach, median sternotomy is performed and the gland can be dissected from below to achieve a safe total thyroidectomy.

Radioiodine therapy is not accepted in retrosternal goitre. Stridor due to compression by retrosternal goitre is very dangerous. Surgical removal should be complete because recurrent retrosternal goitre is very difficult to re-operate. Chemotherapy has no role in this condition. 

The retrosternal goitre is an extension of the nodular goitre into the mediastinum. This condition is usually asymptomatic and may not require surgery. If the gland enlarges within the thoracic inlet, the pressure may lead to dysphagia, tracheal compression, and eventually airway symptoms.

The management of small, asymptomatic nontoxic goiters typically involves nonoperative surveillance, including regular thyroid function testing and neck imaging. TSH suppression with levothyroxine (LT4) is often considered a first-line treatment, as it may reduce goiter size in about 30% of patients. For those who prefer a more proactive approach or have specific concerns, RAI ablation is an alternative that can reduce goiter size by up to 50% over a year.

Indications for surgery:

  • Symptomatic patients
  • Significant airway compression
  • In young patients in whom symptoms are likely to develop

In elderly patients where retrosternal goitres are incidentally found, it is observed rather than treated.

questions.text: A 7-year-old boy is brought to the casualty following a fall on an outstretched hand. He complains of pain in his left elbow. Examination reveals tenderness and swelling over his left elbow. An X-ray of the patient is given below. What is the fracture type according to the Gartland classification?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and x-ray showing posterior fat pad sign are suggestive of supracondylar fracture of the humerus which is type 1 according to Gartland classification.

Gartland classification

  • Type I – an undisplaced fracture
  • Type II – an angulated fracture with the posterior cortex still intact.
             IIA: a less severe injury with the distal fragment merely angulated
             IIB: a severe injury; the fragment is both angulated and malrotated
  • Type III–a completely displaced fracture(although the posterior periosteum is usually preserved, which will assist in surgical reduction)
  • Type IV – an anteriorly displaced fracture

Supracondylar fracture of humerus:

It is most commonly seen in children of 5-7 years. The extension type is seen in 98% of the cases while the rest are flexion type. The mechanism of injury involved is usually a fall on an outstretched hand with an elbow in full extension. On examination:

There may be an S-shaped deformity at the elbow. If the proximal fracture fragment is sharp and has penetrated the muscles and fascia, a dimple may be seen on the skin above the elbow (dimple sign). The three-point bony relationship is maintained in supracondylar fracture.

Radiology:  

  • An undisplaced fracture may show a triangular lucency like a sail of a yacht (sail sign), also called a fat pad sign. This is due to the fat pad around the elbow being pushed forward by the hematoma.
  • Baumann’s angle is the angle between the horizontal line of the elbow and the line drawn through the lateral epiphysis and long axis of the arm. It is normally less than 5 degrees and is checked with the other arm.

The most common nerve to be injured in extension type is the anterior interosseous nerve while the ulnar nerve is injured in flexion type. The brachial artery is most likely involved when there are blood vessel involvement.

Cubitus Varus deformity:

Cubitus varus or gunstock deformity is the most common angular deformity that results from supracondylar fractures in children. The static deformities of cubitus varus with respect to the distal fragment are :

  • Posterior displacement
  • Horizontal rotation
  • Coronal tilt.

Treatment: 

Conservative management is attempted with closed reduction using traction and counter-traction. Successful reduction is when the long axis of the arm and forearm lie in parallel. If conservative management fails, skin or skeletal traction is employed but is not used anymore due to better modalities of treatment.

Surgery is by either closed reduction and percutaneous internal fixation with K-wires or open reduction and internal fixation with wires or plates

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: A colonoscopy of a patient with a history of chronic abdominal pain, diarrhoea, and weight loss is given below. Biopsy showed transmural inflammation and the presence of non-caseating granulomas. Which of the following statements is correct regarding the management of the underlying condition?

choices.text: A frozen section is unreliable for determining microscopic Crohn's disease
Extra-intestinal complication of ankylosing spondylitis often subside after resection of involved bowel
Repeated wide resections can lead to significant remission or even to cure of the disease
Patient's with this condition cannot be managed laparoscopically as poor visualisation leads to worse outcomes

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the cobblestone appearance on colonoscopy and histopathological findings is suggestive of Crohn's disease, and the frozen section is unreliable for determining microscopic Crohn's disease.

A frozen section is not mandatory to determine the margins of resection. In fact, a frozen section is unreliable for determining microscopic Crohn's disease and should be performed only if malignancy is suspected.

Crohn's disease may occur in any area of the GI tract, but the most common sites involved at presentation are the terminal ileum, ileocecal valve, and cecum. 

Clinical features include:

  • Crampy abdominal pain may be limited to the right lower quadrant in patients with ileal disease. More extensive/severe disease will have features of abdominal obstruction
  • Intermittent and persistent diarrhoea- fluid secretion/impaired absorption in the inflamed bowel, bile acid malabsorption, steatorrhea due to loss of bile salts, enteroenteric fistulas.
  • Fatigue
  • Fistulae and abscesses
  • Malabsorption

The main gross and histopathological features include:

  • Transmural inflammation- full-thickness inflammation involving all the layers of the bowel
  • Aphthous ulcers- small, shallow ulcers surrounded by erythema
  • Longitudinal ulcers- linear or serpiginous deep ulcers 
  • Skip lesions- involvement of discontinuous segments of the bowel with intervening normal mucosa
  • Creeping fat
  • Cobblestone appearance- deep, longitudinal ulcerations interlaced with intervening normal mucosa.
  • Fibrosis, adhesions, and fistulae due to increased inflammation

Nutritional therapy and glucocorticoids are used for inducing remission in Crohn's disease.

Drugs used in the treatment of Crohn’s disease:

  1. Oral budesonide (mainly for mild to moderate)
  2. Oral prednisolone
  3. Methotrexate
  4. Anti-TNF alpha
  5. Azathioprine
  6. 6-mercaptopurine
  7. Monoclonal antibodies
  8. Antibiotics

The aim of surgical intervention for Crohn’s disease is to perform minimal surgery, intended to remove just grossly inflamed tissue or to increase the luminal diameter of the bowel (i.e., stricture-plasty). Repeated wide resections may lead to short bowel syndrome. The operative treatment of a complication is limited to the segment of the bowel involved with the complication, and resection of any more bowel should be avoided, even though the grossly evident disease may be apparent. Patients with Crohn's can be managed laparoscopically - especially in specific complications like localized abscess, simple intraabdominal fistulas, perianastomotic recurrent disease, & disease limited to the distal ileum.

The extraintestinal complications of Crohn’s disease often subside after resection of the involved bowel, with the exception of ankylosing spondylitis and hepatic complications.

Related Pearl: Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD)

 

  Crohn's disease Ulcerative colitis
Age of onset  2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 2nd-4th decades & 7th-9th decades 
Most common presentation Ileocolitis with rectal sparing Proctitis (rectum)
Protective factors  None 

Smoking 

Appendicectomy
