questions.text: During the evaluation of a patient posted for emergency appendicectomy, the anesthetist grades him as Mallampatti class III and suspects a difficult airway. The device given in the image below can be used in this patient. The disadvantage of this device compared to an endotracheal intubation is:

choices.text: Risk of aspiration of gastric contents

questions.solution:
The given image shows a laryngeal mask airway (LMA) which is indicated in cases with difficult airways. The disadvantage of LMA is that it increases the risk of aspiration of gastric contents.

LMA is used for airway management as a temporary, life-saving measure in patients with difficult ventilation. Difficult ventilation can be either due to difficult airways, unavailability, or difficulty in mask ventilation and intubation.

Advantages of LMA:

  • Less invasive as compared to tracheal tubes.
  • Lesser bronchospasm as compared to tracheal tubes 
  • It partially protects the larynx from pharyngeal secretions.
  • Useful in difficult intubations
  • Less trauma to teeth and pharynx
  • Muscle relaxation is not required
  • Neck mobility is not required 

Disadvantages:

  • does not protect from gastric regurgitation
  • Less safe in prone or jack-knife positions
  • Less secure airway
  • Greater risk of a gas leak and pollution

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of Laryngeal mask airway (LMA)

Indication:

  • Difficult airway management during cardiopulmonary resuscitation.
  • In emergency where intubation & mask ventilation is not possible. 
  • For minor surgeries, where Anesthetist wants to avoid intubation. 
  • As a conduit for bronchoscopes, small size tubes, gum elastic bougies.

Contraindications:

  • Oropharyngeal abscess or mass
  • Poor mouth opening 
  • Conditions with high risk of aspiration:
    • Hiatus hernia
    • Pregnancy
    • Full stomach patients who are vulnerable to go in bronchospasm
    • Low pulmonary compliance (eg. Obesity)
    • Peak inspiratory pressure > 30 cm of H2O. 


 

Related Pearl: Different sizes of the laryngeal mask airway

Mask size Patient Size  Weight (kg) Cuff Volume (mL)
1 Infant <5 2-4
1.5 Infant 5-10 upto 7
2 Child 10-20 upto 10
2.5 Child 20-30 upto 14
3 Small Adult 30-50 upto 20
4 Normal adult(women) 50-70 upto 30 
5 Normal adult >70 30-40
6 Adults >100 50

questions.text:
Identify the matched foods corresponding to the graph as provided below.

GI- Glycemic Index
questions.solution:
The matched option is option A, i.e. 1 - potato (High glycemic index) and 2 - lentils (Low glycemic index)

Some low-GI foods which are beneficial in patients with obesity and type 2 diabetes mellitus include:

  • Fruits and vegetables (except potatoes)
  • Whole grains
  • Brown rice
  • Pasta
  • Beans
  • Lentils

Food with high GI:

  • White rice
  • Potatoes
  • Pumpkin 
  • Corn flakes
  • White bread.

The increase in the blood glucose levels after a test dose of a carbohydrate meal compared with that after an equivalent amount of glucose is termed the glycemic index (GI). Graphically, it is represented by the area under the curve of the blood glucose-time graph. The given graph shows the glycemic index of test food versus the glucose as a reference.

Foods containing different proportions of insoluble fibers prolong digestion and absorption. Foods that are not readily hydrolyzed and absorbed from the small intestine have a lower GI. On the other hand, starches that are easily digested have a higher GI. Since the blood glucose levels rise slowly, there is no rapid spike in insulin levels.

questions.text: A patient with poorly controlled diabetes and peripheral neuropathy complains of pain and swelling in the left foot after sustaining a trivial injury. Examination revealed the following findings. The radiograph reveals midfoot dislocation. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of loss of sensation and flat foot is suggestive of sensory and motor neuropathy in a diabetic patient along with joint involvement, pointing to a diagnosis of Charcot foot. 

Charcot foot is a condition in which patients develop neuropathic destruction of joints. Diabetic neuropathy is a common cause. It may be painless but most cases present with pain. Other features include redness and swelling. 

The principle of treatment is to maintain the shape of the foot in order to avoid pressure ulcers at a later stage. Surgical options are aimed at preventing deformity by early stabilization, reconstruction, and prevention of complications like ulcers by removing bony prominences. 

Other options:

Option B: Osteomyelitis is a common complication in diabetics, often presenting with foot pain and swelling but without immediate dislocation on imaging.

Option C: A fracture-dislocation may result from a traumatic event, it typically suggests acute injury rather than the underlying chronic changes associated with neuropathic conditions.

Option D: Cellulitis is a bacterial infection following any broken skin or any pre-existing condition. It is characterized by pain, fever, and leucocytosis.

questions.text: A 60-year-old male comes to the emergency with a cardiac arrest and cardiopulmonary resuscitation is initiated. Which of the following capnographs would be obtained in this case?
questions.solution:
Image B represents the capnographic waveform seen while performing cardiopulmonary resuscitation. 

Waveform capnography is a continuous non-invasive measurement and graphical display of the EtCO2. 

Uses of waveform capnography in CPR:

  • Evaluation of the effectiveness of chest compressions (<10 mmHg low EtCO2 suggests poor chest compressions)
  • Identification of return of spontaneous circulation (significant increase to 35–45 mmHg, due to drastic improvement of blood flow to the lungs)

It is a direct measure of lung ventilation and an indirect measure of circulation and metabolism. It is now the desired investigation for assessing the effectiveness of chest compressions. 

Image A shows rebreathing of CO2, which may occur due to a faulty expiratory valve or an exhausted absorber system. 

Image C shows cardiac oscillations at the end of expiration as flow decreases and the beating heart causes emptying and filling of various parts of the lung with exhaled and fresh air. 

Image D shows malignant hyperthermia.

The normal capnograph displays the exhaled CO2 in both inspiratory and expiratory phases. The expiratory phase is divided into three distinct components:

  • Phase I: exhalation of dead space gas (i.e., partial pressure of CO2, pCO2 ∼0).
  • Phase II: A sharp rise in pCO2 to a plateau indicates the sampling of transitional gas between the airways and alveoli. 
  • Phase III: The plateau region of the capnograph, corresponds to the pCO2 in the alveolar compartment. 
  • Following phase III, a sharp inspiratory downstroke occurs, which is referred to as the beginning of phase 0 or phase IV by some authors.

Related Pearl: Various capnography waveforms:

A- Obstructive airway or bronchospasm
B- Expiratory valve malfunctioning
C- Inspiratory valve malfunction
D- Normal physiological variant seen in pregnant subjects under GA
E- Curare cleft
F- Rebreathing
G- Esophageal intubation
H- Spontaneous breathing
I-Dual capnogram in one lung transplantation patient. The first peak in phase III is from the transplanted normal lung, whereas the second peak is from the native disease lung. A variation of dual capnogram (steeple sign capnogram – dotted line) is seen if there is a leak around the sidestream sensor port at the monitor
J- Malignant hyperthermia
K- Classic ripple effect during the expiratory pause showing cardiogenic oscillations
L- Sudden rise of baseline and end-tidal PCO2 (PETCO2) due to contamination of the sensor with secretions or water vapor.
The gradual rise of baseline and PETCO2 occurs when soda lime is exhausted. 
M -Intermittent mechanical ventilation (IMV) breaths in the midst of spontaneously breathing patient.
N -Cardiopulmonary resuscitation: capnogram showing positive waveforms during each compression. 
O-Capnogram showing rebreathing during inspiration. This is normal in rebreathing circuits such as Mapleson D or Bain circuit.

Related Pearl: Signs of correct endotracheal intubation

  • Detection of end-tidal CO2 by capnography (Surest confirmation)
  • Symmetric chest rise
  • Bilateral breath sounds
  • Absence of breath sounds in the epigastrium
  • Visible condensation in the endotracheal tube
  • Large exhaled tidal volumes
  • Appropriate compliance of the reservoir bag during manual ventilation

questions.text: A patient's sample being tested for typhoid with the widal test is found to show a poor agglutination response. Assuming he had the disease, which of these factors can lead to this test result?

choices.text: Blood was taken for test after 1st week
Blood was taken for test after 2nd week

questions.solution:
In this patient with suspected typhoid, the Widal test has not shown agglutination despite the patient having the disease. The likely reason for this is administration of antibiotics to the patient early in his disease course.

Prior administration of antibiotics can show a poor agglutination response in patients having typhoid by reducing bacterial overload and, thus, antibody production. This may lead to delayed diagnosis and inadequate treatment.

The titers can also be reduced if the test is performed in the early stage of the disease, as the agglutinins usually appear by the end of the 1st week. The titers tend to decline after the third and fourth weeks. However, the importance of Widal is the demonstration of increasing titres rather than a single high titre.

Widal Test measures the presence of somatic O antigen (S. typhi) and flagellar H antigen (S. typhi, S. paratyphi A and B). The paratyphoid O antigen cross-reacts with the typhoid O antigen and hence, the O antibody cannot differentiate between the Salmonella types. H agglutinins persist longer than O agglutinins.

Other Options:

Options A and B- Widal test usually shows agglutination after the 1st week till the 3rd or 4th week. Therefore, a test done after 1st or the 2nd week will show a good agglutination response.

Option D- Anamnestic response is the rapid production of antibodies in response to an unrelated fever in individuals who have had prior infection with salmonella or immunisation. Therefore, in this case, the titres will be high but only transiently. While in typhoid fever, the rise is sustained.

questions.text: A farmer presented with a mass on his jaw, containing draining sinuses with purulent discharge. The culture of the discharge from the sinus grew colonies, which are shown in the image given below. What is the causative organism?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario along with the image showing molar tooth colonies that are characteristic of actinomyces species. The given clinical scenario describes a lumpy jaw seen in cervicofacial actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis is a chronic suppurative and granulomatous infection caused by Actinomyces. It presents as one of the following clinical types:

  • Cervicofacial actinomycosis- fluctuant mass in the jaw area producing draining fistulas (lumpy jaw)
  • Thoracic actinomycosis- pulmonary infection with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. 
  • Abdominal actinomycosis- following ruptured appendix or ulcer. It may involve multiple organs.

The image given below shows cervicofacial actinomycosis.

The image given below shows a patient with multiple cutaneous lesions caused by actinomycosis.

Actinomycosis can spread to bones and surrounding tissue and produce multiple discharging sinuses.

Diagnosis is by examination of the pus from sinuses, sputum, or tissue specimens for sulfur granules. These granules are yellow, hard, lobulated, and made of tissue and bacterial filaments. Gram staining shows filamentous gram-positive bacteria.

Specimens should be cultured anaerobically on appropriate media such as chocolate blood agar, brain heart infusion broth, and brucella blood agar with hemin and vitamin K1. They may form molar-tooth colonies on agar and grows as clumps within the broth. Actinomyces species are mostly facultative anaerobes. 

Treatment is with IV penicillin for 2-6 weeks followed by oral therapy with penicillin or amoxicillin for serious infections.

Other options:

Option A: Cryptococcus usually manifests as meningitis with headache, neck stiffness, and disorientation. In addition, there may be lesions in the skin, lungs, or other organs. Cryptococcus produces whitish mucoid colonies. On microscopy, spherical budding yeast cells with a thick capsule are seen.

Option B: Bacillus anthracis usually manifests as cutaneous anthrax. The typical lesion has a characteristic central black eschar with marked edema. Microscopy shows gram-positive rods and culture on blood agar produce nonhemolytic gray to white, tenacious colonies with a ground-glass appearance. Comma-shaped outgrowths may project from the colony.

Option D: Klebsiella is a gram-negative, encapsulated, non-motile bacterium. It can cause pneumonia, urinary tract infections, and skin and wound infections. It produces a very viscous, mucoid growth when cultured on ordinary media. On MacConkey agar, they grow as lactose-forming colonies.

questions.text: You are posted as the in-charge medical officer for a special vaccination drive for measles. You would advise avoiding measles vaccination in all of the following individuals except ____.

choices.text: A patient who has a high fever
A patient in early stages of HIV infection
A patient with history of an anaphylactic reaction to gelatin

questions.solution:
A patient in the early stages of HIV infection is not a contraindication for measles vaccination.

Measles vaccination is contraindicated

  • if the patient has a high fever, 
  • pregnant women,
  • severely immunocompromised due to congenital disease,
  • severe HIV infection,
  • advanced leukaemia or lymphoma,
  • serious malignant disease,
  • history of an anaphylactic reaction to neomycin, gelatin
  • treatment with high-dose steroids, alkylating agents or antimetabolites, or immuno-suppressive therapeutic radiation

The measles vaccine is a live attenuated vaccine which is safe and effective with no evidence of person-to-person transfer of vaccine strains. In general, live vaccines are contraindicated in immune deficiency diseases and immunosuppressive states(malignancies, steroid therapy, chemotherapy with anticancer drugs, radiation) and in pregnancy.

Measles vaccine can be given in combination with other live attenuated vaccines such as mumps, and rubella vaccines (MMR vaccine), measles, mumps, rubella and varicella (MMRV), and measles and rubella (MR).

Measles is caused by an RNA paramyxovirus. Contact with large droplets or small-droplet aerosols is the route of transmission. Infection results in respiratory tract epithelial necrosis and lymphocytic infiltration. Clinical features include high fever, cough, coryza, and a rash. Koplik spots appear 1-4 days before the onset of the rash at the level of the premolars. This is followed by the appearance of the rash that starts on the forehead, neck, and behind the ears. It then spreads to involve the torso and extremities.

Diagnosis can be made by IgM assay. Affected children need to be isolated for 4 days after the beginning of the rash to prevent its spread. Treatment is mainly supportive.

Most of the complications are secondary to bacterial infections. It includes pneumonia, acute otitis media, croup, bronchiolitis, encephalitis, and subacute sclerosing panencephalitis. Secondary attack rates in susceptible contacts are usually ≥90%. Vaccination against measles is the most effective way to prevent the condition.

 

Related Pearl: Measles vaccine

Measles vaccine: 

  • Type: Live attenuenated, lyophilized (freeze dried), vaccine (Tissue culture vaccine- chick embryo or Human diploid cell line).

  • Strains used: 1. Edmonston Zagreb strain (most common). 

                            2. Schwartz strain.

                            3. Moraten strain.

  • Dose: 0.5ml.

  • Route: Subcutaneous.

  • Site: Right arm (usually).

  • Age of administration in National immunization schedule (India): 9 months (can be lowered to 6-9 months in epidemics and malnutrition) and 16-24 months.

  • Diluent for reconstitution: Distilled water or sterile water. (To be used within 4 hours after reconstitutuion).

  • Measles (and MMR) vaccine can lead to Toxic shock syndrome.

  • Measles vaccine is contraindicated in pregnancy.

  • Cold chain temperature for storage: +2 to +8 degree Celcius.

  • Protective efficacy: >90% with one dose; >99% with two doses.

  • Duration of protection: Life long.

  • IP of vaccine induced measles: 7 days.

  • Ideal gap between two successive doses: 6 months.

questions.text:
A 60-year-old woman presents with a sudden onset of severe chest pain and shortness of breath for 1 day. A chest radiograph reveals a moderate pleural effusion. Thoracocentesis is performed and results are given below. What is the most likely cause of pleural effusion in this patient?
  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein ratio: 0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH ratio: 0.6
  • Pleural fluid glucose: 65 mg/dL
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the pleural effusion in the setting of acute breathlessness and chest pain that meets the criteria for exudative pleural effusion, along with pleural fluid glucose levels above 60 mg/dL. is likely to be due to pulmonary embolism.

The effusion in pulmonary embolism is a result of increased pulmonary capillary permeability leading to interstitial fluid moving from the lung to the pleural space by crossing the visceral pleura. The increased permeability is caused by the release of inflammatory mediators from clots that are rich in platelets. 

Transudative and exudative pleural effusions are distinguished by measuring the lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) and protein levels in the pleural fluid. Exudative pleural effusions meet at least one of the following criteria, whereas transudative pleural effusions meet none:

  • Pleural fluid protein/serum protein >0.5
  • Pleural fluid LDH/serum LDH >0.6
  • Pleural fluid LDH more than two-thirds of the normal upper limit for serum

Also if the difference between the protein levels in the serum and the pleural fluid is >3.1 g/dL, it is likely to be transudative pleural effusion.

If the fluid appears to be exudate, then pleural fluid glucose levels can help in identifying the etiology. If the glucose levels are less than 60 mg/dL, then the effusion is likely due to malignancy, parapneumonic effusion (bacterial infection), and rheumatoid pleuritis.

Examples of transudative pleural effusions are effusions due to congestive heart failure, cirrhosis, and nephrosis. Exudative pleural effusions are caused by malignancies, bacterial infections, rheumatoid pleuritis, and pulmonary embolism.

If the pleural fluid cytology, culture, glucose, and staining do not yield any result, perform spiral CT to rule out pulmonary embolism and assess the markers of tuberculosis.

Other options:

Option A and C : Congestive heart failure and cirrhosis are examples of transudative pleural effusion.

Option B: Although this patient's exudative effusion may be parapneumonic, the absence of fever, sudden onset of symptoms, chest x-ray without consolidation, and normal pleural fluid glucose make bacterial infection a less likely cause.

Related Pearl: Types of pleural effusion

Transudative Pleural effusion

  • Congestive heart failure (most common)
  • Cirrhosis
  • Nephrotic syndrome
  • Myxedema 
  • Peritoneal dialysis
  • Urinothorax
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Constrictive pericarditis
  • Superior vena cava obstruction

Exudative Pleural effusion 

  • Infections: Tuberculosis, pneumonia, intraabdominal abscess (like- liver abscess)
  • Malignancy: Pleural mesothelioma, metastasis, lymphoma
  • Connective tissue diseases: SLE, rheumatoid arthritis
  • Drugs: Amiodarone, bromocriptine, dantrolene, dasatinib, methysergide, nitrofurantoin
  • Others:
    • Pancreatitis
    • Asbestosis
    • Pulmonary embolism
    • Hemothorax
    • Chylothorax
    • Meigs' syndrome 
    • Dressler syndrome (post-myocardial infarction or cardiac surgery)
    • Yellow nail syndrome

questions.text: A woman is admitted to the antenatal ward at 35 weeks. Her BP is 170/110 mmHg and her urine dipstick is 3+. She developed a generalized seizure attack during the examination.  What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Give a 4 g bolus of MgSO4 by slow IV injection
Give a 40 mg bolus IV injection of labetalol

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is that of a patient with eclampsia, where the first step of treatment is the management of the airway and prevent aspiration.

The immediate measures in the medical management of eclampsia include the following steps:

  • Call for extra help (Communication)
  • To put the patient in a left lateral recumbent position
  • Maintain oral airway
  • O2 inhalation – non-rebreather mask; 10 L/minute
  • Commence IV lines; 1 or 2 wide bore cannulas
  • Catheterize the patient with a foley's catheter and an urometer
  • To monitor O2 saturation; pulse oximeter (SPO2 >95%)
  • Control of seizures: MgSO4 (IV/IM regimens)
  • To monitor vitals; fetal status and magnesium toxicity
  • Control of hypertension: Labetalol, Hydralazine
  • Fluids: Crystalloids (saline) or colloids (albumin/blood) <125 mL/h
  • Oropharyngeal suction
  • Diuretics administration for pulmonary edema, if present

MgSO4 regimens:

Regimen Loading Dose Maintenance Dose
Intramuscular (Pritchard) 4 g (20% solution) IV over 3-5 minute
followed by 10 g (5O%), deep IM
(5 g in each buttock)		 5 g (5O%) IM 4 hourly in the alternate buttock
Intravenous (Zuspan or Sibai) 4g IV slow over 15-20 minute 1-2 g/h IV infusion

 

Delivery of the fetus resolves eclampsia. In most cases, labor sets in with antepartum eclampsia. If labor does not start and the seizures are controlled, a mature baby is vaginally delivered by induction of labor. If the baby is premature, steroids are given(<34 weeks) and delivery is conducted with an NICU setup.

If the seizures are not controlled for 6-8 hours, delivery is conducted by induction of labor and by shortening the duration of the second stage of labor. In case of obstetric contraindications for a vaginal delivery, a cesarean section should be done to deliver the fetus.

questions.text: A five-year-old girl is brought in with complaints of progressive fatigue, muscle weakness, and shortness of breath. Her diet is primarily plant-based with little to no animal products. On examination, she is tachypneic, tachycardic and upon auscultation, S3 gallop is heard. X-ray shows cardiomegaly. Which of the following interventions would be most beneficial for her condition?

choices.text: Begin iron supplementation and recommend a diet high in fortified cereals
Start vitamin D and calcium supplementation to address underlying rickets
Initiate selenium supplementation, and recommend dietary changes
Start parenteral vitamin B12 supplementation to treat underlying anemia

questions.solution:
The child presents with progressive fatigue, muscle weakness, shortness of breath, tachypnea, tachycardia, and cardiomegaly on X-ray, along with an S3 gallop. These symptoms, along with the primarily plant-based diet, suggest a possible diagnosis of Keshan disease, which is a cardiomyopathy caused by selenium deficiency. Therefore, the next step would be to Initiate selenium supplementation, and recommend dietary changes 

Dietary sources of selenium include whole grains, meat, eggs, seafood, garlic, and mushrooms. Selenium is an essential component of glutathione peroxidase, an antioxidant found in red blood cells and various tissues. It also plays a vital role in regulating normal immune function.

Other options: 

Option A : Iron supplementation and a diet high in fortified cereals would be appropriate for iron deficiency anemia, but this patient's primary symptoms point more towards heart failure and not anemia-related fatigue or weakness. 

Option B : Vitamin D and calcium supplementation would be used to treat rickets, which manifests with bone pain, skeletal deformities, and delayed growth, none of which are the primary issues here.

Option D : Vitamin B12 supplementation is crucial for individuals with a plant-based diet, but vitamin B12 deficiency typically causes neurological symptoms and megaloblastic anemia, rather than heart failure or cardiomegaly.

questions.text: The drug whose site of action is marked as 'A' is effective in the treatment of Pseudomonas but not in the treatment of Clostridium, due to ?

choices.text: Absence of oxygen dependent channels in Clostridium
Plasmid derived resistance against the drug
Absence of cell wall in Clostridium

questions.solution:
The mechanism of the drug marked as 'A' is that of an Aminoglycoside which acts by inhibiting the 30S ribosomal subunit. The reason aminoglycosides act on aerobic bacteria (Pseudomonas) and are ineffective in anaerobic ( Clostridium )organisms is that oxygen-dependent channels are required for aminoglycoside to enter into the bacteria.

Gram-negative bacteria use porin channels for diffusion and carrier proteins connected to the electron transport chain to transport molecules across membranes. This process relies on a polarized membrane and oxygen-dependent active mechanisms, specifically the energy-dependent phase I (EDP1) entrance. In the absence of oxygen, these processes are deactivated, leading to reduced sensitivity in anaerobic microorganisms and increased resistance in facultative anaerobes in low-oxygen environments, such as large abscesses.

Aminoglycosides include streptomycin, gentamicin, tobramycin, amikacin, and kanamycin and acts by causing irreversible inhibition of the initiation complex through binding of the 30S ribosomal subunit. They also cause misreading of the mRNA. They are bactericidal and the killing is concentration-dependent. 

They are used in the treatment of aerobic gram-negative bacterial infections such as urinary tract infections, mycobacterial infections, tularemia, respiratory infections in cystic fibrosis, and other pseudomonal infections.

The adverse effects of aminoglycosides include-

  • Ototoxicity 
  • Nephrotoxicity 
  • Neuromuscular blockade 

Related Pearl: Protein synthesis inhibitors: Primary subunit of ribosome binding

Mnemonic: 50 CELLS arranged into 30 TEAM

50s subunit binding:

  • C: Chloramphenicol, Clindamycin
  • E: Erythromycin (macrolides)
  • L: Lincosamides
  • L: Linezolid
  • S: Streptogramins

30s subunit binding

  • Te: Tetracyclines
  • Am: Aminoglycosides

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravida at 30 weeks of gestation comes with complaints of absent fetal movements over the last week. Examination shows absent fetal heart sounds. Ultrasonographic examination shows overlapping of skull bones and no fetal movements. Which of the following is false about this likely condition?

choices.text: Robert's sign may be seen as early as 12 hours
Spalding's sign may be seen on USG
Spontaneous expulsion rarely occurs in these patients and induction is required
Infection by gas-forming organisms is likely after rupture of membranes

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes a case of intrauterine fetal death (absent fetal heart sounds, no fetal movements and Spalding's sign on ultrasound). The false statement is spontaneous expulsion is rare and induction is required.

It is an antepartum death occurring beyond the period of viability. In most of these cases, spontaneous expulsion occurs within 10-14 days. 

The causes of intrauterine fetal death are given below -

  • Maternal - Hypertensive disorders in pregnancy, diabetes in pregnancy, maternal infections, APLA, hyperpyrexia, thrombophilias, abnormal labour, post-term pregnancy, SLE
  • Fetal - Chromosomal abnormalities, structural abnormalities, infections, Rh-incompatibility, non-immune hydrops, growth restriction
  • Placental - Antepartum hemorrhage, cord accident, twin transfusion syndrome, placental insufficiency
  • Iatrogenic - External cephalic version, drugs
  • Idiopathic 

Sonographically, fetal heartbeat and fetal movements are absent. Overlapping of skull bones irregularly on one another known as Spalding's sign can be seen. Also, a gas shadow in the chambers of the fetal heart and great vessels called Robert's sign is seen as early as 12 hours.

Complications like infection following rupture of membranes with gas-forming organisms such as Clostridium welchii, and blood coagulation disorders may occur.

Management includes early intervention for psychological issues, signs of uterine infection, prolonged retention beyond two weeks, and falling fibrinogen levels. The first-line choice for induction of labor in such cases is a combination of mifepristone and prostaglandins, although misoprostol and oxytocin infusion can also be utilised effectively.

Note: The period of viability is when the fetus is capable of independent existence. The WHO defines it to be 24 weeks while the Indian definition is 28 weeks.

Related Pearl: Radiological features of Intrauterine Death

  • Robert's sign - The presence of a gas shadow within the chambers of the heart or the greater vessels like aorta, in cases of foetal death in utero
  • Spalding sign - Loss of alignment and over-riding of bones of cranial vault and overlapping of skull bones due to shrinkage of brain after death
  • Deuel’s halo sign – Increased pericranial fat
  • Hyperflexion of spine and crowding of ribs

questions.text:
A 5-year old child presents to the OPD with excessive dryness in the eyes and difficulty in seeing at night. On examination, cutaneous lesions are seen over the elbows, as shown in the image below. Which of the following deficiencies can cause this cutaneous lesion?
  1. Vitamin A
  2. Vitamin B complex
  3. Vitamin C
  4. Vitamin D
  5. Vitamin E
  6. Vitamin K
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of vitamin A deficiency. The cutaneous lesion in the image is phrynoderma, and it can caused by deficiency of vitamins A, B complex, C, and E and essential fatty acids.

Phrynoderma are keratotic follicular papules commonly present over the elbows and knees. They can also extend to the shoulders, neck, back, thighs, buttocks, and abdomen. It is also known as toad skin. 

When it occurs due to vitamin A deficiency, it is associated with ophthalmic symptoms like xerophthalmia, night blindness, and Bitot's spots and cutaneous symptoms like xerosis, scaling, and acne.

Management includes nutritional improvement through diet, multivitamin supplementation, and treatment of the underlying cause.

questions.text:
A primi mother delivered a neonate through NVD. Her past medical records reveal that she had seizures and was under valproate which she discontinued during pregnancy and restarted due to a seizure episode during the second trimester. She is concerned about breastfeeding what would be your advice?

NVD - Normal vaginal delivery

choices.text: Reassure her that antiepileptics don’t cross into breastmilk
Since valproate is hepatotoxic, avoid it and continue breastfeeding
Continue taking the antiepileptic and breastfeeding
Prefer formula milk as antiepileptics potentially cross into breastmilk

questions.solution:
Antiepileptics can be continued in the postpartum period and alongside breastfeeding. 

Maternal drug intake during nursing may have adverse effects on lactation and the baby through the ingested milk. Any drug ingested by a nursing mother may be present in her breast milk however, the levels are usually low when compared to those in the mother and such low levels are usually not of any clinical significance to the infant. 

The milk concentrations of some drugs like iodide may exceed those in the maternal plasma. However, the benefits of breastfeeding stand out. The risk of drug exposure to the neonate must be weighed against these benefits. 

Antiepileptics do cross into breastmilk, but the benefits of breastfeeding exceed the risks of exposure to antiepileptics, and hence breast milk supersedes other options like discontinuing the drug or usage of formula milk.

questions.text: A patient was brought to the casualty following a stab injury to the abdomen. Immediate laparotomy was performed and penetrating injuries to the retroperitoneum were noted. Which maneuver is performed to explore suprarenal vasculature and the left renal hilum?
questions.solution:
Mattox maneuver involves left medial visceral rotation which allows exploration of injuries to the suprarenal vasculature (aorta) and the left renal hilum

This is achieved by dividing the peritoneum along the entire left side of the abdomen, from above the spleen to the distal left colon. The plane posterior to the colonic mesentery and the pancreas is developed, and the abdominal viscera are retracted to the right to expose the superior retroperitoneal vasculature.

Penetrating injuries to the retroperitoneum identified during laparotomy require exploration and repair. Various surgical manoeuvres are done to explore different regions of the abdomen based on the location of the injury / Hematomas.

Other options:

Option B: Cattell-Braasch manoeuvre involves right medial visceral rotation. This allows the exploration of hematomas located in the infrarenal vasculature (IVC) and the right renal hilum.

Option C: Kocher manoeuvre is performed to allow inspection of the duodenum, pancreas, and other retroperitoneal structures over to the great vessels

Option D: The Pringle manoeuvre is performed when there is excessive bleeding from the liver. It involves compressing the hepatic pedicle for 15 - 20 minutes at the Foramen of Winslow.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old male presents with recurrent episodes of muscle weakness, fatigue, and intermittent muscle cramps. His blood pressure is 146/94 mm Hg. He has a family history of similar illness in his elder brother. Laboratory investigations reveal the following results. Which drug is least likely to be prescribed to this patient?
  • Serum potassium: 2.8 mEq/L 
  • Urine chloride: 45 mEq/L
  • Arterial blood gas (ABG):
    • pH: 7.48
    • pCO₂: 44 mmHg
    • HCO₃⁻: 30 mEq/L
questions.solution:
Spironolactone is least likely to be prescribed in this case.

The clinical presentation of hypertension, hypokalemia, and metabolic alkalosis in a patient with a family history of similar illness points toward Liddle’s syndrome.

Amiloride (Option A) and triamterene (Option B) are potassium-sparing diuretics that block ENac and are prescribed for Liddle’s syndrome.

Although KCl (Option D) is not the drug of choice in Liddle’s syndrome, it may be used for correction of hypokalaemia whenever required.

The metabolic abnormalities in Liddle’s syndrome show no response to spironolactone (Option C). Despite being a potassium-sparing diuretic, spironolactone, owing to its action on aldosterone rather than ENac, is ineffective in this case and least likely to be prescribed.

Liddle syndrome is caused by a gain-of-function mutation in the epithelial sodium channels (ENaC), leading to increased sodium reabsorption and potassium excretion, which results in hypertension, hypokalaemia, and metabolic alkalosis.

Among the inherited tubular disorders, hypertension is a classical feature of Liddle’s syndrome and is not seen in Bartter's or Gitelman's syndromes. Low renin and aldosterone levels are seen in Liddle’s syndrome, which suggests that sodium retention is unrelated to aldosterone excess.

Related Pearl: Renal Tubular Syndromes

Related Pearl: Site and mechanism of action of diuretics

Diuretics  Site of action  

Enzyme/receptor/transporter inhibited 
Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors   Proximal tubule   Carbonic anhydrase  
Loop diuretics  Thick ascending loop of Henle  Na+- K+- 2Cl- symporter
Thiazides Distal convoluted tubule  Na+- Cl- symporter
Epithelial sodium channel inhibitors  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts   ENaC 
Aldosterone antagonists  Late distal tubule and collecting ducts  Mineralocorticoid receptors (indirectly ENaC)

questions.text: Identify the type of skull fracture in the given image?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a separation of the lamboid suture, indicating a diastatic fracture.

Diastatic fractures refer to fractures in which the fracture line involves the separation of one or more cranial sutures. These are commonly seen in children and are often associated with epidural or subdural haemorrhage. The sagittal suture between the two parietal bones is the most common site of these fractures.

Other options:

Option A- A mosaic fracture is another name for comminuted fractures.

Option B- A linear lambdoid fracture is a linear fracture located near the lambdoid suture.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text:
Which of the following is the best test for quantifying viral load for herpes simplex virus?

PCR: Polymerase chain reaction

RTPCR: Reverse transcriptase-polymerase chain reaction

choices.text: RTPCR followed by Real time PCR

questions.solution:
Real-time PCR is the best test to quantify the viral load of herpes, which is a DNA virus.

Quantification of DNA involves the assessment of the amount/concentration of DNA that is present in a sample when carrying out a technique like PCR. Real-time PCR or quantitative PCR/qPCR involves the quantification of DNA after each cycle of amplification, or, in "real-time" at the end of the procedure; therefore real-time PCR helps in the quantitative analysis of DNA viral load.

Option A: RT-PCR (reverse transcriptase PCR) involves the generation of complementary DNA (cDNA) copies of the mRNA using the reverse transcriptase enzyme followed by amplifying the cDNA copies by PCR technique. When reverse transcriptase PCR and qPCR are combined, they can be used to quantify RNA viruses like coronavirus.

Option B: RTPCR can convert the RNA into cDNA by reverse transcriptase enzyme and then amplify the cDNA copies by means of PCR but cannot quantify the RNA.

Option C: PCR-Restriction fragment length polymorphism (PCR-RFLP) is also called cleaved amplified polymorphic sequence (CAPS) assay. Polymorphisms are inherited differences found among individuals in more than 1% of the normal population. PCR-RFLP is a technique in which organisms may be differentiated by variations in their DNA sequence by restriction endonucleases. Typically, gel electrophoresis is used to visualize RFLPs. Thus, RFLP can detect differences in homologous DNA sequences and is not a tool for quantifying viral load.

Related Pearl: Some Enzymes Used in Recombinant DNA Research

questions.text: A 27-year-old man presented to the infertility clinic for semen analysis during which a hypoosmotic swelling test is done. What is the purpose of this test?

choices.text: To differentiate between normal and altered sperm morphology
To differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm

questions.solution:
During semen analysis, a hypoosmotic swelling test is done to differentiate between dead and nonmotile sperm.

Unlike dead sperm, living sperm have the capability to maintain an osmotic gradient. Thus, when mixed with a hypoosmotic solution, living, nonmotile sperm with normal membrane function swell and coil as fluid is absorbed.

Semen abnormalities:

  • An acidic pH or lack of fructose indicates an obstruction in the efferent ductal system.
  • A low semen volume reflects incomplete specimen collection, short abstinence interval, partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation.
  • Oligospermia: A sperm concentration <15 million/ml, and counts <5 million/mL are considered severe.
  • Azoospermia: Absence of sperm in semen due to outflow tract obstruction as a result of congenital absence of vas, infection, vasectomy, or non-obstructive causes like testicular failure.
  • Teratospermia or teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology (Morphology is the most important factor/marker of semen analysis).

Sperm morphology is evaluated by looking at the sperm under a microscope and reporting the percentage of sperm with abnormal shapes. Morphology is evaluated using the WHO5 criteria.

Related Pearl: Semen Analysis : WHO Criteria (2022)

Semen analysis Normal reference value and minimal reference (in parenthesis) limit
Volume 2ml or more (1.4ml)
pH 7.2-7.8
Viscosity Less than 3
Sperm concentration 20 million/ml (15 million/ml)
Total sperm count More than 40 million/ejaculate
Motility More than 50% progressive forward motility(Progressive motility = 30%)
Morphology More than 4% normal form (lower reference limit)
Forward progression >2 (Scale of 0-4)
Viability 54% or more living
Leucocytes Less than 1 million/ml
Round cells Less than 5 million/ml
Sperm agglutination Less than 10 spermatozoa with adherent particles (<2)

questions.text: All of the following are used in sclerotherapy for varicose veins except:
questions.solution:
Acetic acid has been used as an injection sclerosant for treating cystic lesions, not varicose veins.

Other options:

Option A: Hypertonic saline, in various concentrations, was long considered the agent of choice. But, despite adding lidocaine, it was found to be painful during injection and appeared to exhibit a higher incidence of hyperpigmentation after treatment. 

Options C and D: Varying concentrations of sodium tetradecyl sulfate and polidocanol are now the preferred agents.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man who is on medical therapy for atrial fibrillation presents with anorexia, nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and confusion. He is also experiencing yellowed and blurred vision and has a heart rate of 120 beats per minute. Which of the following ECG findings is most suggestive of this patient’s current drug toxicity?
questions.solution:
This patient presents with signs and symptoms of digoxin toxicity. A characteristic EKG findings is the sagging ST depression, aka the “Salvador Dali” sign, as shown below.

Digoxin toxicity can occur in the elderly and in patients with renal impairment and presents nausea, vomiting, diarrhoea, confusion, blurred vision with a characteristic yellowing of vision (compared to the “starry night” painting), and irregular heart rhythms.

On ECG, digoxin toxicity is characterised by a number of findings, including:

  • Downsloping ST depression ("Salvador Dali sagging” or “Hockey Stick” appearance): not elevation (Option C)
  • T wave changes (flattening, inversion, or biphasic T waves)
  • QT shortening (Option A)
  • Premature beats (atrial, junctional, or ventricular)

Digoxin can induce nearly any arrhythmia but rapidly conducted atrial arrhythmias such as atrial fibrillation/flutter are very rare. (Option D)

questions.text: Cerebral blood flow is regulated by all except _______
questions.solution:
Normal cerebral blood flow is maintained despite the fluctuations in blood pressure due to autoregulation.

Cerebral Blood Flow:

  • Normal cerebral blood flow→ 50-65mL/100g of brain tissue/min
  • For entire brain CBF→750-900mL/min (15% of the resting cardiac output)
  • Factors that increase CBF
    • Cerebral metabolic rate
    • ↑ Arterial Pco2
  • 70% increase in Paco2 (80mmHg)  approximately doubles the CBF
    • ↑ H+ ion concentration
    • Hypoxia
    • Substances released from astrocytes that cause local vasodilation- NO, K+, adenosine, etc

Role of intracranial pressure

  • Monro-Kellie doctrine 
    • Because brain tissue and spinal fluid are essentially incompressible, the volume of blood, spinal fluid, and brain in the cranium at any time must be constant
    • More importantly, cerebral vessels are compressed when intracranial pressure rises
    • Any change in venous pressure promptly causes a similar change in intracranial pressure

Related Pearl: Blood Pressure and its determinants

Stroke volume (directly proportional)

Compliance of aorta (inversely proportional)

Diastolic BP (DBP)

Elastic recoil of aorta/major vessels (directly proportional)

Pulse pressure (PP)

Ratio of stroke volume to compliance of the arterial tree

Mean blood pressure (MAP)

Cardiac output

questions.text: Which of the following statement is false with regards to gastroschisis and omphalocele?

choices.text: Umbilical cord is attached adjacent to a gastroschisis defect
Extruded bowel is normal in character in gastroschisis
Omphalocele is associated with multiple anomalies
Intestinal obstruction is common in gastroschisis

questions.solution:
In gastroschisis, because of the absence of a sac and direct exposure of the intestine to amniotic fluid in utero, the intestine is often thickened, edematous, discoloured, and covered with exudate.

Points to remember:

  • Alpha-fetoprotein levels are elevated in both gastroschisis and omphalocele, but the levels are higher in gastroschisis.
  • Defects of size >4 cm are omphalocele; defects of <4 cm are designated as umbilical hernia.
  • omphalocele major should be operated at birth.
  • The most important prognostic factor in omphalocele is the presence of associated anomalies.

Gastroschisis is characterized by a defect in the anterior abdominal wall. The abdominal contents protrude through this defect. The defect is located usually to the right of the umbilicus at the junction of the umbilicus and normal skin. It is the most common anomaly seen in babies born to mothers under 20 years of age. It is usually <4cm in size without an overlying sac as seen in omphalocele.

Intestinal atresia is commonly associated with gastroschisis. The intestine is thickened, edematous and foreshortened in gastroschisis as the intestine is directly exposed to the amniotic fluid in-utero due to the absence of an overlying sac. 

Gastroschisis can be diagnosed by a prenatal ultrasound scan.

All newborns with gastroschisis require urgent surgical treatment. IV fluids are given to maintain fluid balance. The reduction of the bowel is staged using a silo-plastic bag that is attached to the abdominal wall containing the herniated bowel that is gently reduced every 12-24 hours. Surgical closure can be done within approximately 1 to 2 weeks. 

Omphalocele is a congenital abdominal wall defect where the bowel and the solid viscera are covered by the peritoneum and amniotic membrane. The defect can be of small size with intestinal contents to giant omphaloceles which has >4 cm abdominal wall defect.

Omphaloceles can be associated with other syndromes such as

  • exstrophy of the cloaca (vesicointestinal fissure), 
  • Beckwith-Widemann syndrome (macroglossia, macrosomia, hypoglycemia, visceromegaly and omphalocele) 
  • Cantrell's Pentalogy (lower thoracic wall malformations, ectopia cordis, epigastric omphalocele, anterior midline diaphragmatic hernia and cardiac anomalies). 

Immediate treatment includes stabilizing the baby and maintaining body temperature. Prophylactic antibiotics should be administered in case a rupture of the sac occurs.

Small-medium-sized defects have a better prognosis. In cases of large-sized defects, primary repair of the omphalocele is attempted if the pulmonary status is satisfactory.

Most standard books say that liver is not a content of the heriated viscera in gastroschisis.But there are some studies which show that liver or part of the liver can be a content in gastroschisis also.

Related Pearl: Difference between gastroschisis and omphalocele

Characteristic Gastroschisis Omphalocele
Defect size (diameter) 2-3 cm 2-15 cm
Sac Never Always, may be ruptured
Gestational age Prematurity Term
Umbilical cord Adjacent to the defect (defect is seen usually on its right side)  Attached to sac
Herniated viscera Small bowel, stomach, colon Small bowel, stomach, colon, liver
Malrotation Yes Yes
Bowel character Inflammatory, edematous Normal
Enternal nutrition Delayed Normal
Associated abnormalities Uncommon (10% atresia) Common (50%)

questions.text:
According to the national immunization schedule, what is the dose of vitamin A that should be administered with the first dose of the vaccine shown in the image?

IU- international units
questions.solution:
According to the national immunization schedule, 1ml containing 1 lakh IU of vitamin A should be given along with the first dose of the measles-rubella vaccine(shown in the image) orally. This is given at 9 completed months of age.

Vitamin A schedule in the National Immunisation Schedule: 

  • 1 lakh IU at 9 completed months along with the Measles-Rubella vaccine
  • 2 lakh IU is administered bi-annually for children between 1-5 years of age
  • Total number of doses administered- 9 doses,17 lakhs IU 

Related Pearl: National Immunization Schedule (India)

Vaccine When to give Dose Route Site
For Pregnant Women

questions.text: A study was conducted in a school to compare the heights of children of different grades. The children from 5th grade to 10th grade, were divided according to their grades, and their heights were measured. The appropriate statistical test of significance that should be used is ______
questions.solution:
Since more than two groups (from 5th class to 10th class) are compared in the above study, ANOVA test should be used.

Analysis of variance or ANOVA is used when more than 2 groups (means) are compared for difference.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: All of the following statements are true about pemphigus vulgaris except ______

choices.text: Desmoglein 1 is the principal antigen implicated in the disease
The bullae are flaccid and are filled with clear fluid
Penicillamine is the most common drug inducing pemphigus vulgaris

questions.solution:
In Pemphigus Vulgaris, desmoglein 3 is the principal antigen against which autoantibodies are produced.

Pemphigus Vulgaris is an immunobullous disease or a chronic blistering disease which occurs due to an autoimmune process, by the production of antibodies (usually IgG) against desmosomes (adhesion proteins).

Oral erosions usually precede the skin manifestations. Other mucosal lesions involve conjunctiva, larynx, pharynx, esophagus, etc.

The skin manifestations include flaccid blisters filled with clear fluid and erythematous base which rupture to produce painful erosions. These are mostly present over the face, scalp, upper chest, back, and neck.

Drug-induced Pemphigus: Penicillamine (Thiol group) is the most common drug implicated in Drug-induced pemphigus.

It usually occurs after 1 year of taking the drug and is seen in patients who are suffering from other autoimmune diseases like rheumatoid arthritis.

Non-thiol drugs which are associated with Drug-induced pemphigus are ACE Inhibitors and glibenclamide.

Phenol group (Cephalosporins, Rifampicin, Phenobarbital, and Aspirin) may also cause Drug-Induced Pemphigus.

questions.text: A 32-year-old male patient is brought to the emergency room with symptoms of confusion, visual changes, palpitations, and diaphoresis. His family recounts that he has had similar episodes that subside after consuming chocolates. Further workup shows the histopathological finding below. Which of the following is true about this patient's condition?

choices.text: C-peptide levels will be low in this patient
Amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette describes an insulinoma and amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature of this condition.

This patient presents with characteristic neuroglycopenic (confusion, visual change, and unusual behavior) and sympatho-adrenergic symptoms (palpitations, diaphoresis, and tremulousness) of hypoglycemia. The image shows neoplastic cells that are monotonous with minimal pleomorphic or mitotic activity. Deposition of amyloid is a characteristic feature of insulinomas.

β-cell tumors (insulinomas) are the most common pancreatic endocrine neoplasms. These are usually benign and often cause symptomatic hypoglycemia. Hypoglycemic symptoms appear when blood glucose levels fall below 50mg/dl. The symptoms usually develop after fasting or exertion and improve after glucose intake.

The most reliable test for diagnosis is a supervised 72-hr fasting test. Blood examinations reveal increased insulin-to-glucose ratio, high circulating levels of insulin, and c-peptides. Insulinomas may occur in association with gastrinomas in patients with MEN 1 syndrome.

Histopathological examination shows giant islets, with preservation of the regular cords of monotonous cells with minimal pleomorphism. Malignant tumors are also well-differentiated. Amyloid deposition is a characteristic feature of many insulinomas.

Surgery is the mainstay of treatment. Medical treatment includes frequent meals and diazoxide or octreotide.

Related Pearl: Pancreatic Endocrine Neoplasms

Endocrine neoplasm

Clinical features

Glucagonoma

Mild diabetes mellitus, a characteristic skin rash (necrolytic migratory erythema), and anemia

Insulinoma

Clinically significant hypoglycemia

Gastrinoma

Peptic ulceration often unresponsive to therapy and in unusual locations such as the jejunum

Somatostatinoma

Diabetes mellitus, cholelithiasis, steatorrhea, and hypochlorhydria

VIPoma

Watery diarrhea, hypokalemia, achlorhydria, or WDHA syndrome

Pancreatic polypeptide-secreting endocrine tumors

Present as mass lesions as even high plasma levels of this hormone fail to cause symptoms

Islet hyperplasia (previously known as nesidioblastosis) is seen in maternal diabetes, Beckwith–Wiedemann syndrome , and rare mutations in the β-cell K+-channel protein or sulfonylurea receptor.

In maternal diabetes, the fetal islets respond to hyperglycemia by increasing their size and number. In the postnatal period, these hyperactive islets may be responsible for serious episodes of hypoglycemia.

questions.text: A patient with melioidosis was prescribed imipenem. Why was this drug administered along with cilastatin?

choices.text: Cilastatin blocks the hepatic metabolism of imipenem.
Cilastatin blocks the renal metabolism of imipenem.
Imipenem blocks the hepatic metabolism of cilastatin.
Imipenem blocks the renal metabolism of cilastatin.

questions.solution:
Imipenem is administered with cilastatin because cilastatin blocks the renal metabolism of imipenem.

Imipenem is rapidly hydrolyzed by the enzyme dehydropeptidase, which is present in the renal tubules. Therefore, imipenem is administered with cilastatin, an inhibitor of dehydropeptidase. Cilastatin inhibits the breakdown and prolongs the action of imipenem. This drug combination is used to treat infections caused by cephalosporin-resistant nosocomial bacteria.

Imipenem is a carbapenem beta-lactam antibiotic. It has a broader spectrum of action than other beta-lactams. It binds to penicillin-binding proteins and disrupts cell wall synthesis, leading to the death of susceptible microorganisms. It is resistant to hydrolysis by most β-lactamases. It is not absorbed orally. The dose should be modified for patients with renal insufficiency.

The FDA approved Recarbrio (a combination of imipenem-cilastatin and relebactam) to treat hospital-acquired bacterial pneumonia and ventilator-associated bacterial pneumonia in patients aged ≥18 years. It was previously approved for the treatment of patients with complicated urinary tract infections and complicated intra-abdominal infections who have limited or no alternative treatment options.

Note: Melioidosis, caused by Burkholderia pseudomallei, resembles glanders disease, which is due to Burkholderia mallei and primarily affects horses, with the potential for transmission to humans. It can present as acute melioidosis, leading to pneumonia with upper lobe infiltrates and symptoms similar to tuberculosis, such as fever, cough, and hemoptysis, potentially progressing to septicemia. In its chronic form, it results in caseous or suppurative lesions, skin abscesses, lymphangitis, and lymphadenopathy, and may also impact bones and internal organs.

questions.text: Psuedo isomorphic phenomenon can be seen in a patient with ________________
questions.solution:
Pseudo-isomorphic/pseudo-Koebner phenomenon can be seen in patients with warts as the new lesions occur due to the seeding of infection.

Koebner phenomenon or true Koebnerisation is typically seen in psoriasis, vitiligo, and lichen planus.

Koebner/isomorphic phenomenon refers to the appearance of new skin lesions on healthy skin at the site of cutaneous injury, in the presence of a pre-existing dermatosis. They are typically linear, as they follow the route of the injury.

Koebner phenomenon is diagnosed clinically using the following characteristics:

  • Linear lesions developing at the site of cutaneous injury on a previously healthy skin
  • Lesions have the same clinical and histological features as the underlying dermatosis
  • Lesions are not due to seeding of an infectious agent, allergic reaction or skin breakdown

The exact cause of such a response is unclear. Theories involving T-cell mediated response, involvement of dermis, and microvasculature are considered. Various triggers for Koebner phenomenon have been identified:

  • Trauma: Insect and animal bites, burns including thermal and electric, excoriation, friction, shaving, lacerations, cryotherapy, pressure sores, and orthotics
  • Chemical irritation: Tattoo associated skin reaction, BCG vaccination, tuberculin skin test, hair dye allergy
  • Diseases: Urticaria, inflammatory dermatoses
  • Others: Phototherapy, sunburn, withdrawal of methotrexate therapy

Other features of Koebner phenomenon include:

  • Graded response to trauma: Intensity of response to trauma is unique to each patient and the underlying disease.
    • No Koebner response to injury
    • Abortive Koebner response: Lesions appear, but spontaneously vanish after a few weeks
    • Minimal Koebner response: Lesions develop at the site of trauma
    • Maximal Koebner response: Wide spread lesions develop across the entire site of trauma
  • All or nothing response: Patients who develop Koebner phenomenon in response to one type of injury, may develop a similar response due to other types of injuries as well. In case, a patient does not exhibit Koebner phenomenon to one type of injury, it is unlikely that it is exhibited after any other type of injury.
  • Time taken to develop the skin lesions is unique to the patient and the specific dermatosis. It may vary from 3 days to 2 years, normally taking around 10-20 days.

Koebner phenomenon can be classified into:

  • True Koebnerisation: New skin lesions seen with the clinical features mentioned above, as seen in vitiligo, psoriasis and lichen planus.  
  • Pseudo-Koebnerisation: Appearance of similar skin lesions at the site of injury in infective lesions like plane warts and molluscum contagiosum, due to the spread of the infective agent (virus) to the new site by seeding, especially due to scratching.

The image below shows Koebner phenomenon seen in a psoriatic patient at the site of trauma.

Koebner phenomenon is also seen in other diseases like:

  • Erythema multiforme
  • Lichen nidatus
  • Necrobiosis lipodica
  • Lupus erythematosus
  • Hailey-Hailey disease
  • Darier disease
  • Vasculitis
  • Pityriasis rubra pilaris

Other phenomena associated with cutaneous trauma are:

  • Reverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of skin lesions after trauma to the area, which is seen in psoriasis after dermabrasion or surgery.
  • Remote reverse Koebner phenomenon: Spontaneous repigmentation is seen in distant patches after autologous skin graft surgery in vitiligo.
  • Wolf's isotopic response/isotopic phenomenon: Emergence of new dermatosis at the site of a previous unrelated dermatosis as seen in granuloma annulare developing at the site of herpes zoster and psoriasis developing at the site of contact dermatitis.
  • Pathergy: Occurance of non-specific papules and pustules secondary to heavy neutrophilic infiltrates after an injection or venipuncture, as seen in pyoderma gangrenosum and Behçet disease.
  • Renbök/inverse Koebner phenomenon: Disappearance of an existing skin condition after the onset of a new dermatosis at the same site, as seen in retention of hair follicles on the psoriatic plaques on the scalp while hair loss was present in unaffected areas of alopecia areata.

questions.text: During a lice outbreak among jail inmates, a few of them developed fevers that subsided after 3-5 days. The fever relapsed after a week and subsided again. Many patients had tender splenomegaly on examination. What is the most appropriate management for the given cases?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario is suggestive of lice-borne relapsing fever (LBRF) caused by Borrelia recurrentis. The most appropriate management is to start Doxycycline therapy.

Relapsing fever is an infectious condition due to Borrelia species and is characterised by two or more episodes of fever with periods of well-being. It can be of two types: 

  • Louse-borne or epidemic relapsing fever acquired from head or body louse and caused by Borrelia recurrentis and
  • Tick-borne relapsing fever acquired from soft ticks 

Clinical features include sudden onset of fever, rigours, pulse and blood pressure rise followed by diaphoresis, temperature fall, and hypotension. Headache, neck stiffness, arthralgia, and myalgia can also be present. There may be hepatosplenomegaly during the episodes, causing abdominal pain. Myocarditis may be present and can lead to death.

The preferred treatment for louse-borne relapsing fever in adults is a 10-day course of doxycycline (100 mg twice daily) or tetracycline (500 mg or 12.5 mg/kg orally every 6 hours). If tetracyclines are contraindicated, erythromycin (500 mg or 12.5 mg/kg orally every 6 hours) for ten days is used as an alternative.

In cases where CNS involvement is suspected or confirmed, intravenous administration of penicillin G (5 million units IV every 6 hours) or ceftriaxone (2 g IV daily) for 10–14 days is preferred. However, if resources are limited and CNS involvement is not suspected, oral penicillin V potassium (500 mg or 12.5 mg/kg every 6–8 hours) can be given for ten days.

Other options: 

Option A: Gentamicin is not used for the management of borrelia as it is relatively resistant to aminoglycosides.  

Options B: Proper personal hygiene and avoiding overcrowding are preventive strategies for this disease. Other preventive strategies include better access to hot water (≥60° C) for clothes washing and use of pesticides in the infested buildings.

Option D: Topical 5% permethrin is used for the treatment of scabies.

Related Pearl: Arthropod- borne diseases

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

questions.text: The image below shows the pattern of cervical secretion under the microscope during a particular phase of the menstrual cycle. What would a vaginal epithelial study during the same phase suggest?
questions.solution:
The image shows a ferning pattern of cervical mucus seen during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle. Estrogen leads to a superficial cell predominance.

The vaginal epithelium is under the ovarian hormonal influences of estrogen and progesterone. In the proliferative phase, under the influence of estrogen, the vaginal epithelium has predominantly superficial cells, which are acidophilic (pink) cells with a pyknotic nucleus.

The progesterone-dominant phase shows the presence of intermediate cells, which are basophilic (blue or green) with distinct margins and nuclei bigger than those of superficial cells seen in the second half of the menstrual cycle and pregnancy. Basal and parabasal cells are seen when no hormone predominates. These are basophilic cells with no distinct outlines and a much larger nucleus. Seen in menopause and the pre-pubertal period.

The image below shows superficial and intermediate cells in vaginal cytology.

Related Pearl: Cytohormonal study of the vaginal epithelium

Layer Cell characteristics Hormones Age of the woman
Parabasal and basal Small, round and basophilic with large nuclei Lack of hormonal activity

Childhood until puberty

Menopause with atrophy
Intermediate cells

Transparent and basophilic (blue-green) with vesicular nuclei

 Progesterone, Androgen, Corticosteroid 

Pregnancy

At an early transition of  menopause
Superficial cells Large cells with a pyknotic nucleus, acidophilic on staining Estrogen

Reproductive period

Preovulatory phase

Note: Malignant cells contain less cytoplasm, and hyperchromatic nuclei which are variable in size.

questions.text: Which of the following factors increase the rate of cooling of a dead body?

choices.text: Bodies in small, ill ventilated room

questions.solution:
The rate of post-mortem cooling is higher in bodies immersed in running water. 

Bodies in running water show an increased rate of postmortem cooling due to the enhanced heat transfer from the body to the surrounding water. The movement of water accelerates the cooling process by continuously removing warmer water layers adjacent to the body, allowing for more efficient heat loss compared to still water or air. Additionally, the temperature of the running water may be lower than the body temperature, further contributing to rapid cooling.

Factors increasing the rate of postmortem cooling:

  • Body immersed in running water
  • Increased difference in the temperature between the body and the atmosphere
  • Large body surface area
  • Children and old aged people
  • Higher humidity and rapid air velocity

The rate of cooling is decreased in:

  • Excess fat
  • Edema
  • Body covered with clothing
  • Bodies in small, ill-ventilated room
  • Deaths due to asphyxia, lightening, CO2 poisoning

questions.text: A 55-year-old woman was admitted to the ICU with suspected severe systemic mycoses. The appearance of the causative organism, as seen on culture from the lesion at 37°C, is shown in the image below. What is the preferred drug for the management of her condition?
questions.solution:
The above image shows the characteristic 'pilot wheel appearance' on culture shown by Paracoccidioides brasiliensis. It causes South American blastomycosis/ paracoccidioidomycosis. Amphotericin B is recommended for the management of severe systemic disease.

Amphotericin B is recommended for moderate to severe disease, central nervous system disease, immunosuppressed patients, or pregnant patients. Itraconazole is recommended for mild-to-moderate disease and step-down therapy.

P. brasiliensis is a thermally dimorphic fungus. It causes paracoccidioidomycosis, a chronic granulomatous disease affecting the lungs, skin, mucosa, and lymph nodes. The characteristic feature is the presence of ulcerative granulomas in the buccal and nasal mucosa.

On culture at 37°C, large oval cells with multiple buds encircling the mother cell are seen. This is known as the Mariner’s or pilot wheel appearance. On culture at 25–30°C, it is found in mycelial phase.

Related Pearl: Systemic fungi - Histopathological findings

Histoplasma: Tiny oval yeast cells (2- 4 μm size) with narrow-based budding within the macrophages with an underlying granulomatous response.

 

Blastomyces : Thick-walled round yeast cells of 8- 15 μm size with single broad-based budding (figure of 8 appearance)

 

Coccidoides : Mature spherules of coccidioidomycus is seen in the above image. Spherules which are large sac like structures (20--80 μm size), have thick, double refractile wall, and are filled with endospores.

 

Paracoccidioides : Round thick-walled yeasts, with multiple narrow-necked buds attached circumferencially giving rise to Mickey mouse or pilot wheel appearance.

questions.text: All of the following clinical features are typically associated with an abscess in the pre-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space, except _______.

choices.text: Swelling behind the angle of the jaw

questions.solution:
Glossopharyngeal nerve palsy is a feature of infection of the post-styloid compartment of the parapharyngeal space and is not a feature of anterior compartment infection/ pre-styloid abscess.

Parapharyngeal space is divided into 2 compartments by the styloid process & its attachments. Clinical features depend on the compartment involved.

Presentation in pre-styloid abscess:

  • prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa
  • trismus (due to spasm of medial pterygoid muscle) along with marked odynophagia
  • external swelling behind the angle of the jaw 

Presentation in post-styloid abscess:

  • Bulge of the pharynx behind the posterior pillar
  • Paralysis of CN IX, X (vocal cord paralysis), XI, and XII and sympathetic chain (Horner’s syndrome)
  • Swelling of the parotid region
  • There will not be any trismus

Related Pearl: Compartments of the parapharyngeal space

  Prestyloid Poststyloid
Relation to styloid Anterior Posterior
Relations

Medially: Tonsillar fossa

Laterally: Medial pterygoid muscle

Medially: Posterior part of the lateral pharyngeal wall

Laterally: Parotid gland
Contents Medial pterygoid muscle

Carotid artery

Jugular vein, IXth, Xth, XIth, XIIth cranial nerves

Sympathetic trunk
Presentation

Prolapse of tonsil and tonsillar fossa,

Spasm of medial pterygoid muscle leading to trismus

The pharynx bulging behind the posterior pillar

Injury to of CN IX, X, XI, and XII leading to vocal cord paralysis

Sympathetic chain injury leading to Horner’s syndrome

Swelling of the parotid region

questions.text: A 52-year-old female patient was brought to the emergency room with complaints of severe headache, sweating, and palpitations. She gives a history of the consumption of red wine. She was on selegiline for treatment of Parkinsonism. On examination, her BP is 200/110mmHg. Which of the following drugs is preferred for treating hypertension in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of cheese reaction and phentolamine is the preferred drug for treating hypertension in this patient.

Tyramine is a sympathomimetic amine. In patients who are on monoamine oxidase inhibitors (selegiline), when they consume tyramine-rich foods like cheese, aged meat, red wine, fish, etc, the amine does not undergo degradation along the intestinal walls and liver and reaches the circulations. These amines release large amounts of catecholamines in the adrenergic nerve endings.

Therefore the patients will present with hypertension, agitation, diaphoresis, tachycardia, muscle rigidity, hyperthermia, etc. This will be followed by hypotension and coma.

Patients should be managed symptomatically by cooling, use of antipyretics, fluid administration, etc. This hypertensive crisis is treated with short-acting drugs like phentolamine.

Phentolamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist that opposes the alpha receptor-mediated vasoconstriction of sympathomimetics. It is also used in:

  • clonidine withdrawal
  • short-term control of hypertension in pheochromocytoma
  • limiting the duration of soft tissue anesthesia.

Other options:

Option A: Phenoxybenzamine is a non-selective alpha antagonist with irreversible action. Short-acting drugs are used to manage hypertension in cheese reactions because long-acting drugs will worsen the hypotensive phase that follows a hypertensive crisis. It is used pre-operatively to reduce blood pressure in pheochromocytoma.

Option C: Prazosin is a selective alpha-1 blocker. Catecholamines act on alpha 1 and alpha 2 receptors that result in vasoconstriction. Another major problem with prazosin is marked postural hypotension and syncope following the first dose (first dose effect). So, using phentolamine is better as it is a non-selective alpha-receptor antagonist. Prazosin has been used in the treatment of hypertension and benign prostatic hyperplasia.

Option D: Propranolol is a non-selective beta-blocker. It can worsen hypertensive crisis by unopposed alpha stimulation. It is used in various conditions like essential hypertension, pheochromocytoma, myocardial infarction, cardiac arrhythmias, etc.

Related Pearl: Parenteral drugs used in hypertensive emergencies

 

Drugs

Contraindications

Beta-blockers

 Labetalol, esmolol, metoprolol

Heart block, systolic heart failure, asthma bradycardia

Calcium channel blockers

Clevidipine, nicardipine

Advanced aortic stenosis 

D1 receptor agonist

 Fenoldopam

Caution in glaucoma

Vasodilators

 

 

Nitroglycerin

 Pericardial tamponade

Nitroprusside

 Relatively contraindicated in liver failure and renal failure 

Hydralazine

ACE inhibitors
