questions.text: A 56-year-old woman is diagnosed with type 2 diabetes mellitus. She has a marfanoid habitus. She also has a history of pheochromocytoma. Which of the following drug should be avoided in her case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a diabetic patient with marfanoid habitus and a history of pheochromocytoma is suggestive of multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome type 2. GLP-1 (glucagon-like peptide) analogues like liraglutide are associated with an increased risk of medullary thyroid carcinoma and are avoided in these patients.

Liraglutide is used as a parenteral hypoglycemic agent and anti-obesity drug. It increases insulin secretion, reduces glucagon release, delays gastric emptying, and normalises fasting and postprandial insulin secretion.

It is administered subcutaneously. It is used as an adjuvant in patients who are not achieving glycemic control with oral agents. It can also be added with basal insulin.

These drugs can cause pancreatitis and medullary thyroid cancer. Hence, they should not be used in patients with a past medical or family history of medullary thyroid cancer or multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) syndrome type 2. 

Side effects of various anti-diabetic drugs are:

Class Example Side effects
Oral
Biguanides Metformin  Diarrhea, lactic acidosis, and vitamin B12 deficiency 
α-Glucosidase inhibitors  Acarbose, voglibose  GI flatulence, elevated liver function tests 
Dipeptidyl peptidase IV inhibitors  linagliptin, saxagliptin, sitagliptin 

Allergy, hypersensitivity reactions (including  Stevens-Johnson syndrome), pancreatitis, nasopharyngitis
Sulfonylureas  Glibornuride, gliclazide, glimepiride  Hypoglycemia, weight gain 
Sodium-glucose cotransporter 2 inhibitors  Canagliflozin, dapagliflozin, empagliflozin  Urinary and genital infections, polyuria, euglycemic DKA
Thiazolidinediones  Pioglitazone, rosiglitazone  CHF, weight gain, fractures, macular edema 
Parenteral/Oral 
GLP-1 receptor agonists  exenatide, liraglutide,  semaglutide (oral)  pancreatitis, medullary thyroid cancer
Parenteral 
Amylin agonists  Pramlintide  increased risk of hypoglycemia with insulin 
Insulin   weight gain, hypoglycemia 

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: In Breslau’s second life test, the organs tested are _______
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s second life test, the organs tested are the stomach and intestine.

BRESLAU’S SECOND LIFE TEST: It is based on the air entering the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water.

Inference:

  • A floating viscera giving out air bubbles when opened underwater is a positive test and suggestive of live birth.
  • False positive – in case of stillbirth, air might enter the stomach when a child tries to free obstruction of air passages.
  • Mucus, saliva and air bubbles in the stomach – breathing has occurred.
  • Only mucus – breathing has not occurred.
  • Blood, meconium, liquor amnii in the stomach – child alive at or shortly before birth.
  • Milk in the stomach – the child was alive for some time after birth.
  • Test is invalid in case of putrefaction.

Other tests for live birth:

  • Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth.
  • Fodere’s test –Based on the increase in the weight of the lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of an unrespired lung is 30 – 40g, whereas the weight of respired lung is 60 – 66g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs- weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:70.
    • Respired lungs- weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:35

questions.text: A  patient with cirrhosis presents to the emergency department with an altered sleep cycle. When asked to draw a star, the patient was not able to draw a perfect one. He appears agitated. On examination, flapping tremors were noted. Which of the following does not form a part of the treatment?
questions.solution:
The diagnosis based on the clinical presentation is hepatic encephalopathy. Benzodiazepines should not be used in its treatment because they may worsen the condition.

Benzodiazepines increase the effects of γr-aminobutyric acid (GABA) neuroinhibitory transmitter by binding endogenous benzodiazepine receptors. This has an inhibitory effect on the brain, thus worsening hepatic encephalopathy.

The clinical features which point to hepatic encephalopathy are:

  1. Altered sleep-wake cycle- this is the earliest symptom
  2. Unable to draw a star - this points to constructional apraxia which is the earliest sign.
  3. Agitation
  4. Flapping tremors- also known as asterixis. It is negative myoclonus. Also seen in carbon monoxide poisoning, and renal encephalopathy. 

Treatment of hepatic encephalopathy includes:

  • Correction of precipitating factors
  • Lactulose - decreased GI transit time due to cathartic actions leading to increased elimination of ammonia
  • Rifaximin - lowers the blood ammonia levels
  • Zinc - serves as a co-factor for the urea cycle and thus stimulating it.
  • L-ornithine L-aspartate - stimulates the urea cycle, resulting in the loss of ammonia

questions.text: If a drug is known to be distributed into the total body water, what dose of the drug is needed to obtain an initial plasma level of 5 mg/L in a male patient weighing 70 kg?
questions.solution:
The drug dose needed to achieve initial plasma concentration is the loading dose, which is 210 mg in this case.

The equation for loading dose or the volume of the distribution equation can be used for calculation.
Loading Dose = Vd × Cp

Since the patient weighs 70 kg and 60% of his body weight is water, he has 42 L (70 L x 60%) of total body water.
Loading Dose = 42 L × 5 mg/L = 210 mg.

questions.text: Pasteurized milk is most commonly tested by:
questions.solution:
The effectiveness of pasteurization of milk is most commonly tested by Phosphatase test.

The phosphatase test evaluates the effectiveness of pasteurization in milk by detecting the presence of alkaline phosphatase, an enzyme found in raw milk. At 60 deg C for 30 mins, this enzyme is usually destroyed. A positive result, indicated by enzyme activity, suggests inadequate pasteurization or addition of raw milk.

Other methods of bacteriological examination of milk-

  • Methylene Blue Reduction Test:  It is a microbiological assay used to evaluate the bacterial load in milk by measuring the time taken for the methylene blue dye to be reduced to colorless due to microbial activity. A shorter reduction time indicates a higher level of microbial contamination, suggesting that the milk may not be of acceptable quality for consumption. It is primarily done for raw milk for gross contamination i.e. pre-pasteurization but can also be done for pasteurized milk for post-pasteurization contamination(Option C)
  • Standard Plate count: It is done for bacteriological quality of pasteurized milk. The current standards include <30000 colonies/ml in pasteurized milk. (Option B)
  • Coliform count : Usually, coliform bacteria should be absent in pasteurized milk. Hence, their presence in the milk is suggestive of improper pasteurization or post-pasteurization contamination due to fecal contamination. (Option D)
  • Turbidity test: The turbidity test assesses milk sterilization by boiling the milk to precipitate heat-coagulable proteins, followed by the addition of ammonium sulfate and filtration. A clear filtrate indicates successful sterilization, distinguishing sterilized milk from pasteurized milk, which may show some turbidity due to residual microorganisms.

questions.text: A patient undergoes hysterosalpingography for the evaluation of infertility. The finding of the study is shown below. Which statement is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Pregnancy can occur in non communicating rudimentary horn
It is a class I type of Mullerian agenesis
Has a functional uterus with normal cervix

questions.solution:
The above hysterosalpingogram shows filling in only one horn of a unicornuate uterus. This is a class II Mullerian duct anomaly. 

A unicornuate uterus occurs when one of the Müllerian ducts fails to develop and elongate properly. In this condition, a fully functional uterus, a normal cervix,(option D) and a typical round ligament and fallopian tube are present on one side. On the opposite side, the Müllerian structures develop abnormally, often resulting in the absence (agenesis) or, more commonly, the presence of a rudimentary uterine horn.

A unicornuate uterus lacking a rudimentary horn presents as a compact, well-defined, elliptical uterus that tilts to one side. The upper part, or fundus, exhibits a concave shape. Three-dimensional imaging reveals a characteristic "banana" configuration for the unicornuate uterus.

Other options: 

Option A: Unicornuate uterus usually has some degree of renal agenesis on the ipsilateral side of the lesion.

Option B: Pregnancy can also occur in the rudimentary uterine horn. In cases of noncommunicating horns, it can occur due to the migration of sperm from the opposite fallopian tube within the abdominal cavity. However, if pregnancy occurs in a cavitary horn, regardless of communication, there is a significant risk of uterine rupture, typically occurring before the 20th week of pregnancy.

  • Vaginoplasty for vaginal hypoplasia

  • Uterine rupture
  • Abortions
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
III Uterus didelphys Unfused paramesonephric duct

Metroplasty- Resection of membrane and fundal recombination. This can be:

  • Hysteroscopic
  • Open e.g., Strassman metroplasty
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
IV Bicornuate uterus  Lower part is fused whereas upper part is unfused Metroplasty in selected cases 
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
V Septate uterus  Septa of fused part persists Hysteroscopic septal resection 
  • Infertility
  • Risk of miscarriage,
  • Malpresentation 
  • Preterm delivery
VI Arcuate uterus A small indentation at upper part    
VII Diethylstillbesterone (DES), drug related T-shaped uterus, shortened and narrow fallopian tubes, cervical collars (Cockscomb cervix)  
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Cervical incompetence
  • Clear cell adenocarcinoma of cervix and vagina

A common complication is an abortion in the second trimester.

Arcuate uterus: Some studies report no increase in adverse outcomes, whereas some studies have shown excessive second trimester loss, preterm labor and malpresentations.

questions.text:
Which of the following essential amino acids are both glucogenic and ketogenic?
  1. Isoleucine
  2. Phenylalanine
  3. Tryptophan
  4. Leucine
  5. Glycine
questions.solution:
The essential amino acids which are both glucogenic and ketogenic include Isoleucine, Phenylalanine and Tryptophan.

Leucine is an essential amino acid that is purely ketogenic, while glycine is a non-essential amino acid that is purely glucogenic.

questions.text:
Which of the following factors is not useful in distinguishing between the enzymes hexokinase and glucokinase?

Glucose-6-phosphate - G6P
questions.solution:
Hexokinase and glucokinase have common substrates and products, thus making them non-differentiable concerning this aspect.

Hexokinase is not an inducible enzyme. Hexokinase has a lower Vmax and a lower Km value than glucokinase. It is inhibited by glucose-6-phosphate.

Difference between Hexokinase and Glucokinase

Characteristics Hexokinase Glucokinase
Tissue distribution (Option C) Most tissues Liver and beta cells of the pancreas
Km (Option A) Low High

Vmax

 Low High
Inhibition by G6P (Option D) Yes No
Inducible  No Inducible 
Clinical significance Deficiency causes hemolytic anemia Less activity in diabetes mellitus
Biological significance Involved in maintaining intracellular glucose concentration  Involved in maintaining blood glucose concentration

questions.text: The muscle involved in the following activity also helps connect the pelvic girdle and vertebral column to the upper limb. Identify the action of this muscle.
questions.solution:
The muscle connecting the pelvic girdle and vertebral column to the upper limb, which is also involved in swimming shown in the image is the latissimus dorsi. Its actions are adduction, extension, and internal rotation of the arm.

The latissimus dorsi is a large muscle of the lower back that connects the pelvic girdle to the upper limb. It originates from the posterior one-third of the outer lip of the iliac crest, posterior layer of the lumbar fascia, spines of T7-T12 vertebrae, lower four ribs and inferior angle of the scapula. It inserts onto the floor of the intertubercular sulcus in the humerus.

Its actions are adduction, extension and internal rotation of the arm. It is used in swimming, rowing, climbing, scratching the opposite scapula and folding the arm across the back. Therefore, it is also known as the “climbing muscle” or “swimmers muscle”. It also helps in forceful expiration and in holding the inferior angle of the scapula in place.

questions.text: The distribution of patients treated with two antihypertensives 1 and 2 have been plotted on the graph as shown below. Which of the following statements is true with respect to this graph?

choices.text: 95% of population in both data sets have similar results
Lower clustering of the data set among patients treated with Drug 1
High frequency of change in the efficacy of Drug 2
Drug 1 has better control of BP as compared to Drug 2

questions.solution:
The correct statement is option B, i.e. lower clustering of the data set among patients treated with Drug 1 as the blood pressures plotted following treatment with Drug 1 are scattered and hence more variable, thus making it comparatively unreliable with respect to Drug 2.

Both the distributions plotted have similar measures of central tendency, i.e. mean, median and mode. It is important to note that drug 2 is more reliable (option D) than drug 1 as there are fewer patients with high or low BP as compared to drug 1. The distribution of patients treated with drug 1 has more scattered plots, making it less clustered together, thus helping us choose a better alternative here, i.e. drug 2. The measures of variability of a data set include range, standard deviation and variance.

Other options:

Option A: As the patients following with drug 1 have a more scattered distribution, there is a higher variability in this population when compared to drug 2. This means that drug 1 consists of a larger fraction of 95% than drug 2, and hence, 95% of the population in both data sets will not have similar results

Option C: This option is incorrect as drug 2  has a lower frequency of change, i.e. high clustering of data as compared to drug 1.

Related Pearl: Mean, Median, Mode in Different Distribution Shapes

  • The relationship between the mean, median and mode depends upon the distribution.
  • In a unimodal symmetrical distribution like a normal distribution, all the three measures are approximately the same, as shown in Figure (2) in the following image, i.e., mean = median = mode.
  • Figure (3) in the following image shows a positively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the positive direction. In this, the mean will be larger than the median and mode, i.e., mean > median > mode.
  • Figure (1) in the following image shows a negatively skewed distribution in which the longer tail is towards the negative direction. In this, the mean will be smaller than the median, i.e., mean < median < mode.

Unimodal symmetrical distribution

Mean = Median = Mode

Positively (right) skewed distribution

Mean > Median > Mode

Negatively (left) skewed distribution

Mean < Median < Mode
  • As seen in the figures above, in any distribution curve, the mode is generally the highest point. The mean will be pulled up or down based on the values in the distribution. The median will lie between the mode and mean and divide the distribution in two equal halves under the curve.
  • A bimodal distribution will have two high points as shown in the image below.
  • Mathematically, the relationship between mode, median and mean in asymmetrical distributions can be given as:
    Mode = 3 median – 2 mean (or) Mean = ½ (3 median – mode).
  • Outlier is the statistical term used for an observation or value that is very distant from other observations in the distribution.
  • In a distribution with outliers, preferred measure of central tendency is the median.
  • Mode is least affected by outliers but mean is the most affected out of all the measures of location.

questions.text:
A 55-year-old woman is diagnosed to have cervical cancer. MRI and PET-CT imaging reveal tumour extension up to the pelvic wall and involvement of the para-aortic lymph nodes. It also shows features suggestive of hydronephrosis. Which stage is it according to the FIGO staging of cervical cancer?

PET-CT - Positron Emission Tomography/Computed Tomography
FIGO - International Federation of Gynecology and Obstetrics
questions.solution:
Cervical cancer involving the para-aortic lymph nodes is classified as Stage III C2 according to FIGO staging.

Cervical cancer is the most common gynecological cancer. The FIGO staging uses clinical, radiological, or pathological findings to stage cervical cancer from Stage I to IV.

Stage III cervical carcinoma involves the lower 1/3rd of the vagina, with or without pelvic wall extension, hydronephrosis, and lymph node involvement. It is further staged as follows:

  • Stage III A: Lower 1/3rd of the vagina involvement, no pelvic wall extension
  • Stage III B: Pelvic wall involvement with or without hydronephrosis or a non-functioning kidney
  • Stage III C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or paraaortic lymph nodes
    • Stage III C1: Metastasis to pelvic lymph node only
    • Stage III C2: Metastasis to para-aortic lymph nodes

Note: If the carcinoma had extended beyond the true pelvis, involving adjacent pelvic organs like the bladder or rectum, it would've been classified as Stage IV A.

Related Pearl: Staging of Carcinoma Cervix

Stage I - limited to the cervix

  • A: Microscopic lesion
    • A1 - stromal invasion <3mm depth
    • A2 - a stromal invasion of ≥3 and <5mm depth
  • B: Macroscopic lesion
    • B1 - stromal invasion ≥5mm depth & tumor size <2cm 
    • B2 - tumor size ≥2cm to <4cm 
    • B3 - tumor size ≥4cm 

Stage II - involves upper 2/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to the upper two-thirds of the vagina without parametrial involvement
    • A1 - tumor size <4cm 
    • A2 - tumor size ≥4cm 
  • B: Extends to parametrium but not upto the pelvic wall.

Stage III - spreads to lower 1/3 of vagina

  • A: Extends to lower 1/3 of the vagina
  • B: Extends to the pelvic wall (hydronephrosis/non-functioning kidney)
  • C: Involvement of the pelvic and/or para-aortic lymph nodes, irrespective of the tumor size and extent
    • C1: pelvic lymph node involved
    • C2: para-aortic lymph node involved

Stage IV - metastasis

  • A: Bladder/bowel involvement (adjacent pelvic organs)
  • B: Distant metastasis

Note: The involvement of vascular/lymphatic spaces does not change the staging. The lateral extent of the lesion is no longer considered.

Stage IIIB is the most common stage of presentation.

Related Pearl: General treatment for primary invasive cervical carcinoma

Stages Fertility preserved Fertility not preserved
IA1 Cervical conization Simple hysterectomy
IA1 (LVSI) Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy Modified radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy
IA2

1. Cervical conization with extraperitoneal pelvic lymphadenectomy

2. Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy

IB1

Some IB2, IIA1

 Radical trachelectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or)chemoradiation Radical hysterectomy and pelvic lymphadenectomy (or) chemoradiation
Bulky IB3, IIA2 Chemoradiation
IIB to IVA Chemoradiation or pelvic exenteration 
IVB Palliative chemotherapy or palliative radiotherapy or supportive care

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl investigated for primary amenorrhea is diagnosed with Mayer–Rokitansky–Kuster–Hauser (MRHK) syndrome. Which of the following characteristics is not associated with this condition?

choices.text: Axillary and pubic hair is present

questions.solution:
The patients diagnosed with Mayer–Rokitansky–Kuster–Hauser (MRHK) syndrome have ovaries that are anatomically and functionally normal.

Mayer-Rokitansky-Kuster-Hauser syndrome or Mullerian agenesis is a condition wherein there is a congenital absence of the uterus and the vagina. The patients have a Karyotype of 46 XX, so the gonads present are ovaries. 

The patient's secondary sexual characteristics are well-developed (Option A and B) with normal external genitalia. The ovaries are normal but have an absence of the uterus and the upper part of the vagina. The patients usually have a blind-ended vaginal pouch. Diagnosis is made with the help of pelvic sonography and  MRI. Patients may have rudimentary Mullerian bulbs without an endometrial cavity.

The investigation algorithm for primary amenorrhea with normal secondary sexual characteristics is given below:

Turner's syndrome have different chromosomal anomalies:

questions.text: Given below is the microscopic appearance of a liver biopsy section of a male patient. Which of the following is not usually seen in this condition?
questions.solution:
The liver biopsy section stained with Perl's Prussian Blue shows blue-stained hepatocyte iron accumulation which is suggestive of hereditary hemochromatosis. Among the following, the feature that is not likely of this condition is choreoathetosis, a movement disorder seen in Wilson's disease due to neurological involvement.

Hemochromatosis, which is an autosomal recessive condition, is caused by excessive iron absorption, most of which is deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver and pancreas, followed by heart, joints, and endocrine organs.

The following features are seen in hemochromatosis :

  • Micronodular cirrhosis
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Abnormal skin pigmentation
  • Koilonychia 
  • Arthropathy
  • Hypogonadism( amenorrhea in females, impotence and loss of libido in the male) 
  • Congestive cardiac failure
  • Chondrocalcinosis or pseudogout

When hemochromatosis results from an inherited disorder, it is referred to as hereditary hemochromatosis. When accumulation occurs as a consequence of parenteral administration of iron it is called secondary hemochromatosis. The adult form of hemochromatosis is almost always caused by mutations of HFE; mutation of TFR2 is far less common.

The main regulator of iron absorption is the protein hepcidin, encoded by the HAMP gene and secreted by the liver.

Other proteins involved in iron metabolism that regulate hepcidin levels include-

  • Hemojuvelin (HJV)
  • Transferrin receptor 2 (TFR2)
  • HFE, product of the hemochromatosis gene.

Decreased hepcidin synthesis has a central role in the pathogenesis of hemochromatosis.

The therapy of hemochromatosis involves the removal of the excess body iron, best accomplished by weekly or twice-weekly phlebotomy of 500 mL (200–250 mg of iron). Chelating agents such as desferoxamine, when given parenterally, remove 10–20 mg of iron per day, which is much less than that mobilized by once-weekly phlebotomy.

Death may result from cirrhosis or cardiac disease. A significant cause of death is hepatocellular carcinomas.

Related Pearl: Classification of Iron Overload

 Primary / Hereditary Hemochromatosis

HFE gene-related

  • Type 1: C282Y mutations of genes encoding HFE 

Non-HFE gene-related

  • Type 2: Juvenile hemochromatosis
    • 2a - HJV mutation (hemojuvelin)
    • 2b - HAMP mutation (Hepcidin)
  • Type 3: Transferrin receptor 2 (TfR2) related 
  • Type 4: Ferroportin-related HH 

Secondary / Acquired Hemochromatosis

Transfusion iron overload

  • Thalassemia major
  • Sideroblastic anemia
  • Chronic hemolytic anemias

Chronic liver disease

  • Alcoholic liver disease
  • Non-alcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Porphyria cutanea tarda

Miscellaneous

  • Congenital atransferrinemia
  • African iron overload (Bantu siderosis)

questions.text: A middle-aged known hypertensive woman presented with complaints of diarrhoea, lower quadrant abdominal pain, fever, and marked leucocytosis. The culture of her stool samples was positive for C.difficile. Which of the following increases the risk of developing this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical history and stool specimen positive for C. difficile toxin positivity suggest a diagnosis of pseudomembranous enterocolitis, and anti-gastric reflux drugs like proton pump inhibitors(PPI) increase the risk of the same.

Chronic treatment with PPIs decreases the absorption of vitamin B12 and increases the risk of bone fractures, with increased susceptibility to certain infections like hospital-acquired pneumonia, community-acquired clostridium difficile infection, and spontaneous bacterial peritonitis in patients with ascites. It is also highly associated with fundic gland polyps and atrophic gastritis. 

Other options: 

Option A: Hypertension is associated with intestinal epithelial dysfunction and reduced microbiota diversity laying a fertile soil for C.difficile infection. ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers (ARBs) attenuate intestinal wall fibrosis and stiffness, increase villi length, decrease intestinal permeability, decrease levels of proinflammatory cytokines (IL-6 and TNF-α ), and improve gut microbiota composition. Other antihypertensive drugs like amlodipine,  increase the expression of tight junctional proteins and, hence, an abundance of beneficial microbiota.

Option B: Vitamin A is an essential fat-soluble vitamin that plays a role in epithelial cell barrier function and immunity. Its deficiency is associated with diarrheal disease, weight loss, and malnutrition. Vitamin D and zinc deficiencies have also been shown to correlate with the severity and recurrence of C.difficile infection. 

Option D: Antimotility agents don’t cause C.difficile infection, although they are preferably avoided while treating patients with pseudomembranous enterocolitis. 

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins

The mechanism of action of various bacterial toxins are as given below:

Increase in cAMP

  • Bordetella pertusis
  • Bacillus anthracis
  • Vibrio cholerae - Cholera toxin
  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat labile toxin

Increase in cGMP

  • Enterotoxigenic E.coli (ETEC) - heat stable toxin

Inhibition of protein synthesis

  • Diptheria toxin: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Pseudomonas: inhibit elongation factor-2 (EF-2)
  • Clostridium difficile
  • Enterohemorrhagic E.coli (EHEC)-Shiga-like toxin: inhibit 60S
  • Shigella dysenteriae- Shiga toxin: inhibit 60S

questions.text: The illustration of a section of an emphysematous lung is shown below. Which of the alveoli would contain higher pressure and in which direction would the air flow in between the two alveoli assuming surface tension to be equal in both the alveoli?

choices.text: Pressure 2>1, Direction of flow from 2 to 1
Pressure 1>2, Direction of flow from 2 to 1
Pressure 2>1, Direction of flow from 1 to 2
Pressure 1>2, Direction of flow from 1 to 2

questions.solution:
This question hinges on the Law of Laplace where P=2T/r since alveoli 1 has a smaller radius than alveoli 2, pressure in alveoli 1 would be greater than that in alveoli 2. The direction of the airflow would always be from an area with high pressure to an area with low pressure thus in this scenario the direction of airflow would be from alveoli 1 to alveoli 2 all on the assumption in the question stem stating that the surface tension is equal in both alveoli.

According to the Law of Laplace: 

where,

P = Collapsing pressure on alveolus (dynes/cm2) or Pressure required to keep alveoli open

T = Surface tension (dynes/cm)

r = Radius of the alveolus (cm)

Collapsing pressure is inversely related to radius i.e. large alveolus (one with a large radius) will have a low collapsing pressure and therefore will require only minimal pressure to keep it open. On the other hand, a small alveolus (one with a small radius) will have a high collapsing pressure and require more pressure to keep it open.

By reducing surface tension, surfactant reduces the collapsing pressure for a given radius. The given diagram shows how surfactant reduces surface tension inside the alveoli:

Emphysema is a chronic obstructive pulmonary disease commonly seen in patients who are between 50–75 years of age with dyspnea being severe very early in the disease, and late-onset cough with scanty sputum. They are often referred to as "pink puffers" due to their typical thin non-cyanotic (pink) appearance with severe dyspnea even at rest. 

Emphysema occurs due to irreversible dilatation and destruction of airspace walls distal to terminal bronchioles. It is particularly severe in patients with α1-antitrypsin deficiency, and smokers. Lung tissue destruction is caused by toxic injury, protease-antiprotease imbalance, oxidative stress, and infection. As a result, the diffusing capacity may be reduced.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman presents to the ER with complaints of fatigue, nocturnal dyspnea and palpitations. The patient's attender gives a history of the patient undergoing a transfemoral catheter a year back to place a pacemaker. Doppler performed showed a shunt. Which of the following may be decreased in this patient?
questions.solution:
This patient's clinical features of fatigue, nocturnal dyspnea, and palpitations are suggestive of a congestive cardiac failure caused due to an arteriovenous fistula which has the potential to lead to reduced diastolic blood pressure.

In an AV fistula, peripheral resistance is decreased because of which diastolic pressure is less leading to higher pulse pressure (Option D). When a patient undergoes a transfemoral catheterization, there is a risk of developing a fistula between the femoral artery and the femoral vein, especially when the needle punctures the wall of the femoral artery in the proximity of the femoral vein.

An arteriovenous fistula allows for blood to bypass the resistance of the systemic arterioles leading to a reduced systemic vascular resistance (SVR) i.e decreased afterload. Low peripheral resistance allows blood to quickly return to the heart leading to increased venous return and a high preload. A combination of high preload and low afterload increases the cardiac output.

Excessively large fistulas can lead to high-output heart failure as the left ventricle fails to keep up with the increased venous return.

A few causes of high-output cardiac failure include:

  • Pagets disease
  • Acquired or congenital arteriovenous fistula
  • Severe anaemia
  • Thiamine deficiency
  • Hyperthyroidism

Other options:

Option A: The turbulence of blood flow would most likely increase due to the increased velocity of blood flow owing to the substantial pressure gradient between the fistulating artery and vein. This concept can be further correlated with Reynold's number which depends on the velocity 'V' as shown in the formula below.

Re - Reynolds number
v – velocity of flow – cm/sec
ρ – density of blood
D – diameter of the vessel in cm
µ – viscosity of blood in poise

Option B: Owing to the large pressure gradient between an artery and a vein there would be increased velocity of blood flow across the formed fistula.

questions.text:
A 45-year-old man is brought to the emergency department one week after sustaining head trauma in a road traffic accident. He complains of severe headache, double vision, and a "whooshing" sound in his head. On examination, he has left-sided pulsatile proptosis, conjunctival injection, chemosis, and a bruit over the left orbit. Which of the following nerves is involved in this condition?

ER - Emergency Room

RTA - Road Traffic Accident
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario presents a case of Caroticocavernous fistula which affects the oculomotor nerve(2), and the trigeminal nerve (3). 

1: Optic nerve 

2: Oculomotor nerve

3: Trigeminal nerve

4: Facial nerve

The cranial nerves involved in caroticocavernous fistula are III, IV, V, and VI. 

Direct communication between the intercavernous portion of the internal carotid artery and the cavernous sinus creates a caroticocavernous fistula(CCF), causing the "whooshing" sound he hears likely due to turbulent blood flow in the affected vessels, which may occur post-head trauma or aneurysmal vessel disease. The classical signs are ptosis, pulsatile proptosis, chemosis, periorbital edema, and diplopia. These are due to the involvement of cranial nerves III, IV, and VI and the ophthalmic division of the 5th cranial nerve. Papilloedema can cause permanent blindness.

These are treated by passing a catheter up the carotid into the fistula, and then occluding it with balloons or coils.

The cavernous sinuses are two large venous plexuses that lie on either side of the body of the sphenoid bone, extending from the superior orbital fissure to the apex of the petrous temporal bone.

Structures related to the lateral wall of the cavernous sinuses are the Oculomotor nerve, Trochlear nerve, and the ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. Within the cavernous sinus are the Abducens nerve and the Cavernous part of the internal carotid artery.

questions.text: Which of the following is most commonly used as a graft for otoplasty in congenital abnormalities?
questions.solution:
Autologous costal cartilage is commonly used as a graft for ear reconstruction surgeries for congenital anomalies like anotia and microtia.

Pinna reconstruction surgeries are done after the age of 6 to 7 years. At around 3 years of age, 85% of the auricular growth is complete and the cartilaginous growth is almost complete by 5 years.

The advantages of costal cartilage grafting include relative ease of carving, abundant volume, and its inherent capacity to survive in a surrounding tissue bed without the need for a specific blood supply.

Other options:

Option A: Pelvic wing bone graft used in orthopedic and maxillofacial surgeries, providing structural support in pelvic fractures and spinal fusions.

Option C : Temporalis fascia is used in middle ear surgeries like tympanoplasty and myringoplasty.

Option D : Septal cartilage is used in rhinoplasty and nasal septum correction for structural support and contouring.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient involved in a road traffic accident was brought unconscious to the emergency room. CT brain reveals the following findings. All of the following are indications for performing an open craniotomy in this patient except?

choices.text: A GCS drop of 4 points in a comatose patient
A GCS drop of 6 points  in a comatose patient

questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the plain computed tomography (CT) scan shows a concavo-convex-shaped hematoma on the left side suggestive of an acute subdural hematoma (SDH). A midline shift > 5mm is considered an indication for performing an open craniotomy.

Acute SDH results from the accumulation of blood between the arachnoid membrane and the dura. The tearing of a bridging vein running from the cerebral cortex to the dural sinuses is the most common cause of acute SDH.

On head CT scan, acute SDH appears as a hyperdense, crescent-shaped (concavo-convex) lesion (as seen in this question)

Open craniotomy for the evacuation of acute SDH is indicated for the following:

  1. Thickness >1 cm
  2. Midline shift >5 mm

Emergent decompression is also recommended to a comatose patient with an acute subdural hematoma less than 1 cm in thickness causing a midline shift of less than 5 mm if any of the following criteria are met:

  •  GCS drops by two or more points from the time of injury to the hospitalization
  •  The patient presents with fixed and dilated pupils
  • ICP is >20mm Hg

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: A 1-year-old child is brought to the clinic with a history of diarrhea for the past day. On examination, he has mild dehydration. Oral Rehydration Solution (ORS) treatment has begun, and zinc supplementation is being considered. What is the correct dose of zinc for this child as per IAP guidelines?
questions.solution:
The correct dose of zinc in a one-year-old child with acute diarrhea would be 20 mg/day for 10-14 days. 

Zinc supplementation is recognized for its remarkable efficacy in alleviating the burden of diarrhea, offering multifaceted benefits. It helps in decreasing the severity of loose stools, decreases the further recurrence of diarrhea, and promotes epithelialization of the GI tract.

In addition to fluids, zinc supplementation is considered standard care for acute diarrhea in children. The correct dose would be : 

  • < 6 months: 10 mg/day
  •  >6 months: 20 mg/day

The duration of treatment is 14 days irrespective of age.

Related Pearl: Symptoms associated with different levels of dehydration

Symptoms No or minimal dehydration Mild to moderate dehydration Severe dehydration
Loss of body weight <3% 3–9% >9%
Mental status Well; alert Fatigued or irritable Lethargic or unconscious
Thirst Drinks normally Thirsty; eager to drink Drinks poorly
Heart rate Normal Normal to increased Tachycardia
Quality of pulse Normal Normal to decreased Weak, thready or impalpable
Skin turgor test Instant recoil Recoil in <2 sec Recoil in >2 sec
Capillary refill Normal Prolonged Prolonged

questions.text: The sensation of a sour taste after consuming an orange rich in citric acid is contributed by the inflow of which of the following ions?
questions.solution:
The sour taste of the orange fruit is triggered by the inflow of protons (H+) via the ENaC channels thus contributing to the sour taste. 

The sour taste from consuming an orange is due to the inflow of H+ ions from citric acid. These H+ ions enter taste receptor cells through proton channels or by blocking K+ channels, preventing K+ from leaving the cell. This causes depolarization, sending signals to the brain, which interprets the sensation as sour. K+ channels play a role by being blocked, but it's the influx of H+ ions that directly triggers the sour taste.

The sour taste is mediated by the TRPV1 channel. The TRPV1 (Transient Receptor Potential Vanilloid 1) channel is involved in detecting the acidity of foods, which contributes to the perception of sour taste.

Taste Receptors

  • Humans have five established basic tastes: sweet, salt, sour, bitter and umami.
  • The taste receptors for these five basic tastes are of two major types:
    • Ligand-gated channels (ionotropic receptors): for salt and sour taste
    • G-Protein Coupled Receptors (metabotropic receptors): for sweet, bitter and umami
  • Salt and sour taste are mediated through epithelial sodium channels (ENaC)
    • Na+ movement through ENaC → salt taste (Option A)
    • H+ movement through ENaC → sour taste
  • Sweet, bitter, and umami are sensed via GPCRs
    • T1R2 and T1R3 families→ sweet taste
    • T2R family → bitter taste
    • T1R1, T1R3, and Metabotropic glutamate receptor (mGluR4) → Umami 

Other options:

Options C and D: K+ and Cl- ions have no role in contributing to the sour taste sensation.

questions.text: The histology image of a cartilage is shown below. Which of the following structures is not made up of this type of cartilage?
questions.solution:
The histology image shows a white fibro cartilage which is not seen in articular cartilage. Articular cartilage is a type of hyaline cartilage. 

The given image shows prominent collagen fibers arranged in bundles with intervening rows of chondrocytes. This is suggestive of white fibrocartilage.

Microscopy of fibrocartilage shows the following:

  • Chondrocytes- round in shape (in tendons they are flattened and elongated)
  • Ground tissue with collagen fibers- type I collagen fibers
  • Absence of perichondrium

Fibrocartilage is found in:

  • Articular discs (temporomandibular joint and sternoclavicular joint)
  • Intervertebral discs
  • Menisci
  • Glenoid and acetabular labrum  
  • Pubic symphysis
  • Manubriosternal joint
  • The lining of the bony grooves for tendons

The image below describes the histology of different types of cartilage.

Related Pearl: Types of Cartilage

Type of Cartilage Hyaline Cartilage Elastic Cartilage Fibrocartilage
Colour Bluish opalescent Yellow White
Collagen type Type 2 Type 2 Type 1 (mainly) and type 2
Perichondrium Present (except at epiphyses & articular cartilage) Present Absent
Calcification Occurs with old age No calcification Occurs only with bone repair
Cells Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Chondroblasts & chondrocytes Fibroblasts & chondrocytes
Fibres Thin collagen Elastic fibres Thick collagen
Examples

Arytenoids except for apices

Cricoid cartilage

Thyroid cartilage

Trachea and bronchi

Articular cartilage at ends of bones

Epiphyseal plate

Costal cartilages of ribs

Temporary skeleton in embryo

Apices of arytenoid

Epiglottis

Corniculate cartilages

Cuneiform cartilages

Eustachian tube

Pinna(Auricle)

External auditory meatus 

Articular discs e.g. of Temporomandibular joint and Sternoclavicular joint

Intervertebral discs

Menisci

Glenoid and acetabular labrum   

Pubic symphysis

Manubriosternal joint

Lining of the bony grooves for tendons

questions.text: You are planning to perform elective hernioplasty for a patient who has a history of myocardial infarction for which a drug-eluting stent was placed 2 months ago. At the very least, how long from now should the patient's procedure be postponed?
questions.solution:
The elective hernioplasty should be postponed in this patient who had a drug-eluting stent placed 2 months ago. It is advisable to wait an additional 4 months, totalling 6 months post-stent placement, before proceeding with surgery.

According to the American Heart Association, elective non-cardiac surgeries should be postponed for a minimum of 1 month, if a bare metal stent is placed and a minimum of 6 months, if a drug-eluting stent is placed in the coronary artery. This is followed in order to reduce the occurrence of stent thrombosis and perioperative cardiovascular complications.

In exceptional cases where the risk of cardiovascular complications is considered less when compared to the risk due to further delay in the surgery, a time period of 3 to 6 months is followed on a case-to-case basis

questions.text: A patient presents to the OPD with complaints of inguinoscrotal swelling. On performing Zeiman’s three-finger test, a cough impulse is felt on the index finger. Identify the correct sequence of coverings of the hernia sac from inside to outside.

choices.text: Fascia transversalis - conjoined tendon - external spermatic fascia
Internal spermatic fascia - cremasteric fascia - external spermatic fascia
Fascia transversalis - cremasteric fascia - external spermatic fascia
Internal spermatic fascia - conjoined tendon - external spermatic fascia

questions.solution:
The above case of an inguinoscrotal swelling which on Zeiman’s three-finger test shows an impulse in the index finger is an indirect inguinal hernia and the correct sequence of covering from inside to outside would be Internal spermatic fascia - cremasteric fascia - external spermatic fascia

Indirect hernias occur majorly due to partial or complete patency of processus vaginalis but others may be acquired as a result of progressive weakening of the posterior wall of the inguinal canal in the region of the deep ring. It may descend into the scrotum. Its coverings from inside to outside are: 

  • Extraperitoneal tissue 
  • Internal spermatic fascia
  • Cremasteric fascia 
  • External spermatic fascia
  • Skin

Direct inguinal hernias occur through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal through the Hesselbach’s triangle bounded by the inferior epigastric artery, lateral border of rectus abdominis, and inguinal ligament. This area is divided into medial and lateral by the passage of obliterated umbilical artery.

The coverings of a medial direct inguinal hernia:

  • Extraperitoneal tissue 
  • Fascia transversalis
  • Conjoined tendon
  • External spermatic fascia
  • Skin

The coverings of a lateral direct inguinal hernia:

  • Extraperitoneal tissue 
  • Fascia transversalis
  • Cremasteric fascia
  • External spermatic fascia
  • Skin

Ziemann's Three-Finger Test is used to distinguish between direct, indirect, and femoral hernias. The examiner places three fingers over the inguinal region: the index finger over the deep inguinal ring, the middle finger over the superficial inguinal ring, and the ring finger over the femoral canal. A cough impulse felt on the index finger indicates an indirect hernia, on the middle finger a direct hernia, and on the ring finger a femoral hernia. This test helps assess the type of hernia but may require imaging for confirmation.

Related Pearl: Difference between Direct and Indirect inguinal hernias:

  Indirect hernia Direct hernia
Age Young Elderly
Herniation Through the deep inguinal ring Through the posterior wall of the inguinal canal
Shape Pyriform/oval Globular/round
Descent Obliquely and downwards Directly forwards
Descent to scrotum Complete – descends till the bottom of the scrotum Rarely complete
Neck Narrow Wide
Sac Lateral to the inferior epigastric artery Medial to the inferior epigastric artery
Zieman’s test Cough impulse on the index finger Cough impulse on the middle finger
Invagination test Tip of finger Pulp of finger
Ring occlusion test Doesn’t bulge Bulges medial to occluding finger
Coverings

Extraperitoneal tissue

Internal spermatic fascia

Cremasteric fascia

External spermatic fascia

Skin

Extraperitoneal tissue

Fascia transversalis

Conjoint tendon

External spermatic fascia

Skin
Obstruction/strangulation Common Rare
Sac Should be opened during surgery Not necessary
  Usually unilateral Usually bilateral

Related Pearl: Inguinal canal

It is a 4 cm long intermuscular canal directed downwards, forwards, and medially.

It extends from the deep inguinal ring to the superficial ring.

Boundaries:

Boundary

 Structures forming

Anterior wall
  • Skin, superficial fascia, external oblique aponeurosis (whole extent)
  • Muscle fibers of internal oblique (lateral 1/3rd)

Posterior wall
  • Parietal peritoneum, extraperitoneal tissues, fascia transversalis (whole extent)
  • Medially reinforced by the conjoint tendon and reflected part of the inguinal ligament

Roof
  • Arched fibers of internal oblique and transversus abdominis forming the conjoint tendon medially

Floor
  • Grooved surface of the inguinal ligament
  • Lacunar ligament at the medial end
 

Deep inguinal ring is an oval opening in the fascia transversalis situated 1.25cm above the mid-inguinal point.

Superficial inguinal ring is a triangular opening in external oblique aponeurosis situated 1cm above and lateral to pubic crest (or medial to the pubic tubercle).

Related Pearl: Boundaries of Hesselbach’s triangle

  • Lateral - inferior epigastric artery
  • Medial - lateral border of rectus abdominis
  • Inferior - inguinal ligament

Direct inguinal hernia emerges through Hesselbach’s triangle (Hence situated medial to inferior epigastric artery)

Indirect inguinal hernia enters deep inguinal ring (Hence it is lateral to inferior epigastric artery)
